story:
About The Idle Playthings

Bath based comedy troupe The Idle Playthings are a great comedy package, they do it all - Stand up, Sketches, Improv – all the points of the comedy trifecta. From humble beginnings sidelining in various festivals (The Independent Bath Literature Festival, The Jane Austen Festival and Bath Live Art Project) the Playthings have really come into their own. Under the guidance of president Luke Mallison, ("a fast developing young force to be reckoned with" - Danny's Comedy Club 2013) who supported Russell Howard earlier this year, they have hosted their own range of cabaret nights; 'BringBackCabaret', had a 3 year run as part of the Independent Bath Literature festival,  performed a Bath Fringe Festival sketch show 'The Ladle of Destiny' and ran charity comedy events for Oxjam Bath and Movember UK.  One of their most recent gigs was a sellout gig at Komedia, Bath.

"Comedy Gold" Milk Magazine 2013
"Not to be Missed" SpaLife Magazine 2013 

The Idle Playthings are embarking upon their debut show at Edinburgh fringe, Ctrl, Alt, Sketch: A Musical Sketch Show. "We browse the history of the internet from its inception to the present web of cats, porn and catty porn with one simple question: where did it all go wrong?" The troupe have been working towards this aim for the past few years and now we finally have the chance we've been waiting for.


What We Need & What You Get

Here's the breakdown:

  • We aim to raise £500 which will go towards transport, promotion and accommodation whilst in Edinburgh.
  • The Playthings have devised a selection of unique perks (listed on the right) from our unending gratitude to Idle Playthings merchandise (only available at selected Idle Playthings retailers...so mainly this website)! 
  • If we don't reach our entire goal, don't worry we won't get stranded in Carlisle. We'll put all the money we raise, towards what we can to get us to the Fringe; petrol, bus, canoe.

This project is really important to us. We've worked incredibly hard to get to Edinburgh and now we've got the chance.

For more information about the Idle Playthings find us at;

Twitter: https://twitter.com/IdlePlaythings1

Facebook: https://www.facebook.com/BathSpaComedy

YouTube: https://www.youtube.com/user/TheIdlePlaythings

Edinburgh Blog:  https://ctrlaltsketch.wordpress.com/


Or listen to our SpaLife Radio show: https://www.mixcloud.com/spaliferadio/

story:
THE THIEF COMETH is an original one-woman show by Daniella De Jesús about the gentrification of Bushwick, Brooklyn. Thirteen characters experience loss, opportunity, and discrimination, as they confront the transformation of their neighborhood. Last summer, under the direction of Stephen Chacon, The Thief Cometh was performed in a number of parks in the gentrified or gentrifying neighborhoods of Bushwick, Williamsburg, and the Lower East Side. Just recently, we have been selected to be part of the 5th Annual United Solo Festival in New York City in the fall of 2014. To be officially admitted to the festival, we have to come up with a $495 participation fee by March 30th--that's where you come in. With your help we can bring The Thief Cometh to a larger audience in the hopes of spreading awareness about the effects of gentrification on the gentrified. 


What We Need & What You Get

We need $495 by March 30th, to complete our participation fee
  • By donating $100, you get: your name in the program, a signed copy of the script, a digital copy of Civil JustUs' EP "The Uncle Billy Tape", and a hand-written thank you letter from Daniella
  • $50: A signed copy of the script, a digital copy of Civil JustUs' EP "The Uncle Billy Tape" and a hand-written thank you letter from Daniella
  • $25: A digital copy of Civil JustUs' EP "The Uncle Billy Tape" and a hand-written thank you letter from Daniella
  • $10: A photograph from the original production and a hand-written thank you letter from Daniella

The Impact

Daniella De Jesús, a student at New York University’s Tisch School of the Arts and a lifelong resident of Bushwick, has developed and produced work that empowers the underrepresented and incites her audience to political action. At this critical point in her artistic development, the support of United Solo would enable this young artist to continue telling stories that normally are not given the opportunity to be told.

The Thief Cometh, while it is written and performed by a single woman, is not a singular story. Inspired by interactions with the residents of Bushwick and residents of other gentrifying neighborhoods, this play tells the story of a community and reminds it’s audience that as a community, they have the power to retain the integrity of their neighborhood. By funding this project you can aid in telling the stories of people that are not normally  told and bring theatre to an audience who may have otherwise never been exposed to it. 

Other Ways You Can Help

  • Spread the word.
  • Share. Share. Share.

God is Hood. And word is weight.
-Daniella De Jesús

story:
The Box Colony Theatre is Producing a Brand New Full-Length Play!

The Box Colony Theatre is celebrating its 5th season and this year we're bringing something new to the table. This October, alongside Jersey City's Art House Productions, we'll be producing Alexander Janosek Doyle's new play, Is That Danny DeVito?, an absurd comedy parodying Waiting for Godot. 

Written in the style of the absurdist comedies of Samuel Beckett, Is That Danny DeVito? focuses on the psychological non-adventures of two over-educated but under-employed millennials as they wait for a perpetually delayed bus to return them from their New England campsite to their beloved Garden State.

As they wait, Dusty (Julian Gordon) and Geoff (David Gazzo) pass the time with the help of bizarre locals (Natasha Edwards & Carlo Fiorletta) and conversations on topics ranging from the millennial experience to celebrity culture, pop entertainment, literature, New Jersey, and whether or not a man unseen to the audience is Danny DeVito.

This production marks our first collaboration with Art House Productions, a driving force behind Jersey City’s growing arts scene.

Mark your calendars: performances will be held at Art House Productions, 136 Magnolia Avenue, Jersey City, NJ on Oct. 8, 9, 10, 16, and 17 (8 p.m.) and Oct. 11 & 18 (2 p.m.) Tickets will become available this fall.

Starring: Julian Gordon, David Gazzo, Natasha Edwards, & Carlo Fiorletta
Executive Producers: Christine Goodman & Alexander Janosek Doyle
Co-Producers: Carlo Fiorletta, Charles Foster Cohen, & Melissa Weiss
Director: Amanda Levie
Technical Director: Lance Michael
Theater Manager: Shimeon Nandlal
Stage Manager: Summer Dawn Hortillosa


Help Us Meet Our Goal of $5,000

We're looking to raise $5,000 for this production of Is That Danny DeVito? in order to produce the best show we can. The funds we raise will go towards the purchase of unique costumes, set pieces, and props, print and web advertising, and stipends for our four actors, director, and theatre technicians. The Box Colony Theatre Inc. is a registered 501(c)(3) non-profit organization, and donations to the company are tax-deductible to the fullest extent of the law. 

Join Us for a Paint & Sip Event

For the first time (and hopefully not the last!), we are hosting a Fundraising Party to thank our higher-level donors for your contributions to The Box Colony Theatre. On September 25th at 8pm, join us for a  two-hour "Paint and Sip" Event in Downtown Jersey City, where you will learn to paint on canvas in a fun, relaxing environment while drinking complimentary wine and beer and mingling with other Box Colony Theatre supporters! Alcoholic drinks will be served at no additional charge (but only to our guests 21 and older!), but please feel free to BYOB if you'd prefer. 

For a ticket to this event, donate at a level of $75 or higher and claim the "Paint & Sip Event" perk on this page. We'll send you a ticket to the event along with the exact location and details of the party. But don't delay; we have a limited number of tickets available! 

Claim the "Paint & Sip Event" perk to learn how to paint this image!

We're Already Ramping Up for the Production

Our talented director, Amanda Levie, and our team of skilled actors have begun rehearsals. Over the next few weeks we will need to begin implementing the many elements of stagecraft - sets, costumes, props, lights, and sounds - to help tell our story.

Can't Contribute? That's Ok! Just Come to the Show!

We understand that donating to our production isn't in everybody's budget. That's that's okay, you can help out The Box Colony Theatre and Is That Danny DeVito? by purchasing tickets (when available) to the show! 

Tickets will be on sale on September 10th at Brown Paper Tickets and you can keep updated about the show at boxcolonytheatre.com. 

About The Box Colony Theatre

The Box Colony Theatre is dedicated to producing new and extant works of theatre that are inventive and imaginative without sacrificing affordability. Theatre should be available to all who are eager to participate in the conversation. Thus, it is The Box Colony Theatre's mission to develop new audiences by offering very affordable ticket prices. The Box Colony is an ensemble.

As a 501(c)(3), The Box Colony is largely supported by charitable and in-kind donations, all of which are tax-deductible under section 170 of Internal Revenue Code. To learn more about The Box Colony Theatre or to make a donation, please visit www.boxcolonytheatre.com.

The Box Colony Theatre has been active in New York City and Jersey City since 2011, perhaps most notably in 2013 when it’s production of Dan Kitrosser’s play theMUMBLINGS received critical acclaim in the New York International Fringe Festival. The Box Colony most recently produced the short play "Statue of Limitations" by Alexander Janosek Doyle & Melissa Weiss as part of the Stagefest 2014 festival at the Landmark Lowe’s in Jersey City.

story:
Geek Theater Has Arrived!

The Rogues Gallery, a Geek Theater Company proudly presents the world premier of "Shoggoths on the Veldt," a CTHULHU adventure comedy by Cameron McNary. Directed by Artistic Director Daniel Wood.

"When famed Victorian explorer Melford Pumbleshire is torn to pieces by something horrible and unseen while on safari in Deepest, Darkest Africa, his redoubtable fiance Euphonia Riggstone must lead an expedition to put his unquiet spirit to rest. In this globe trotting thriller, romance, betrayal, and a two-fisted adventure ensue as Euphonia must deal with perfidious cultists, an amnesiac ghost, ancient horrors and... the Shoggoths on the Veldt!"


 So Who Are You?
Founded by acclaimed director, actor and overall geek Daniel Wood, The Rogues Gallery is a theater company dedicated to producing plays with geek themes. The spark of the idea for this theater company was born at PAX Prime 2010, in front of an audience of 550 geeks during a standing ovation for the world premier of Cameron McNary's play "Of Dice and Men", about a group of 30-something Dungeons & Dragons players. It was a monumental experience which famously made Tycho's mom cry. 
Now Daniel and Cameron are teaming up once again to bring you his newest brilliant incarnation, "Shoggoths on the Veldt."

What's This All About Then? 

Putting on a professional play is expensive. Putting on a professional play that includes the kind of special effects necessary for a good CTHULHU story even more so. The $5,000 we raise will be used to design props of eldritch horror, purchase exotic weapons for epic stage fights, create gorgeous period costumes designed by award winning costume designer Julia Evanovich and, of course, as any good CTHULHU story needs, build giant tentacles with which to assault our heroes.  

But Why Give To This Show? 

Because nobody else is doing anything like this.  Because we want to bring genuine, unabashed geekery to the stage; the kind of geekery that has been shamefully absent from live theater. Because we're just a small crew of scrappy scoundrels in the big, black 'verse of Seattle theater. Raising $5,000 is infinitesimally tiny compared to the budget of a theater like the Seattle Rep, but for a crew like us it feels like trying to make the Kessel run in less than 12 parsecs. Unlike the Seattle Rep, we don't have access to tens of thousands of dollars in government grants and we don't have the backing of Rich White People and their large corporate money. 

What we have is you. 

And we're telling all new stories--exciting, fun, original stories--stories those big theaters don't want to tell you. All of our money is going to the artists instead of bloated administrative costs. All of our money is going toward innovation and creativity and adventure. And we need you to succeed.

Risks & Challenges

If we don't raise this money then we will have to perform the play with shoe string and duct tape and pay our artists with a complimentary cheese platter. WE ARE SOMEWHAT INNOVATIVE. But not even we would be able to overcome that disaster. 

Perks

We've got a bunch of great perks we're very excited about so make sure to read them all. As a non-profit powered by Fractured Atlas your contributions are tax-deductible by the fullest extent of the law. 


Other Ways You Can Help

Some people just can't contribute, but that doesn't mean they can't help:

  • Contact people who would be interested personally and let them know they can help contribute to bring this show to life!
  • Share this link on your blog and social media. Talk about us. Like us on social media.

And that's all there is to it. We're really excited to bring this hilarious, heart felt, geeky story to life. You are instrumental in achieving that. 


The Rogues Gallery is a sponsored project of Fractured Atlas, a non-profit arts service organization. Contributions for the charitable purposes of The Rogues Gallery must be made payable to Fractured Atlas only and are tax-deductible to the extent permitted by law.

story:
About Me:

Kenneth Johnson began moving and grooving at a very young age. His parents signed him up for little league baseball, and they discovered his talent, dance. While Kenneth would be in the outfield waiting to catch the ball, he would groove to the music playing in the park. That's when his parents knew they were going to have an artist. Kenneth enrolled in the performing arts school Rozelle Elementary and that was the start of his dancing experience. At the age of 7, he saw his first Alvin Ailey show and it changed his life. He wanted to be a professional dancer. As time continued, Kenneth found a huge interest in Hip Hop. At the age of 16, he started dancing with Subculture Royalty, a Hip Hop dance based company. Seeing the possibilities of being a professional, Kenneth enrolled into the Dance Program at The University of Memphis to further his dance experience. Kenneth has been teaching Hip Hop and Lyrical across Memphis for more than 4 years. Kenneth says “Being an artist allows me to connect to others, and being a teacher allows me to open possibilities to others, who don’t know their potential”  He is striving to be one of the top choreographers and teachers in the world. 

A month ago Kenneth auditioned for the American Dance Festival Conference, which is based out of Durham, North Carolina. This is an intensive 6 week program. Kenneth will be learning a plethora of styles ranging from Modern to Ballet.



What We Need 

I need 5,000 dollars to make this trip happen! 

These are the expenses:

Application Fee: $40

Tuition: $1,990

Dorm:  $1,333

Dorm Damage: $50

Dorm Key Deposit: $100

Meal plan: $1,140

Student Health Center: $110

Plane ticket: $400

The Impact

Your contribution means the world to Kenneth. Dance is Kenneth. Dance is Kenneth’s life. This program can change his life, take his dancing to the next level. To interact with some of the nations best choreographers and receive valuable feedback can evolve this amazing dancer into the world’s next sensational choreographer. By simply donating a few dollars you are investing into Kenneth’s future and the future of dance.

story:
DSD in a nutshell & What makes us different

Dance Scratch Day is a free one day event happening for the first time in Edinburgh. Its aim is to engage dancers and audience from different backgrounds (contemporary, tango, pole dance etc.) and is open to everyone. 

In this day event apart from the performances, a workshop of "Physical Theatre with Vocals" will take place, as well as a party of free admission, where everyone - dancer or not - can take part in it. 

The team behind DSD are both dancers and Event Manager graduates, which guarantees the ability to meet the needs of the dancers and the professionalism needed for that kind of event with a minimum to a low budget. 

The team of DSD is :

Art Director : Antigoni Chroni

Production Manager : Kostis Vrettos

Project Manager : Vasilis Mitrakas

Communications Manager : Ismini Inglesi

Marketing Manager : Sara Albertinelli

What We Need & What You Get

In order to achieve our goal, we will need your help. Of course, for your contribution you will receive perks.

But, let's break down our costs and need to run an Indiegogo campaign.

  1. Marketing - Promo Material. We need to create programs/flyers and print our posters. 
  2. Technical Equipment (Lights & Sound).
  3. Air tickets for dancers arriving from Greece.
  4. Props for the stage.

Other Ways To Help Us

We understand that you might not be able to give us money, or even as much money as you want to. However, you can still help us if you share our campaign with your friends and on your social media platforms.
story_txt:
DSD in a nutshell & What makes us different
Dance Scratch Day is a free one day event happening for the first time in Edinburgh. Its aim is to engage dancers and audience from different backgrounds (contemporary, tango, pole dance etc.) and is open to everyone. 
In this day event apart from the performances, a workshop of "Physical Theatre with Vocals" will take place, as well as a party of free admission, where everyone - dancer or not - can take part in it. 
The team behind DSD are both dancers and Event Manager graduates, which guarantees the ability to meet the needs of the dancers and the professionalism needed for that kind of event with a minimum to a low budget. 
The team of DSD is :
Art Director : Antigoni Chroni
Production Manager : Kostis Vrettos
Project Manager : Vasilis Mitrakas
Communications Manager : Ismini Inglesi
Marketing Manager : Sara Albertinelli

What We Need & What You Get
In order to achieve our goal, we will need your help. Of course, for your contribution you will receive perks.
But, let's break down our costs and need to run an Indiegogo campaign.

Marketing - Promo Material. We need to create programs/flyers and print our posters.

Air tickets for dancers arriving from Greece.

story:
"The Waste Land: A Performance/Installation"

is the collaboration between a painter, an actor and a poet. Eliot’s famous 1922 poem is interwoven in its entirety into this performance/installation, designed by Daniel Domig and performed by Christopher Domig. This project will have its World Premiere at the New York International Fringe Festival 2015. 

The Team

Daniel Domig was born in Vancouver, Canada, raised in Salzburg, Austria and attended the Academy of Fine Arts in Vienna, where he now resides. Domig’s work engages with the darker, hidden aspect of human psychology through exploration of the corporeal form, while simultaneously testing both the limitations and potential of painting and installations. His work is a commentary on the representation of the individual experience in the external environment. His installation “If All Else Fails” at Thrust Projects, NYC was awarded a Critic’s Pick in the publication Artforum. www.currentlynowhere.com

Christopher Domig was born and raised in Salzburg, Austria, and now resides in Brooklyn. He holds an M.F.A in Acting from Southern Methodist University. His recent theatre work includes the world tour of the Award-Winning play Dirt by Robert Schneider, for which he received the FringeNYC Outstanding Actor Award. He is a two-time NY Innovative Theatre Awards nominee for Outstanding Solo Performance and Outstanding Actor in a Lead Role for his work in Dirt and A Mysterious Way.  His feature film and TV credits include Apartment 4E, Bastards Of Young, 3 People I’ve Never Heard Of, The Blacklist, Boardwalk Empire, and Blue Bloods. www.christopherdomig.com

How you can help:

Funds raised will go towards paying our crew for their time, rehearsal spaces, set construction, and other production expenses and fees such as insurance and promotion.
You can also help by seeing the show! And by following us on Facebook, Twitter and Instagram #wastelandproject


See The Wasteland at the Fringe Festival!

FringeNYC, is the largest multi-arts festival in North America. It takes place over the course of two weeks every August, spread on more than 20 stages across several neighborhoods in downtown Manhattan. Each year thousands of applicants and companies apply and around 200 shows are chosen using a jury-based selection process. We are excited for The Wasteland to have it's World Premiere here in NYC at the Fringe and hope you can attend.


Performances:

Wednesday 8/19 - 5:15pm

Saturday 8/22 - 2:45pm

Monday 8/24 - 9:30pm

Wednesday 8/26 - 3:00pm

Saturday 8/29 - 7:00pm

Running Time: 1 hour 

Venue #12: 

64E4UNDERGROUND

64 East 4th St.

(Bowery & 2nd Avenue)

Tickets on sale July 17th at http://tinyurl.com/o4duyur


Photography by: Topher Ayrhart

story:
Helsinki West Theatre Ensemble is devoted to lionhearted storytelling through brave, emotionally available, physically capable, an viscerally captivating acting that leads to unforgettable performances. We wish to offer an artistic home and a creative haven for our actors, directors, writers, and audiences. We welcome you to join us on this exciting journey into our very first full length production.


I Gelosi, by David Bridel, tells the story of Italy's first great traveling theatre troupe. In the late 16th century the Gelosi company takes the provinces by storm, thanks to the beauty, wit and charm of Isabella Andreini, one of the very first women ever to play on the stage. Invited to perform at the Court of King Charles IX of France, the Gelosi become the toast of Europe - until they risk the wrath of the Pope with a virulent theatrical satire...


I Gelosi, is, fittingly for us, a story of the birth of a new theatre company. We follow an ensemble of enthusiastic players and their passions, joys, and despairs, both on and off the stage. In a form of meta-theatre, some serious questions are asked: Who, if anyone, should have authority over the artists' expression? Do we do theatre for fame, for profit, for food, for the love of poetry, or do we do it for a political agenda, revenge, or perhaps out of a deep desire to make sense of our own existence and purpose in life, to heal wounds, uplift hearts, and make a change for the better in the world? 


We need to raise $10,000  to cover our production costs.

That $10,000 covers:

  • Performance space rental at Six01 Studios in Burbank
  • Rehearsal space rental in Glendale
  • Raw materials to build the world of our play in a warehouse space
  • Actor/Designer pay
  • Lighting and Equipment rental
  • Costumes
  • Publicity


Just like the Gelosi, we are a fledgling theatre company finding our way and speaking our truth, running into the same challenges theatre companies have had throughout centuries. Our show is timely, especially right now, here in LA where the 99-seat debate is heating up the walls of every small and mid-sized theatre. 

We believe that the best work comes when actors are truly an ensemble, and that theatre is a craft to be respected. We are deeply committed to the vision we have for this company. By supporting our first production, you will allow us to build a foundation for the future. Please help us get there. If you want to read more about our mission statement, or what we’re up to, check us out on social media, or visit our website.

We welcome you to join us on our first artistic journey! 

Thank you for your support and belief!

www.helsinki-west.com

Instagram: @helsinkiwest

Facebook: www.facebook.com/helsinkiwest

story:
About the Play

When Christopher Robin runs away from freshman year of college and into the Hundred Acre Wood, he finds things aren’t exactly how he remembered them: Piglet’s a shut-in, Owl’s a twat, and Pooh's, well, still his very best friend. Some things never change, but there’s definitely something amiss in the Wood, and Christopher Robin is in for a rude awakening…

In competition as part of the Thespis Theater Festival in August, this brand new play, set in the world of Winnie the Pooh, is self-produced by the playwright, Theodore Wolf, and his team. While the festival very generously provides performance space at the Hudson Guild Theater, there's so much more that goes into a fully-realized staging, so we need your help to make this production the beautiful and theatrical piece that we envision.

Evening performances will be August 24th and 26th at 9pm, with a matinee on the 29th at 3:30pm. Tickets are available online and at the door for $20!


What We Need

Our initial funding goal is a modest $2000. This will pay for our festival fee, rehearsal space, and basic costumes, props, and set pieces. This is the minimum that we need to bring the play to life.

Once we've reached that initial goal, we will have stretch goals that will allow us to create even more! The bigger our budget can be, the more we can do for you, the audience!

Just as Christopher Robin needs help from his stuffed-animal friends, we need help from you. Be one of those friends for us, and we'll reward you with much more than just a beautiful production. Check out our list of perks in the sidebar!

We are confident that we will reach our initial funding goal of $2000. But, even if we don't, you have no need to worry that your money could go to waste. We are already booked as part of the Thespis Theater Festival, and we will be performing in August, no matter what! Any amount of money that we raise will go toward making this production the very best that it can be, whether it's $1000 or $10000!


About the Team

100 Aker Wood is the first full-length play by Theodore Wolf, who graduated from Cornell University in 2013 with a bachelor's degree in humor (that's not a joke, it actually happened). Theodore won the Heermans-McCalmon Dramatic Writing Competition at Cornell for his short play, King's Gambit, which caught the attention of a talent manager in Los Angeles. Following graduation, Theodore moved to LA, where he pitched shows to networks and took an ungodly number of coffee meetings . After being asked to make a pilot "a little more 50 shades," he left California to return to his original love of playwriting. He is a proud member of the Dramatists Guild.

This production at Thespis Theater Festival marks the first staging of 100 Aker Wood, as well as the NYC debut of Pittsburgh-based director (and fellow Cornell grad), Spencer Whale. Spencer's recent directing credits range from a production of Titus Andronicus for the 25th Anniversary Season of the Cornell Mainstage, subculture: a part rave/part performance of Steve Yockey shorts, and Melancholy Play: Sarah Ruhl's comic love letter to depression. No stranger to adaptation, he developed a new, a cappella stage adaptation of Joss Whedon's cult hit, Dr. Horrible's Sing-Along Blog.


Other Ways You Can Help

We appreciate all of the help that we get, whether that's through donating to the campaign, spreading the word to your friends, liking us on facebook, following us on twitter, or simply coming to see the show on August 24th, 26th, or 29th!


Thanks for your support!

story:
Sometimes you stumble upon a play that bends your mind, breaks your heart and makes you laugh out loud. You put it down but it stays with you, always on the periphery, lurking behind every conversation, begging for a closer examination. And you realize that this is why you became a producer, so you could bring this kind of play into the world.  

We at To-By-For Productions believe in the power, importance and universality of female-driven storytelling, and we are thrilled to be producing the work of Dipika Guha, who is an important, genre-defying, and language-driven female voice. We are not alone in our excitement: Dipika topped the Kilroys list this year (http://thekilroys.org/list/) and Pulitzer Prize-winning dramatist Paula Vogel called Dipika an "incredible, nuanced playwright, someone who is smart, political, theatrical and deeply, fiercely emotional" (http://www.playbill.com/article/14-powerhouse-female-creatives-name-the-up-and-coming-women-in-theatre-they-are-watching). 

In Mechanics of Love, a man who forgets everything falls in love with a ballerina who forgets nothing. That is, until she falls in love with him. And his wife. And the mechanic. This rapidly moving, madcap comedy explores how we love, who we choose, and the cost of making sense of it all. 

This play has been workshopped at theaters all over New York City and has received a San Francisco premiere, but To-By-For has been granted the rights to give Mechanics of Love a fully-mounted NYC premiere this September and has enlisted the masterful talent of director Elena Araoz to lead our production.

The Ladies:

To-By-For, helmed by Victoria Frings and Anastasia Olowin, is a female-driven theatre and film production company dedicated to making work by women, for everyone. Our goal: to tell three-dimensional female stories through a non-male lens, to challenge the industry standard that art by and about women will only be consumed by women, and to produce each work in the medium that best suits the story. Since our inception last year, we have produced After Ever After, a web series that explores Disney's damaging romantic paradigms, Stitches, the world premiere of Leah Franqui's play about self-betterment and self-harm, and Marie Marie Marlene, an original cabaret act about celebrity branding and worship as told through the life and legend of Marlene Dietrich. And this fall we will team up again with Stitches director Elena Araoz to bring Dipika Guha's work to a New York stage.  

Mechanics of Love is our most ambitious project yet!

How You Can Help!

Our project is ambitious but not exorbitant, and our budget reflects that. We have already raised the majority of the funds needed for our production, but we need just a bit more to offset expenses before we see a return from ticket sales... and that's where you come in. 

  • $900.00: design budget/materials
  • $3,800.00: artist stipends
  • $5,000.00: space rental
  • $1,000.00: PR/marketing
Donations are tax-deductible, and your generosity is hugely important to the success of this production! You may notice that the numbers above add up to more than we are asking for with this campaign, so if we've made our initial goal and you would like to help us make our reach goal, we'd be forever grateful!

Why So Ambitious?

We were able to produce both Stitches and Marie Marie Marlene on a shoestring budget, and we learned that we are very good at producing with limited means. However, as our work grows in scope and reach, we would like the funds and budget to grow to match it. We are very grateful that Dipika's team has decided we are the right company to helm her NYC debut, and we want to give her the best premiere possible!

The world of this play is very specific - as Dipika describes it, it is "a mythical European city pressed up against a communist state" and we need to design and build the kind of set that will embrace that very free but constricted theatrical space. We have the Tony nominated and Drama Desk winning designer Justin Townsend designing our set, and we are focusing a lot of our budget and resources towards enabling him to create something extraordinary!


"Mechanics of Love" is a sponsored project of Fractured Atlas, a non-profit arts service organization. Contributions for the charitable purposed of "Mechanics of Love" must be made payable to Fractured Atlas only and are tax-deductible to the extent permitted by law.

story:
SLAMHAIN III: SKELETON CRUISE

Party World Rasslin' is a seasonal party and bizarre wrestling spectacle. At our last event, your support allowed us to bring our imaginations to life and create a Nickelodeon games-and-sports-themed battle arena. Under the glow of the GIANT POLYHEDRAL CRAGGROCRAG, amidst the chatter of a GIANT TALKING SKULL, 1700+ attendants yelled in one voice while a bird-man drop-kicked a neon villain in the face. 

We now prepare for our 9th party! Thanks to you—the MULTIVERSE—PWR has  become something far beyond what we ever could have imagined. It remains FREE TO ATTEND even as we mount mammoth costs. Here's what we want to do for our next show.

In our ongoing journey to make each of our parties bigger and more bonkers than the last, we've turned our eyes to the sea; we're going underwater. Halloween is the greatest of all party holidays. And so to celebrate, we're going to convert 4th Tap Brewery into a haunted, sunken paradise complete with skeleton pirates, gold, tentacles, barnacled jack-o-lanterns and weird fish! We invite you with us to take a SKELETON CRUISE! Treasure and horror await in equal measure those who venture into the briny deep!

In a wrestling ring at the bottom of the sea, Dan "the Man" Ziglar will stake the PARTYWEIGHT CHAMPIONSHIP BELT in a match with the mighty Dock Master! The anchors and harpoons will surely fly in this NO-HOLDS-BARRED fight to the finish! 

Meanwhile, HELLSPORT, inc, continues to tighten its stranglehold on PWR. Can we overthrow these corporate monsters, or will a new dark age swallow PWR? Can our heroes stem the dark tide of chaos? This story, and many others, will be told!

New chapters in the chronicles of Theodosia,  Chad Blitz, Pink Eye, Kippy (age 13), Chubby Uncle Juan and Puggin'Head, the Intergalactic Express, Pasta Man, Luigi Primo, Hot Dog, Dadbod, Baron Zahkey, the Night Mayor, and more all continue this October! And it's all aboard a mouldering, ghostly ship! 
 

What is this money used for?

$4600 is a lot of money! What’s it going toward?

First, an important recitation: PWR is free and we want to keep it free. PWR is for everyone, even if they can't afford to pay cover at a show. We'd like to keep from having to charge admission for as long as we can.

PWR is also now a 80-person organization putting on a show for 1700 people. One and a half thundo! Increased expectations beget increased (and wholly worthwhile) costs: we spent just north of $9000 to create WRESTLEVANIA and $11,000 on SLIP N SLAM.

Through diligent saving and prudent investment, we've managed to reduce the Indiegogo amount for SLAMHAIN by about $1000. That's a big thundo! And it's all on the backs of our beautiful volunteers who submit themselves to the Multiverse out of love. We've survived more than two years as we've grown into the massive wrestling party you know today—and we're not slowing down! Accept no impostors! HELL RIGHT.

But we still have to deal with the effects of the end of summer, and our newest seasonal expense: COOLING. While it won't be as hot as hot as our July show, we don't want to take any chances, and quality swamp cooler rentals cost $400 apiece. We want to have at least one in the venue so everyone has a comfortable, safe party experience. We’re also paying for the services and equipment of EMTs—now that we’re well over a thousand attendees strong, we want to make sure no catastrophe prevents Trve Kvlt Party Violence.

Some of the cool things your donations have let us do include:

  • Art and design. We have an extremely talented team of designers who transform the venue into an art piece by using garbage. 4th Tap was turned into a NEON NICKELODEON POWERZONE by their selfless capable hands. Though most of our resources are scavenged from trash bins and thrift stores, filling a venue of our size with cool decorations—and the storage to keep them preserved show after show!—costs money.

  • Safe space/security: PWR is a party for everyone. Our performers have always followed anti-sexist/homophobic/transphobic/racist guidelines, and we wanted to make sure that comfort extends to our audience. We’re proud of our security phone line. Any member of the audience may use this number to report gross behavior at the show, and we resolve the problem, no questions asked. Your support lets us keep reaching toward a goal of ULTIMATE PARTY VIOLENCE for everyone.

  • Paying artists. Capitalism is whatever, but we work hard to make sure everyone who contributes art gets some money in exchange—whether our art team, our powerful tech wizards, our video crew, or our performers.

  • Projection and lighting. Huge audiences compel us to try to use every part of our venue—so that all audience members can find a comfortable view of the show. We’ve found a ton of bargain-barrel prices on new lights, new projector equipment, and new mounts. SKELETON CRUISE will be our best-looking show yet.

For transparency: this Indiegogo doesn’t cover all of adolescent PWR’s expenses, but it takes care of a majority of them. Below is our complete budget.

Show Expenses: $1645
Misc: $50
Props: $200
Art: $650
Food: $100
Promo materials: $100
Security: $160
Insurance: $385
Printing: $200

Operational Expenses: $850
Ring Repairs: $150
Discretionary Show Expenses: $300
New Projects Capital: $400

Other Expenses: $3832
Artist pay: $2100
Indiegogo fees & fulfillment: $1732

Extremely Hype Swag

 
Whoa! Are you ready for this?

It's the Donor T-shirt Design, only available to you through the Indiegogo! Whoa! Brought to you by PWR artist Zug Goodina—it's spooky! Scary! And it appears on the Donor Shirt and Raglan tee. Whoa! {note: This is a rough draft of the image - the final version will be even more detailed and radical!}

 

Below, the die-cut pin! It looks even hyper in real life.

 

Here's the pillowcase! Professor Snooze will fireman's carry you quickly to the Dream Realm once your cheek presses against this bad boy!

What do we have here? Why, it's the Theodosia and Bench Horse Wrestlebuddies!

 

Risks & Challenges

 

Challenges:

PWR has become robust and its universe swole with powerful party drama. As it continues to grow wantonly like an uncontrollable teen (and our expectations for our performance climb) we approach a new realm of costs we could not have imagined before.  We are depending on the support of our Multiverse to keep our show free and open—thank you for your continued support.  Rest assured we are working night and day to make sure this event is the most fun thing you do all quarter.

 

Risks:

The only risk is the risk of not partying hard enough. We laugh at the concept of "risk." It is as outmoded as "shame," or "weakness." We have sworn to party 'til death, and we will do so.

Other Ways You Can Help

If you don't want to donate money you can help us by getting the word out about this campaign and/or just word out about PWR and SLAMHAIN III: SKELETON CRUISE!


Here is the Facebook event page:https://www.facebook.com/events/1669319156723934/

HMW
story_txt:
SLAMHAIN III: SKELETON CRUISEParty World Rasslin' is a seasonal party and bizarre wrestling spectacle. At our last event, your support allowed us to bring our imaginations to life and create a Nickelodeon games-and-sports-themed battle arena. Under the glow of the GIANT POLYHEDRAL CRAGGROCRAG, amidst the chatter of a GIANT TALKING SKULL, 1700+ attendants yelled in one voice while a bird-man drop-kicked a neon villain in the face. We now prepare for our 9th party! Thanks to you—the MULTIVERSE—PWR has  become something far beyond what we ever could have imagined. It remains FREE TO ATTEND even as we mount mammoth costs. Here's what we want to do for our next show.In our ongoing journey to make each of our parties bigger and more bonkers than the last, we've turned our eyes to the sea; we're going underwater. Halloween is the greatest of all party holidays. And so to celebrate, we're going to convert 4th Tap Brewery into a haunted, sunken paradise complete with skeleton pirates, gold, tentacles, barnacled jack-o-lanterns and weird fish! We invite you with us to take a SKELETON CRUISE! Treasure and horror await in equal measure those who venture into the briny deep!In a wrestling ring at the bottom of the sea, Dan "the Man" Ziglar will stake the PARTYWEIGHT CHAMPIONSHIP BELT in a match with the mighty Dock Master! The anchors and harpoons will surely fly in this NO-HOLDS-BARRED fight to the finish! Meanwhile, HELLSPORT, inc, continues to tighten its stranglehold on PWR. Can we overthrow these corporate monsters, or will a new dark age swallow PWR? Can our heroes stem the dark tide of chaos? This story, and many others, will be told!New chapters in the chronicles of Theodosia,  Chad Blitz, Pink Eye, Kippy (age 13), Chubby Uncle Juan and Puggin'Head, the Intergalactic Express, Pasta Man, Luigi Primo, Hot Dog, Dadbod, Baron Zahkey, the Night Mayor, and more all continue this October! And it's all aboard a mouldering, ghostly ship!  What is this money used for?$4600 is a lot of money! What’s it going toward?First, an important recitation: PWR is free and we want to keep it free. PWR is for everyone, even if they can't afford to pay cover at a show. story:
Who we are and what we do: 

We are Airplane Mode, a group of artists who want to temporarily disconnect you from your service and cut to the real shit. We are interested in deeply exploring the concepts underlying modern life, taking them, and turning them on their heads. The Center for Competitive Rationalization is the first phase of our inaugural collaboratively-devised performance exploring the concept of freedom, drawing from mythology, personal experience, political position papers, philosophy, current events, literature, film, and imagination. We hope to create an experience that brings you inside, underneath, through, and beyond the concept of freedom. In an hour.

What we're asking:
We are looking to raise $1,000 to help us realize the first phase of this ambitious project. Your generous donations will be used to:
  • support artist pay 
  • defray production costs - space rental, costumes, props
  • support cost of documenting performances so we can include footage and pictures in future grant proposals to continue the life of the piece 

What we give in return:

Our gratitude, some cool perks, and the beginning of an ongoing connection and relationship with the work we create.
If you donate and are unable to see the show, we will gladly send you a link to the filmed performance. Just email us!
Tickets to the performance will be entirely donation based!
Meet the Team:

Ryan Patrick (Collaborator):Originally based in Minneapolis, Ryan now lives in Brooklyn. He has a BFA in Acting. Many of his performances were created through HOMOHOTDISH, a Queer glam punk theatre group that was based in Minneapolis from 2013-2016. Along with Chase Burns and Jared Ziegler, HOMOHOTDISH created full length plays ( MICHAEL, MICHAEL, MICHAEL: A Gay Odyssey; I DO! I DO!; The Tucking of My Shrew); creative place-making projects and pop up performances. His work often incorporates classical theatre traditions, drag, and silly dances. 

Suzy Kohane (Producer/Collaborator):  Hailing from the great swing state of Ohio, Suzy is an actor, theater maker, and Shakespeare gender bending enthusiast. NY theater credits: The Acting Company -Macbeth, Hamlet, R&G are Dead, Connecticut Yankee in King Arthurs Court; Next In Line Productions - Exposure; Cloud City - Persona non grata;  Columbia Stages - The Cherry Orchard; Lunar Energy/Wandering Bark - Short Life of Trouble. Film/TV: none! She studied acting at the University of Minnesota/Guthrie BFA Actor Training program. 

Mitsu Hadeishi (Producer/Collaborator): Mitsu has been organizing and curating multi-media art/video/performance events in the Bronx and New York City since 2003, exhibiting experimental video, performance art, 2D and 3D visual art, net art, installations, music, and site-specific interactive work, and he’s also collaborated with artists on internet projects for many years prior to that. He has an undergraduate degree in Physics from Harvard University and has lived in the Bronx for over a decade.

Susanna Stahlmann (Collaborator): The Acting Company: Macbeth, A Connecticut Yankee in King Arthur’s Court; Guthrie: A Christmas Carol, In Game or Real; Hudson Valley Shakespeare Festival: Hamlet, Around the World in 80 Days; Hope Summer Repertory Theatre: Pride and Prejudice, An Inspector Calls; Film/TV: The Mask, Moonstruck, The Witches of Eastwick, MermaidsTraining B.F.A., University of Minnesota/Guthrie Theater Actor Training Program

story:
What's the play about?

This production of Rajiv Joseph’s Gruesome Playground Injuries is an exploration of Doug’s and Kayleen’s relationship, spanning over 30 years. Throughout the piece we witness them grow from the ages of eight to thirty-eight as they navigate love, pain, and loss. All the while, the pair numbs their pain through humor and search for hope and healing within each other.

What is being paid for?

COMPENSATION
We at Outlet Ensemble believe firmly in compensating artists for their ingenuity, time, and hard work. Often, artists are asked to work for free, or for "exposure", and while we are a new and humbly situated company, we feel strongly that artists provide a service and should be valued as best as they can be. As such, we are making sure our actors/creative team/crew receive stipends for their commitment. Your donations support this principle and help us pay our team.
THE SPACE
This production is going to take place in Theaterlab's gorgeous and evocative white box theatre. This enhances the storytelling in many ways -- it's clinical, sterile look contributes greatly to the fact that the play takes place in several medical settings; the all-white is striking and creates a powerful offset to the deliberate use of color onstage; the flexibility of the space enables us to place the audience where they can best absorb the story in an immersive way. Your donations help us produce in the best space for the show.
MARKETING
The most important thing in putting on a show is having people see it! Your donations will help us ensure that people know about Gruesome Playground Injuries.

Other Ways You Can Help

If you are unable to donate financially, we completely understand -- you can help us by SPREADING THE WORD! Share this fundraising link, tell your friends about our great show, and don't forget to BUY TICKETS!
http://www.theaterlabnyc.com/events/gruesome-pl...

story:
Short Summary

Since 2007, Chatterbox has been creating a podcast of full-cast audio theater. Working with more than 300 volunteers, we've created nearly 75 shows -- more than 48 hours of original audio.

Now we want to take it to the next level! We've set an ambitious goal of releasing one new show each month from October 2015 through September 2016. We've got an exciting, diverse list of stories to tell, including literary classics, myths, dramas, thrillers, original works, kids' shows, and more.

Twelve shows in 12 months means more Chatterbox releases more regularly than ever before. To accomplish it, we need your help!


What We Need & What You Get

Chatterbox is 100% volunteer-operated. But our podcast still has costs, such as rent on our dedicated studio space, hosting costs, and sound effects purchases.

Our total budget for 2015-16 is $16,000. We're hoping to raise 25% of that — just $4,000 — by December 6, 2015. Your help will allow us to plan out the year and focus on producing our shows!

In return, we're saying thanks with some fun Chatterbox items that you can't get anywhere else. See the full list of donor rewards at the right.

If we don't reach our goal, by the way, we'll use whatever funds we raise to get as far through our production schedule as possible!


The Impact

Chatterbox sparks the imaginations of listeners around the world with a free, full-cast podcast. We've heard from teachers who use Chatterbox in their classrooms, people in other countries using Chatterbox to help them learn English, and plenty of folks who just love tuning in to dramatized, full-cast productions during their downtime or their daily commute. 

Your contribution helps us keep Chatterbox shows available without charge to all of these listeners. And not just our new releases -- everything we've ever produced is freely available through our website and iTunes. We'd rather work on the giveaway model and trust that devoted fans like you will help us meet our costs. For eight years and almost 75 shows, it's been working!


Other Ways You Can Help

Maybe you love the podcast but can't contribute to Chatterbox right now. That's OK -- you can still help us out! Here are some other ways to show your support:

  • Tell your friends about this fundraising campaign! You can use the Share Tools on this page.
  • Subscribe to the Chatterbox podcast through iTunes or your favorite podcatcher.
  • Write us a glowing review on iTunes or Facebook.
  • Listen to and share some of our many great shows!

Thank you for your support!

story:
Help fund the October reading of "The Battles."

Hi Theatre Lovers!   

Ned Massey here, the author of the new musical, "The Battles." The show is so close to a pivotal step in its development, and I hope you can help us make that step a reality.

“The Battles” is about a painting competition that took place between Leonardo Da Vinci and Michelangelo in Florence, Italy around the year 1500. But more than that, it’s about how fear and bigotry can infect individuals and society. It’s about how terribly easy it is, sometimes, to shut out love. Both artists’ lives were shaped by the hatred directed toward homosexuals in the Renaissance, and the show explores how each of them—despite their visionary work—wrestled with shame and doubt in a way that may be all too familiar to contemporary audiences.

  I've been working on “The Battles” for the past 5 years, and it's finally ready to present to theatre professionals!

Musical theatre at even this level of presentation --a staged reading-- is very expensive, but I am incredibly fortunate to have much of the funding in place. We need just a little more to make it all happen. PLEASE help make this reading a reality by considering a contribution through this Indiegogo campaign! 

What We Need & What You Get

We need to raise a minimum of $3000 to help augment the $10,000 already in place for the reading. Our total budget is almost $14,000, which covers payment of 15 artists, and space, sound, casting, and insurance costs.

Also, there are lots of awesome perks available, including admission to this invite-only industry reading performed by top Broadway actors! Actors currently on-board (subject to change) included Nathan Lee Graham (The Wild Party, Priscilla, Queen of the Desert, Zoolander, Hitch), Joel Perez (Fun Home), and George Abud (The Visit). 

The Impact

Your contribution helps fund this incredibly necessary step towards production. The budget for most off-Broadway musicals is $1.5 million. The budget for most Broadway musicals is $10-15 million. The goal for our October reading will be to engage investors for a short-run production called an off-Broadway Lab that will, in turn, be the step that can help us gain the visibility and support to leap to off-Broadway and then Broadway!

Phew.

Risks & Challenges

Well, only 1 in 5 Broadway shows even make their money back. The odds are daunting. So, possible investors have to feel a motivation beyond possible monetary reward. They have to share in the creative team's passion and vision. And for that to happen, they have to experience it. This reading helps us toward that goal.

The hardest money to raise is the early money. So this reading is the bedrock from which all our subsequent efforts proceed. Please consider making a donation to help defray the costs of this reading.

Other Ways You Can Help

If contributing financially is not something you can do at this point, please consider other ways you can be a part of this effort:

•  Tell your friends about the campaign!

•  Like us on Facebook! https://www.facebook.com/thebattlesmusical

•  Use the Indiegogo share tools to let others know about our campaign!

Thank you SO much for all your support!

All the best

Ned Massey

Author of "The Battles"

Also, there are lots of awesome
perks available, including admission to this invite-only industry reading
performed by top Broadway actors! Actors currently on-board (subject to change) included Nathan Lee Graham (The Wild Party, Priscilla, Queen of the Desert, Zoolander, Hitch), Joel Perez (Fun Home), and George Abud (The Visit). 
The Impact
Your contribution helps fund this
incredibly necessary step towards production. The budget for most off-Broadway
musicals is $1.5 million. The budget for most Broadway musicals is $10-15
million. The goal for our October reading will be to engage investors for a
short-run production called an off-Broadway Lab that will, in turn, be the step
that can help us gain the visibility and support to leap to off-Broadway and
then Broadway!
Phew.
Risks & Challenges
Well, only 1 in 5 Broadway shows even
make their money back. The odds are daunting. So, possible investors have to
feel a motivation beyond possible monetary reward. They have to share in the
creative team's passion and vision. And for that to happen, they have to
experience it. This reading helps us toward that goal.
The hardest money to raise is the
early money. So this reading is the bedrock from which all our subsequent
efforts proceed. Please consider making a donation to help
defray the costs of this reading.
Other Ways You Can Help
If contributing financially is not
something you can do at this point, please consider other ways you can be a
part of this effort:
• 
Tell your friends about the campaign!
• 
Like us on Facebook! https://www.facebook.com/thebattlesmusical
• 
Use the Indiegogo share tools to let
others know about our campaign!
Thank you SO much for all your
support!
All the best
Ned Massey
Author of "The Battles"

story:
Summary

My name is Alex Cole, and I'm a dancer living and working in Denton, Texas. I have a huge amount of pride for the best small town in America, and want to create a space for dancers to create, rehearse, and perform, locally. Dance of all forms should be seen and enjoyed. With this venue, we can put Denton on the map for dancers and performers.

What We Need & What You Get

This fundraiser is for the startup expenses, which include anything and everything needed to open a professional, safe, and comfortable dance performance and rehearsal venue.
  • Startup Expenses: $25,000 for a brand new sprung dance floor, state-of-the-art sound equipment, and a lighting grid with stage lights for performances.
You get:
  • A handwritten letter of thanks for your donation of $10
  • A Lil' D PP Sticker for your donation of $25
  • CD of professional Dance Musician Westin Portillo's past works for a $50 donation
  • Lil' D PP T-shirt with a $100 donation
  • Handmade Crochet Afghan with $350 donation
  • You/your organization's name on an art piece for a donation of $1,000
  • Year-long pass to Lil D PP Performances for your $5,000 donation

Impact

Providing dancers with adequate space to perform and rehearse has long been a dream of mine. Students, professors, choreographers, performers, aspiring dancers, and professionals will all benefit from a professional rehearsal and performance space. With this space, choreographers can set pieces, improvisers can host jams, and teachers can lead a class, all for an affordable and accessible rate. Plus, the space will be locally owned and operated; a local will know how to better serve the Denton dance community.

Challenges

Our biggest challenge with opening up the Little D Performance Platform is simply raising the startup funds. That's where you (yes, you in the back) come in! Donate, share, and tell your friends. This dream can only become reality once our community gets involved. 

Other Ways You Can Help

Can't donate right now? No problem! Help us by sharing our campaign on Facebook, Twitter, Tumblr, Instagram, and any other social media site. 
Know of affordable warehouse space in Denton, Texas? Have space near the Square that needs a tenant? Let me know; Lil' D PP needs a home!

Photo Credit: Lauren Shafer with Eastfield College Dance Department

story:
Short Summary

My name is Wendell Tucker, I am the writer and performer of "Wendell Tucker Hates the World". WTHTW is my story of discovering that I have been living with Major Depressive Disorder, how it affected my life, and how I began to take steps to overcome it. I wrote this show with these thoughts in mind:

  • To let others know that they are not alone, and that the help they need is available.
  • To encourage people to be aware of the symptoms of depression in their loved ones.
  • To increase awareness of the need for proper mental health care in urban areas and particularly with Black Men.
I have been selected to perform at the Atlanta Black Theatre Festival this year, and need your help bringing this message to a city with one of the highest African American populations in the country!


What We Need

I am honored to be able to bring this work to Atlanta, however the cost of producing and touring can be prohibitive. In addition to investing my personal funds and  seeking traditional funding, I am attempting to raise $3,000 to help make this a success. In a little less than 6 months, I am tasked with building an audience in a new city, creating a new stage experience fitting of the occasion, and possibly shooting a special performance for submission to two popular streaming platforms.
Your Donation Will Help Cover
  • Our Festival Performance Cost
  • Travel Expenses
  • Marketing Cost
  • Printing of our Playbills and Major Depressive Disorder Info Brochure
  • Videography and Post Production Expenses

The Impact

My hope for this project is simple: I hope to reach someone who may be contemplating suicide and give them hope to push through. To help one person take that critical first step to taking control of their life back from this sickness, that sometimes still incapacities me. 

  • Clinical Depression is a biological condition that affects every aspect of a person's life including, but not limited to: mood, productivity, inter-personal relationships, libido, weight, and finances. 
  • Surgeon General studies estimate over 19 Million Americans living with Depression. African Americans compose a large amount of these cases, but are among the least diagnosed and treated. 
  • The rate of suicide among African American Children has doubled over the past 20 years. 
In short: BLACK MENTAL HEALTH MATTERS

Other Ways You Can Help

Some people just can't contribute, but that doesn't mean you can't help:

  • Share, Retweet, and Blog about this campaign. 
  • Connect us with media, marketing, and sponsor contacts at theorifinearts@gmail.com
  • Help us get the show up! Buddy passes, lighting or sound equipment, Printing... However you can help!
But most importantly...

Check on your loved ones. If you see them showing the signs of depression, talk to them about getting help. If they are suicidal, get them to an emergency facility. Silence kills.  

For more information on Suicide Prevention and Major Depressive Disorder please visit the American Foundation for Suicide Prevention.

story:
I’m thrilled to tell you about the world premiere of H5x7, my new adaptation of Shakespeare’s Henry V to be performed by seven actors. Get it? H5x7? This will be the second production of Barabbas Theatre, a company I founded last year for the highly successful world premiere of Alexandra Petri’s Never Never. If you didn’t see it, click the link and read our outstanding reviews.

In keeping with our core belief that great theatre can come in many forms, we’re pivoting from contemporary tragicomedy to Shakespearean history this year. With H5x7, we take our cue from the Chorus of Henry V, who urges the audience to use its imagination to aid the players in portraying the momentous events of King Harry’s campaign for the French crown during the Hundred Years’ War. In that spirit, seven actors–four men and three women–will play 30 roles, aided by the simplest of sets, props, and costumes. The siege at Harfleur, the antics of the Eastcheap crew, the glorious and terrible Battle of Agincourt, and Harry’s wooing of France’s Princess Katharine will all be brought to life through the skill of the ensemble cast and your willingness to “eke out our performance with your mind.”

Barabbas Theatre has set itself a high bar for artistic excellence. To live up to that standard we need your help. Our expenses for H5x7 will come to about $3,500. About 35% of that goes to paying the artists involved in bringing the play to life. About 28% is taken up by fees paid to Capital Fringe—they provide the venue, technical equipment, box office, some marketing, and insurance. Another 26% will go toward getting people in the seats. The remaining 11% is what we have left for the set, props, and costumes.

We’re trying to raise $2,500 to help meet these expenses and are asking you to consider making a donation to our company. 

I know you receive many requests for money for many worthy causes. But I’m asking you to recognize the intrinsic value of great theatre by supporting the world premiere of H5x7. Barabbas Theatre puts artistic merit above all else. We began proving that with Never Never, and we aim to enhance our reputation with H5x7. I hope you agree that this mission is worthy of your support.

Whether you can donate or not, I hope you can make it to the play! Tickets are on sale here: www.capitalfringe.org/events/892-h5x7!

Barabbas Theatre is a sponsored project of Fractured Atlas, a non­profit arts service organization. Contributions for the charitable purposes of Barabbas Theatre must be made payable to “Fractured Atlas” only. Any contribution above the value of the goods and services received by the donor is tax-deductible to the extent permitted by law.

story:
Short Summary

My name is Janet Aisawa.  I created, directed and perform in "Them",  a multimedia piece that will be shown at Green Space in Long Island City, NY, this coming April 15th and 16th in their “Take Root” series. 

"Them" has been a life time in the making, and comes from interviews that I started doing in 2005 of my aunts, uncles, and their friends. These Japanese Americans were forced from their homes and placed in internment camps in the United States during WWII.   This project is important to me because I not only want to pass down these stories but I also hope it will start conversations and questions about what it means to be “Them” and “Us”  and is a reminder that  we have all once been labeled "Them". 

A portion of the video “Shadows of Hiroshima” by Yuko Takebe, which we filmed in Hiroshima and Matsuyama, Japan last fall, will also be included in “Them”.  This video shows the past as always being present and asks the question, “How do we live in the world today post-Atomic bomb? 

Thank you for all the support you have given me in the past. I couldn’t have done it without you.  Now I am asking for the  biggest contribution ever to realize this piece.  I feel that I was told these stories to become part of our collective history.  With your help I can finally pass them on.  Thank you again!

What We Need & What You Get

WHERE YOUR MONEY IS GOING

Your contribution will help pay the amazing performers that are working on this piece with me - Osamu Uehara, Sumi Matsumoto, and Mel Khaw.  We started rehearsing in the fall of 2015 and a $20 contribution will help pay for one hour of rehearsal rental.

We are hoping to show the full length version of "Shadows of Hiroshima" in film festivals throughout the world.  Part of your contribution will pay for post-production editing, color corrections, and sound editing of the entire video.   

The Impact

Your contribution will help to create a continued awareness of the ongoing prejudices that continue to repress us today.

Risks & Challenges

The challenge is to get as many people to see"Them" and "Shadows of Hiroshima" outside my wonderful and supportive circle of friends who will help to spread the word.

Other Ways You Can Help

If you can't contribute, that doesn't mean you can't help:

Please help by sharing this campaign with others through Facebook, Twitter, or your email contacts.  And please come to the show!

story:
Short Summary

EgyptAir Flight 990 plunged into the Atlantic Ocean off the coast of Nantucket on October 30th 1999, killing all 217 people aboard.  Almost immediately, rumors began swirling that the Relief First Officer, Gamil el Batouty had crashed the plane intentionally.  Egyptian officials, outraged at the suggestion that one of their employees would do such a thing, insisted that Flight 990 crashed as a result of a mechanical failure.  What ensued was a politically-charged, years long investigation, the results of which are still disputed to this day, and that threatened to rip relations between Egypt and the United States apart.  

My two-act play, "Son of a Dog" focuses on the FBI and National Transportation Safety Board's interview/interrogation of EgyptAir Captain Mohammed el Badrawi, Gamil Batouty's closest friend, and the play explores the cultural complications, prejudices, paranoia, and agendas that were at play during the course of the investigation.  "Son of a Dog" was written entirely using source material from the cockpit voice recorders on EgyptAir 990, transcripts from FBI documents, news reports, and, of course, the interview with Captain el Badrawi.

"Son of a Dog" has gone through multiple revisions and benefited from a staged reading at The Drilling Company in New York City in 2014.  Now is the time for this play to receive a professional production in Philadelphia, and we need your support to make that a reality.  We have a polished script, a director, a performance space, and now all we need is... you!    

What We Need & What You Get

In order to fully produce "Son of a Dog," we need to raise $6,500.  These funds will be utilized to compensate the cast of 5 actors, our director, stage manager, lighting, sound, and costume designers, and will also pay for the rental of Studio 5 at the Walnut Street Theatre, as well as pay for marketing, sets, props, and costumes.

The Impact

"Son of a Dog" is not just about a plane crash and the ensuing investigation.  It is an emotionally-charged play that explores the delicate nature of sensitive, international relations, the complexities of language, ethnocentrism and xenophobia.  The play examines our prejudices and preconceived notions and, like any good work of theatre, what it means to be human and fallible.

story:
What's the project?

JOAN is a new play written by Theatre SKAM's artistic producer Matthew Payne about his best friendship with local arts maven Joan Mans. The show has been in development for some time, and thanks to the Victoria Foundation, will soon be ready for a full preview in April 2014.

The preview runs at the Metro Studio Theatre (1411 Quadra Street), April 18 & 19 at 8 PM and April 20 at 2 PM.


“A celebrated — and slightly notorious — figure in this city’s close-knit cultural scene.”
– Adrian Chamberlain, Times Colonist, Victoria

For over thirty years, Joan Mans attended arts happenings in the capital, sometimes from morning until night, finishing her evening most nights at Swan’s Pub dancing to live music.

She developed quite an eye for great theatre and an ear for excellent music. In 1997, enthralled with our outdoor back-alley production of Zastrozzi, she made a donation to SKAM to pay for the 50 army blankets we'd provided for the audience. These same army blankets are still used at SKAM shows today.

The play has gone through a lengthy development process, as SKAM worked closely with Oak Bay Lodge, The Belfry Theatre, and The Banff Centre; Canada’s Creative Leader in Arts and Culture. A reading at the Belfry Theatre in March of 2012 was successful and built buzz for the show's eventual debut.

In its current form, Joan is a biography of Joan from the outside, with Matthew-Payne-as-himself attempting to discover the hidden details of her life. Projections, recordings and re-enactments examine the truth of Joan Mans and question the reliability of memory. Jan Wood and Lynda Raino play twinned representations of Joan – but sometimes Matthew is Joan and Jan and Lynda are Matthew’s college buddies. At one point they all wear goldfish heads. (Hey, it wouldn’t be a SKAM show without a few fun surprises.)

Who are we?

Theatre SKAM is Victoria's leading alternative theatre company. For nearly 20 years, SKAM has created varied and provocative theatrical entertainment -- at home and abroad -- that is innovative, entertaining, and above all... never boring.

In 2013, we presented a solo show about fatherhood. We created a new venue for Victoria artists. We staged the world premiere of a musical on the back of our new Mobile Performance Venue:

We hosted the 5th incarnation of our annual theatre festival Bike Ride, where the audience rides bikes to over a dozen short, multi-disciplinary performances from local and national companies:

We gave kids from six local elementary schools the chance to turn a gallery audience's outfits into entirely new, wearable art:


And we doubled our annual operating budget.

Theatre SKAM is mandated to create a living, contemporary, professional theatre, and to employ emerging theatre artists while we do it. You can check out more information about our past and future projects at SKAM.ca.

Who are you?

You are a fan of theatre. You take pride in supporting the arts and emerging artists within Canada. You are excited about this project and either hope to see it in Victoria during its preview run, or want to help build up a strong preview that will heighten the prospects of a future touring run that will bring the show to you in years to come. May we just say, you are also very handsome.

What will happen?

Theatre SKAM has a proven track record for ambitious, intimate, and unique projects like this one.

“Theatre as it should be. Current, confrontational and provocative.”

– Victoria News Group

“Whatever Theatre SKAM touches seems to turn to theatrical gold.”

– Jon Kaplan, NOW Magazine

Adding to a significant contribution made by the Victoria Foundation, your investment will go towards paying the actors, production team, designers, venue hosts, and administrative staff necessary to make this project possible.

JOAN features an extensively integrated multimedia component, with video clips and photographs of Joan Mans and her fascinating life projected across the stage in a surprising and clever variety of ways. Your contribution will help support the purchase and installation of the equipment necessary for this ambitious undertaking, and allow Theatre SKAM to enhance its shows with exciting multimedia for years to come.

Throughout the process, we'll keep our funders -- that's you -- in the loop about the production process, with behind-the-scenes text and video updates as we prepare for the show's premiere.  And all IndieGoGo contributors will be thanked personally on our website and on display at the performance venue.

How else can I help?

We'd appreciate it if you would Like and Share our page on Facebook, follow us on Twitter, and most importantly, tell your friends! Even if you can't contribute to this IndieGoGo campaign -- or can only contribute a little -- it would be a tremendous help for you to bring people to the project page who want to support innovative, entertaining, and unique Canadian theatre. Plus, have we mentioned just how handsome you look today?

Thank you for your interest, your time, and your generosity.

--Theatre SKAM

and Lynda Raino play twinned representations of Joan – but
sometimes Matthew is Joan and Jan and Lynda are
Matthew’s college buddies. At one point they all wear goldfish
heads. (Hey, it wouldn’t be a SKAM show without a few fun
surprises.)
Who are we?Theatre SKAM is Victoria's leading alternative theatre company. For nearly 20 years, SKAM has created varied and provocative theatrical entertainment -- at home and abroad -- that is innovative, entertaining, and above all... never boring.In 2013, we presented a solo show about fatherhood. We created a new venue for Victoria artists. We staged the world premiere of a musical on the back of our new Mobile Performance Venue:We hosted the 5th incarnation of our annual theatre festival Bike Ride, where the audience rides bikes to over a dozen short, multi-disciplinary performances from local and national companies:We gave kids from six local elementary schools the chance to turn a gallery audience's outfits into entirely new, wearable art:And we doubled our annual operating budget.Theatre SKAM is mandated to create a living, contemporary, professional theatre, and to employ emerging theatre artists while we do it. You can check out more information about our past and future projects at SKAM.ca.Who are you?You are a fan of theatre. You take pride in supporting the arts and emerging artists within Canada. You are excited about this project and either hope to see it in Victoria during its preview run, or want to help build up a strong preview that will heighten the prospects of a future touring run that will bring the show to you in years to come. May we just say, you are also very handsome.What will happen?Theatre SKAM has a proven track record for ambitious, intimate, and unique projects like this one.“Theatre as it should be. Current, confrontational and provocative.”– Victoria News Group“Whatever Theatre SKAM touches seems to turn to theatrical gold.”– Jon Kaplan, NOW MagazineAdding to a significant contribution made by the Victoria Foundation, your investment will go towards paying the actors, production team, designers, venue hosts, and administrative staff necessary to make this project possible.JOAN features an extensively integrated multimedia component, with video clips and photographs of Joan Mans and her fascinating life projected across the stage in a surprising and clever variety of ways. Your contribution will help support the purchase and installation of the equipment necessary for this ambitious undertaking, and allow Theatre SKAM to enhance its shows with exciting multimedia for years to come.Throughout the process, we'll keep our funders -- that's you -- in the loop about the production process, with behind-the-scenes text and video updates as we prepare for the show's premiere.  And all IndieGoGo contributors will be thanked personally on our website and on display at the performance venue.How else can I help?We'd appreciate it if you would Like and Share our page on Facebook, follow us on Twitter, and most importantly, tell your friends! Even if you can't contribute to this IndieGoGo campaign -- or can only contribute a little -- it would be a tremendous help for you to bring people to the project page who want to support innovative, entertaining, and unique Canadian theatre. Plus, have we mentioned just how handsome you look today?Thank you for your interest, your time, and your generosity.--Theatre SKAM

story:
Short Summary

Neoteny Theatre, led by Artistic Producer Carly Chamberlain, is undertaking its first production: a double bill of Overruled by George Bernard Shaw and Romance by Neil Labute at Red Sandcastle Theatre, March 27-30 & April 3-6, 2013.

This unlikely pairing of two rarely-produced shorts promises to be a funny, unusual and exciting theatre event, featuring the performance prowess of Amos Crawley, Kelly Penner, Caitlin Stewart and Meghan Swaby. Romance, which was written with the intention of any gender playing any role, will also include four different variations on casting.

What We Need & What You Get

The gist is this: our current funding comes from Carly's credit card. These amazingly talented professional actors are working as a co-op and profit-sharing in lieu of rehearsal and performance fees. The $2,000 we're looking to raise will help to cover the following costs:

  • Rehearsal space
  • Venue space
  • Publicity (posters and programs)
  • Set & Costumes

Donations over $50 include a complimentary ticket to the performance date of your choosing!

The Impact

Beyond helping this project get on its feet, your contribution has a larger impact. We are determined to keep our ticket prices low and accessible. If you have the means to donate you are not only supporting our artists but also creating access to theatre for those in our community who would not otherwise have the means. 

Other Ways You Can Help

Come to the show! Come four times to see the different versions of Romance!
