Il s'agira d'un réel travail de création de la part des acteurs/actrices. C'est dans ce sens qu'il s'agira d'une création quelque part collective. Je ne prendrai aucunement la position du savoir supposé. Je ne saurai pas, pas plus que n'importe qui d'autre. Je voudrais qu'on ouvre un espace d'insécurité, de doute, de non-savoir sans que je sois obligé de jouer le rôle de celui qui sait. En d'autres mots, j'aimerais arriver à une existence de travail théâtral sans maître, que nous pensions, agissions et créions par nous-mêmes.
Pour ce qui est de l'esthétique que j'aimerais rechercher, je considère que le naturalisme demeure l'ennemi absolu. Cherchons l'abstraction au théâtre. Cherchons la défiguration. Mais allons y avec puissance. Allons au delà de nous-mêmes. Les acteurs devront se plonger corps et âme dans cette espace incertain, au risque de leur santé mental, se promenant sur la limite de la folie. Chaque proposition de jeu doit être sans retenue, au risque de tout, sans compromis; et ce serait là dedans qu'on trouvera un plaisir et une réelle puissance.
N'ayons pas peur du pathos humain. D'un pathos non-pathétique.
Un mot sur moi : né en Allemagne, j'ai vécu cinq ans à Montréal (Québec), Canada. J'y ai commencé à étudier la psychologie et j'ai terminé ma licence 3 en France. Durant cette année, j'ai découvert le théâtre et rien de moins que le sens de ma vie. Depuis-lors, tous mes choix sont dirigés vers le théâtre et une possibilité de créer librement. Je suis entré au théâtre en jouant, mais j'ai touché rapidement à la mise en scène. L'année dernière, j'ai mis en scène Le songe ou un jeu de rêve d'August Strindberg intercallé avec des textes de Dostoïevski, Rilke, Lautréamont, Baudelaire et autres. Ce travail préfigurait alors ce présent projet en tant qu'il s'agissait d'une mise en place d'un vaste chantier théâtral: http://theatre-vitez.com/2012/05/festival-3-jours-et-plus-4/
En contribuant à ce projet, vous aidez des jeunes créateurs à pouvoir travailler et donc à réaliser leur nécessité; et dans ce cas, à défendre un théâtre libre, un théâtre qui croit qu'il est crucial, qu'il est absolument nécessaire dans notre société, un théâtre qui est profondément politique même en ne l'étant pas explicitement, qui est une variation autour de l'étendard standard (en parlant encore une fois avec des termes deleuzien).
Même si cela n'a pas un prix exorbitant, cela coûte quelque chose. Voici un budget prévisionnel :







Dépenses


 





Costumes


150,00 €




Accessoires


150,00 €




Maquillage


30,00 €




Transports


100,00 €




Résidences, loyer pour 40 jours


1000,00 €




Impressions


50,00 €





TOTAL


1480,00 €


Comme vous pouvez le voir, le plus grand montant va au loyer d'une scène où nous pouvons répéter. Nous sommes, bien entendu, aussi à la recherche des locaux qui pourraient nous être prêtés gratuitement, mais la plupart du temps, il s'agit de locaux associatifs et alternatifs qui soit demandent, eux aussi, dû à leur situation, une participation financière, soit offre une possibilité de répéter un temps court une fois par semaine par exemple. Je considère que ce ne sont pas des conditions possibles pour le travail que nous voulons délivrer, car ceci demande d'exclure des éléments théâtraux comme la lumière, le son ou la scénographie du processus de création. Le reste dans le budget montre que nous faisons du réel théâtre pauvre (Grotowski). Si jamais il devrait y avoir un surplus d'argent, celui-ci ira directement dans la création de la seconde partie du diptyque Esquisse # 2 : une ode, laquelle sera créé l'année prochaine avec une plus grande équipe. 
Que recevez-vous pour votre contribution? (Normalement, la première question dans notre système capitaliste.) En fait, il n'est pas facile d'y répondre lorsque notre produit final est du théâtre considérant qu'il s'agit d'un art techniquement non reproductible (ce qui fait, d'ailleurs, sa beauté, sa cruauté, sa force et son unicité). Bien sûr vous recevrez une invitation à une représentation si vous êtes dans le coin. Sinon, nous vous enverrons au moins une carte postale. Si vous donnez un peu plus, nous écrivons sur vous. Oui! Il ne s'agit pas d'une récompense matérialiste, mais plutôt mentale, spirituelle. Une équipe de jeunes hommes et femmes écrivent sur vous, peut-être à l'autre bout du monde, s'ils vous connaissent ou non. Si vous donnez encore un peu plus, nous vous enverrons une lettre avec ces écrits.
Si jamais vous ne pouvez donner de l'argent, mais que vous appréciez le projet que nous proposons, vous pouvez partager l'information avec vos ami(e)s et votre famille et faire passer le mot.
Si vous avez quelconques questions, nous serions heureux de vous répondre. N'hésitez surtout pas. Nous essayerons de tenir ce site à jour et y mettre un vidéo des prochaines répétitions. Les photos que vous voyez viennent de nos premiers trois jours de travail.
Merci beaucoup de votre intérêt,
M.S.
 
Matériaux et Références voir en bas.
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Wenn ich etwas sagen kann, dann dass ich nichts sagen kann und nichts sagen will. Ich habe keine Nachricht. Ich bin weder Politiker, noch Priester, noch ein Publizist oder Werbedienst. Ich will das Theater von allen seinen Missionen befreien, und es an und für sich gelten lassen. Alles was ich habe sind Bilder, Wahrnehmungen, Texte, die mich bewegen, Musik, die mich erschüttert, Erfahrungen... Damit gehen wir auf die Bühne und konfrontieren sie mit dem notwendigen Kriterium des Theaters: Raum. Ich habe und will nicht mehr als diese Elemente, da ich den semantische Raum frei halten möchte, um aus der Konfrontation der genannten Materialien mit dem physischen Raum vollkommen unerhoffte semantische Zusammenhänge entstehen lassen zu können. Meine Absicht ist nicht beabsichtig, vorsätzlich oder absichtlich. Wenn das Theater endlich autonom werden will, sollte es auch autonom arbeiten, ohne dem Text, der Aussage, oder sonst irgendetwas Zweitrangigem etwas zu schulden. Nichts ist von vornherein gegeben, alles ist zu konstruieren! Das Resultat, könnte man mit Deleuze sagen, sind Perzepte.
Es handelt sich um eine wahrhaftige theatrale Forschungsarbeit. Diese Materialien frei, ohne a-priori, offen mit der Bühne zu konfrontieren erfordert von den Schauspielern Großzügigkeit, Geduld und Stärke in ihren künstlerischen Vorschlägen. Die Schauspieler müssen somit eine wahrhaftig kreative Arbeit leisten. Aus diesem Grund ist dieses Projekt in gewissen Maßen ein kollektives Schaffen. Ich werde keinesfalls die Position des vermuteten Wissenden einnehmen. Ich werde nicht wissen, nicht mehr und nicht weniger als jeder andere auch. Ich möchte einen Raum der Unsicherheit, des Zweifels, des Nicht-Wissens öffnen, ohne dass ich die Rolle desjenigen übernehme, der weiß. In anderen Worten, ich möchte zu einer theatralen Arbeit ohne Vorbild, Meister oder Führer gelangen, in der wir selbst und eigenständig denken, agieren und schaffen.
Die Ästhetik betreffend denke ich, dass der Naturalismus immer noch unser größter Feind ist und dies auch bleibt. Lasst uns nach Abstraktion im Theater forschen! Nach Entstellung! Nach Verwandlung! Aber lasst uns in die Arbeit mit Macht und Stärke gehen. Lasst uns über uns selbst hinaus gehen. Die Schauspieler werden sich mit Kopf und Seele in diesen unsicheren Raum werfen müssen, ihrer “Geistesgesundheit”wagend, auf der Grenze des Wahnsinns wandelnd. Jeder Vorschlag, jeder Akt auf der Bühne muss sich ohne Grenzen, ohne Kompromisse vollziehen, in der Gefahr vor allem; und nur dort werden wir die Kraft und die Macht, die wir suchen, finden können.
Ich habe keine Angst vor dem menschlichen Pathos. Einem nicht-pathetischen Pathos.
Ein kurzes Wort über mich: In Deutschland geboren, emigrierte ich für fünf Jahre nach Montreal, Kanada, wo ich anfing Psychologie zu studieren. Ich schloss meinen Bachelor in Frankreich ab. In diesem Jahr entdeckte ich das Theater und nichts weniger als den Sinn meines Lebens. Seit dem sind alle meine Entscheidungen auf das Theater und die Möglichkeit, irgendwie frei schaffen zu können, ausgerichtet. Ich bin als Schauspieler ins Theater gedrungen, aber arbeitete schnell in der Rolle des Regisseurs. Letztes Jahr inszenierte ich „Le songe ou un jeu de rêve“ („EinTraumspiel“) von August Strindberg, durchbrochen von Texten unterschiedlicher Autoren wie Dostojewski, Rilke, Lautréamont, Baudelaire u.a. Diese Arbeit erwies sich in dem Sinne als Präfiguration des jetzigen Projekts, als dass sich dort die Konzeption des Theaters als einer großen theatralen Baustelle herausgestellte hatte. (http://theatre-vitez.com/2012/05/festival-3-jours-et-plus-4/)Indem sie dieses Projekt unterstützen, helfen Sie jungen Schaffenden daran zu arbeiten, das ihnen unbedingt Notwendige realisieren zu können, und in diesem konkreten Fall verteidigen sie ein freies Theater, ein Theater, das glaubt, dass es in unserer heutigen Gesellschaft absolut notwendig ist, ein Theater, das, wenn auch nicht explizit politisch, absolut politisch ist : Eine Variation des Standartmaßes (um noch einmal mit Deleuzes Worten zu sprechen).
Dies kostet, wenn auch nicht allzu viel, eine gewisse Summe. Hier ist ein Kostenvoranschlag:








Ausgaben


 




Kostüme


150,00 €




Accessoires


150,00 €




Maske


30,00 €




Transport


100,00 €




Probebühne, Miete für 40 Tage


1000,00 €




Druckkosten


50,00 €




TOTAL


1480,00 €



Wie sie sehen können, fliesst das grösste Budget in die Miete einer Probebühne. Wir versuchen selbstverständlich auch Räume zu finden, die uns umsonst geliehen werden, doch meistens handelt es sich um Vereine, die auch knapp bei Kasse sind, oder um Räume, die wir nur für eine kurze Zeit einmal wöchentlich haben könnten. Unter diesen Bedingungen halte ich jedoch die Arbeit, die wir leisten wollen, für unmöglich. Es würde bedeuten, sämtliche theatrale Elemente wie Licht, Ton und Bühnenbild aus dem kreativen Prozess aus logistischen Gründen ausschließen zu müssen. Anhand der übrigen Kosten können Sie bemerken, dass wir ansonsten armes Theater(Grotowski) machen. Falls ein Teil des Geldes übrig bleiben sollte, wird es direkt in die Produktion des zweiten Teils des Dyptichons, Esquisse # 2: une ode, fließen. Esquisse # 2 werden wir nächstes Jahr mit einem größeren Team in Angriff nehmen.
Und was erhalten Sie für ihren finanziellen Beitrag? (Normalerweise immer die erste Frage in unserem kapitalistischen System.) Diese Frage ist gar nicht leicht zu beantworten, wenn unser „Endprodukt“ Theater, d.h. eine technisch nicht-reproduzierbare Kunstform, ist. Natürlich werden Sie eine Einladung zu einer Vorführung und freien Eintritt erhalten. Wenn Sie aber nicht in der Gegend sind, werden Sie zumindest eine Postkarte bekommen. Falls Sie ein wenig mehr geben können, werden wir über Sie schreiben. Es ist keine materielle Belohnung, aber eine geistige. Ein Team junger Männer und Frauen wird über Sie, ob bekannt oder nicht, vielleicht am anderen Ende der Welt, schreiben. Wenn Sie uns noch ein bisschen mehr unterstützen, werden wir Ihnen einen handschriftlichen Brief mit den verschiedenen Texten über Sie schicken.
Falls Sie uns nicht finanziell unterstützen können, aber unser Projekt trotzdem interessant finden, können sie diese Informationen gerne mit ihren Freundinnen und Freunden und ihrer Familie teilen.
Falls Sie irgendwelche Fragen haben sollten, zögern Sie nicht. Wir freuen uns Ihnen zu antworten. Wir werden versuchen, Sie über diese Seite auf dem Laufenden zu halten und ein Video unserer nächsten Probe hochzuladen. Die Photos, die schon zu sehen sind, stammen von unseren ersten drei Tagen Arbeit.Besten Dank für ihr Interesse,M.S.
 
 
-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Matériaux et Références :
 
Bibliographie :
Heinrich Böll, Ansichten eines Clowns (La grimace)
Gilles Deleuze, Abécédaire
Fjodor Dostoïevski, Aufzeichnungen aus dem Kellerloch (Carnets du sous-sol) 
Michel Foucault, Le Corps utopique, Les hétérotopies
Gombrowitcz, La pornographie
Klaus Kinski, Ich bin so wild dach deinem Erdbeermund
Fernando Pessoa, Le livre de l'Intranquillité 
Marcel Proust, À la recherche du temps perdu
Reiner Maria Rilke, Le livre des images, Les cahiers de Malte Laurids Brigge, Duineser Elegien, Neue Gedichte, Le Livre d'heures, Die Weise von Liebe und Tod des Cornets Christoph Rilke, Lettres à un jeune poète 
 
Musique :
Antonio Caldara, Maddalena ai piedi di Cristo, interprête : M.-C. Kiehr 
Léo Ferré, Ne chantez pas la mort
Monteverdi, Lamento de la nimpha
Arvo Pärt
Bach – Cantata - BWV 44
 
Beaux Arts :
Francis Bacon
 
Cinéma : 
David Lynch, Eraserhead
Sokurov, Mère et fils, Le soleil
Andrej Tarkowski
Werner Herzog
The Quay Brothers
 
Théâtre :
Théâtre du Radeau
Miguel Moreira & Romeu Runa, The Old King 
Claude Régy

story:
My Story

Hello, my name is Courtney Robertson and I am currently studying a BA Honours Degree in Contemporary Dance Performance at The Scottish School of Contemporary Dance.

In October I travelled to Groningen, The Netherlands where I performed in The Grand Theatre as part of ‘Super Special Questions’ a collaborative project. Following great success in The Netherlands I have been offered to complete the last four months of my training as an apprentice with professional dance company named Club Guy & Roni who are based in Groningen.

The Impact

This is an exceptionally unique opportunity for me to expand my dance experience in a professional environment and further my studies abroad. I am extremely keen to explore dance further afield and in the near future return to Scotland bringing back what I have learned. I feel this is an important step between graduating and entering the professional dance industry and know this would be an extremely valuable experience for me.

What I Need

Through funding I hope that my travel and living expenses will be covered helping me for fill this unique offer to the fullest. Between flights to and from the Netherlands, standard living expenses and extra dance classes/workshops I am asking for £1000 to enable me to achieve my goals.

What You Get In Return

If you are also passionate about dance and the integration between different cultures and dance communities your contribution will be highly valued and appreciated. You will have contributed to my oppertunity to gain many exceptional skills and experiences which will enable me to give back to the dance community in Scotland and grow and expand as a professional artist.

Thankyou for your time!

Courtney

You will have contributed to my oppertunity to gain many exceptional skills and experiences which will enable me to give back to the dance community in Scotland and grow and expand as a professional artist.
Thankyou for your time!
Courtney

story:
Our Story

Hello! We are Off Off Broadzway! We were voted Runner's Up for Best Sketch Comedy Group in Chicago by the Chicago Reader's Poll. Chicago loves us, don't get us wrong. They treat us right. Sold out shows every year at the Chicago Sketch Comedy Festival, great reviews from the Chicago Tribune, Time Out Chicago, Metromix, etc... But you know who's begging for us? New Orleans! So we're headed back there this March! We are so excited to see friends we made last year and make new ones! Plus we heard Brad Pitt is going to be in town that weekend, so he'll probably want to hang out.


The Impact

We love being in this group. We love performing for you. We love that you bring your friends and co-workers and you help us spread the word. We do SO many shows and still want to do more. And honestly guys, we put every last cent we make back into this group. And every year our costumes get more awesome, our props more ridiculous, our possibilities grow because of YOU and your support.


What We Need & What You Get

So this is the deal. We want to bring this show to as many people as possible. We went to New Orleans last year and it was a perfect fit. We are booking shows there again in March and we know from last year that it isn't going to be cheap. Round-trip airfare for the 6 of us, hotel, transportation and not to mention the rent for the Theater. That about covers it.


Here's what you get...We are now produced by Cowardly Scarecrow Theater Co, a 501(c)(3) non for profit, so any donation you make can be written off on your taxes. We also have rewards for different levels of donating. From a Thank you in our next program to a spot in the next Off Off Broadzway show! And plenty of other great stuff in between. Check out our list over there------->


Indiegogo allows us to exceed our goal. SO please know that if (big IF) that happens, that's going to get the Broadz some amazingly spectacular stuff for our Spring show, like giant feather fans or....actually probably giant feather fans. They're really expensive and we've wanted them for years...

Other Ways You Can Help

Can't afford it? No prob! We totally get it, but you can still help by spreading the word! We already know you're good at this, because you've gotten us this far! Tweet your little hearts out! Do you know people in New Orleans?? Share this with them! Slap it on their facebook!And thank you so much for even reading this far. We have the best friends.

story:
Short Summary

One girl had an idea but needed some help, the other wanted to finally put her directing training to use. So they teamed up. Caitlin LaBarge and Melissa Meli met at an audition a year and a half ago, but somehow lost each other. When they reconnected through a mutual friend they thought, “This has to be an act of God!”

Both girls attended acting school here in NYC and have been working day jobs and involving themselves in as many shows as possible. Usually, they go through the traditional audition process, but this time they decided to take charge. Truly a case of great minds thinking alike, and all that was said was in Earnest? YES!!

Who doesn’t love mistaken identity and nonsense of that sort? Only crazy people, if you ask us. The Importance of being Earnest is a show that no matter how many times someone sees it, they still will see it again. Two men, Jack and Algernon, both want to be called Ernest and pretend to be when they are not home. Two women, Gwendolen and Cecily, want to fall in love with a man named Ernest. They both seem to have done just that with the same man...or is he? There is also an incident with a handbag… Are you confused yet? Good! It's an amazing show. After all, who doesn’t love Oscar Wilde?

What We Need & What You Get

The reason why you pay so much money when you go to Broadway is because producing a show is expensive, and they want to make a profit. We don’t need to make a profit, but just want to break even. Let us tell you just where your money is going.

  • Venue - most smaller theatres run $2000-2500 for a week's run (including tech rehearsals and performances). The more you give us, the better the theatre we can reserve!
  • Costumes - $500 or more for rentals. Earnest is a period piece, so we can't just grab something from your closets and go.
  • Programs – about $100 for ink and paper
  • Postcards – $250-300 for professionally printed cards to get the word out
  • Last but not least, with any extra we may have, we would love to give a little something back to our actors and tech staff if at all possible!

For those of you doing math, you will notice that all those numbers add up to even more than our goal. We have a little money towards it, but we're hoping for as much as we can get. Fortunately, our rehearsal spaces are free (our apartments) till tech (when the rehearsal space will be incluced with the week's rental).

The Impact

You are helping our dreams come true, to do one of the greatest shows of all time and do it our way(the awesome way, of course)! This show brings laughter and happiness to anyone who sees it. So why wouldn’t you want to help?!

You can read scenes and go to shows and take classes but nothing gives you the confidence and the pride of doing a show, in a theatre - not a studio space or in a park, but a real theatre. And shows like this one can't be adequately done in a field or a large studio; they deserve a larger arena.

Other Ways You Can Help If You Just Can't Spare The Money

  • Send your friends to our IndieGoGo page and ask THEM to donate money!
  • Follow Melissa or Caitlin on Twitter for updates @CaitlinLaBarge or @Melissajmeli
  • Volunteer during the show, helping us haul things to the theatre, printing out programs, being a stage hand, etc.
  • Come to the show anyway and fill those seats!

story:
TICKETS ARE STILL AVAILABLE HERE: http://4soul.tumblr.com/

“INNATE” will be an hour long documentary capturing bboying, often called breakdancing, as a true art form. The film will explore what happens when bboys are taken out of competitions, staged performances, and movies. Using minimal dialogue to keep the focus on the dance, the documentary combines stunning landscapes and explosive dancing to engage the audience into what bboying has become since the 1980s.                                      

THE EVENT

As a huge thank you to everyone who supported our documentary "INNATE," we would like to invite everyone to our celebratory event, SOULCAL! Come see our bboys, aka breakdancers, compete live in this special, exclusive event. This dance event will showcase many of the bboys that will be featured in "INNATE," as well as other top bboys from around the nation, from Florida to Texas and down to California. The event will feature special exhibitions and a 3-on-3 competition, which will also allow open entry by the public.

SOULCAL was a premiere Southern California bboy event which took place quarterly between 2001-2004 and brought in many bboys and people from all over the world, often totaling over 3,000 people in attendence. This event showcased bboys from other states and around the world, resulting in high level competitions and amazing battles between premiere crews and individual bboys.

Not having been around since 2004, SOULCAL is now back and ready to rock Southern California once again. We're ready to bring back the excitement, uncertainties, and challenges of competitions. This event will once again showcase different styles and scenes from inside and outside of Southern California, to rediscover the dance as something fresh and new. The success of this event will help support the completion of our documentary, INNATE, and can help support the possibility of futher SOULCAL events.

HOW YOU CAN HELP

Although we did exceed our original Kickstarter goal of $5000, we've only reached the minimum amount we need to complete our documentary to its fullest. This event will allow you to help provide additional funding for our documentary as well as meet and speak to the bboys face-to-face.

THE INCENTIVES

  • Your support of $15 or more will give you the opportunity to attend SOULCAL and see the bboys live and in person. You will also be given the opportunity to enter the 3-on-3 battles and test your skills against these top bboys. NO PERSONAL VIDEO RECORDING DEVICES WILL BE ALLOWED DURING THE EVENT, so your support will also entitle you to a digital copy of the event that you can view over and over.
  • If you are unable to personally attend the event, your support of $15 or more will enable you to receive a hard copy DVD and a digital copy of the event.
  • For those of you who were unable to support our original campaign and receive a copy of our bboy documentary, INNATE, you have another chance to claim a physical copy of the DVD with your support of $20 or more.
  • Your support of $30 or more will give you the opportunity to attend SOULCAL, receive a digital copy of the event, and receive a physical copy of the DVD documentary, INNATE.

@ A Secret Location
Long Beach.California

The film will explore what happens when bboys are taken out of competitions, staged performances, and movies. story:
Update! Check out the fun new $75 level perks generously donated by team member Kazi.


Laura Casner Photography

$275 Value for ONLY $150!

1.5 hours shooting

1-2 looks

CD of all processed, full sized images

3 select images retouched 

 

Scroll down to find the option on your right!

lauracasnerphotography.com

Follow Blog

"like" on Facebook

 

Chosen for the

Ms. Magazine's The Feminist's Guide to the Hollywood Fringe

Read all about GnR at NY Film Academy site

Watch Funding Friday Broadcast w/ Anastasia & Director Che'Rae 

Listen La LA Land Talk live Saturday June 1st at noonPT

Gist

Gracie and Rose live off the land & love off the grid. This hour-long solo play with multiple characters premieres at the Hollywood Fringe Festival this June.

  • Gracie and Rose fall in love in Wyoming in the late 1950’s. Gracie has been passing as a man, George, for some time, in order to do men’s work and live the way she feels most authentic.
  • These stories are not being told. Lesbians are typically portrayed as punch lines, sex fiends or stereotypes. The day to day love and struggle for acceptance stories are few and far between.
  • The better this premiere at the Hollywood Fringe Festival, the more impact we'll have behind our campaign to tell this story with a teaching component in universities around the world. 

What We Need & What You Get

Okay, so we had a little fun with the video. Of course there is a venue, lights, etc. To stay on schedule with the Fringe Festival offerings, Anastasia fronted the entire budget herself:

  1. $250 = Registration for Hollywood Fringe Festival
  2. $250 = Venue Rental
  3. $500 = Craft Services for video production volunteer team, tech staff, a reading at the Celebration Theatre, everything involved with 5 years of a work-in-porgress.
  4. $750 = Marketing Materials & Ads
  5. $200 = Lighting Operator for tech and run
  6. $200 = Sound Operator for tech and run

So that totals $2150. Why is our goal $5500? 

  1. $350 Indiegogo Fees (if we make the goal)
  2. $1000 to Director Che'Rae Adams (already invested 5 years)
  3. $500 to Producer )
  4. $1000 to (gasp) Anastasia herself!
  5. $500 for additional front-of-house staff & parties!

Everyone on this project is passionate, inteligent and highly creative. Passion doesn't pay the bills.

I am lucky enough to have attracted the best talent - take a look at the bios for Director (Che'Rae Adams) and Social Media Outreach Consultant (Cindy Marie Jenkins*). Amazing - right?

If we raise this money, then all the artists involved get paid more for their hard work and can continue to help me bring Gracie & Rose to colleges and universities with a teaching component. (More on that soon!)

We're working hard to secure funds through multiple sources. We've already received the generous support of the Center for Cultural Innovation's Professional Development grant (*this is how we could hire Cindy!). We continue to seek out grant sources including Women in the Arts and Media Coalition, The Autry Institute Maverick Prize, etc.

 

As you can see, there's no such thing as a solo show - this is a big team effort. And now you're part of that team!

Your Impact

A lot of people ask me if this show is based on a true story. I reply, "It's based on true stories of women through out history that we never hear about." Because we're all deprived of Lesbian and Gay history, there are huge omissions in American history, history of the Western states and women around the world. "Gracie and Rose" is a small offering to share this history with all of us.


 

Other Ways You Can Help

We really understand if this isn't a good time for you to contribute financially, but that doesn’t mean you can’t help:

Have a chat with Gracie, George, Rose and Pig

Facebook.com/GracieAndRoseASoloShow

See “Gracie and Rose” fully produced at the Hollywood Fringe Festival June 13-30!  HFF13.org/1372

Follow us on Twitter!  @AnastasiaCoon

#GracieNRose

Tell the friends you think would be interested in this project by using the Indiegogo share tools.

And see you soon for our great perks!

story:
CRISTAL:

Hello! My name is Cristal Gonzalez, author and performer of the one-woman show, LA SOMBRA. Born and raised in the campesino town of Watsonville, CA. Mi voz es campesina (A farmworker’s voice), hija de una madre soltera (daughter of a single mother) y escribo del corazon (I write from the heart.) I’ve been doing theater since I was a child, continued by passion for teatro at San Jose State University where I obtained a B.A in Theater Arts. SJSU awarded me with the Reed Award for Excellence in Acting and 1stplace in Oral Interpretation (2010). Shortly after graduating I continued to exercise and develop my skills as a performer with El Teatro Campesino, for over a year. In March 2012 ETC gave a home to LA SOMBRA in a successful weekend production.

LA SOMBRA:

LA SOMBRA is a play that deals with the issue that many women face, domestic violence. This play invites you to explore all the sombras (shadows) that outline your own reflection. It focuses on a young couple Celi and Army- a relationship whose love is lingering on a breath of hope: la necia esperanza, que mañana, el cambiara. Celi must confront her past and present shadows to find her own sombra (shadow).

 

Cuando me perdi en ti-      / When did I lose myself in you-

Dejando ni un rostro de lo que yo fui? / Leaving no trace of who i used to be.

Cuando te di tanto poder sobre mi? / When did I give you so much control over me?

 

¿Por que hablar, si es mucho mas fácil callar ? Why speak, if it’s easier to remain silent?

 As a young writer and performer I continue to seek opportunities to share our stories on-stage. All stories, especially the ones we’ve kept quiet for years, the stories that live within our skins, the stories that need a witness in order to heal, the stories we are told MUST not be talked about, “de esas cosas no se habla.” Pero es precisamente esas historias que nos causan dolor, son de esas historias que tenemos que aprender a hablar. La Sombra deals with domestic violence a universal theme that cross-culturally has been kept in shadows. Why do we stay? Why are we silent?  Why did I stay? Why was I loyal to him but not myself? This play is an invitation for dialog to begin. If we don’t share our stories then we stand alone in our experiences.

 

We need YOU y tus centavitos

We need YOU, every dollar counts. Cualquier donación es una ganancia para nosotros.

This production is self-produced and NEEDS the funds ($4000) to cover the following items:

Rental fees, rehearsal space, publicity and submission fees, artistic designers, musician recordings, lighting operator, projection operator, front of house personnel, video and audio recording of production, equipment, postal services, transportation, and food for the my hard-working & talented LA SOMBRA team!

Receive a beautiful poster of LA SOMBRA signed by cast and artistic designers by supporting this production with $50 o mas.

Apoyenos con $75 + y reciba mitad de precio en su entrada a la presentación, if you donate $100 you’ll receive one free ticket to the show.  

Donate $1000 or more and join cast and crew for dinner! 

*Your donations will allow this production to give tickets to local youth and women organizations! 

Other Ways You Can Help

We understand if you can’t support us financially, here are other ways to help this production reach its goal!

  • Share the link to your family & friends (maybe they can help)
  • Come see the show and don’t forget to bring a date. 
  • Llamanle a las comadres, hermanas (os), tias y tios, abuelitos, al vecino chismoso, amigas(os), al novio o novia y vengan al show! 
  • Share the video on your facebook and twitter.
  • Send us good vibes. Mandenos un monton de vibras positivas.
  • Get us connected with Domestic Violence organizations, we want local organizations to see the show.
  • Donate printing services! BIG thank you in advance
  • Don’t forget to use Indiegogo share tools! 

La Caja Negra & CASA0101 Present: La Sombra  

Little CASA Theater:

2009 E. 1st St, 

Los Angeles, 90033

visit: casa0101.org 

September 7th and 8th at 8pm, September 9th at 5pm

Reserve your tickets with CASA0101 

(323) 263 7684

Ticket prices: 

$12 General Admission

$10 Students 

 

Many thanks to: 

El Teatro Campesino, Anahuac Valdez, Alfredo Avila, Alma Catalan, Chirsty Sandoval, George Villanueva, Kinan Valdez, Yely de Leon & friends and family.

story:
Here's the Story!

Chimera Project is a New York based collaboration premiering it's first piece in Spoleto, Italy in August 2014. We received an invitation from La MAMA Umbria to premier a piece in 8 months. Chimera Project is comprised of Kristin Draucker, Marielis Garcia, and Nicole Restani.

Chimera is in the process of creating a  multi-performance series that exemplifies the uniqueness of live theater.  

    


We need your Help!

La Mama Umbria International Festival is graciously providing room and board as well as marketing materials for our performance in Italy but there are still things we need help covering. Your tax deductible donations will go directly towards paying for:

  • Rehearsal Space in NYC: $1500
  • Costumes and Cleaning Cost (so much paint to clean): $500
  • Paint and Canvas: $500
  • Production Cost: $500

What YOU get!

To thank you for your support we have created a wide range of perks from Facebook shout-outs to VIP invitations. Please check them out!  

Any help, even the forwarding along of this campaign will be met with the up most gratitude.  

Risks & Rewards
Every performance begins with a blank canvas on the performance space. Throughout the piece the dancers will paint using different parts of their bodies, thus, marking the canvas. The movements are set and choreographed, but the artwork created is different every time. Each performance will display the final canvas and a canvas of performances prior, allowing the audience to observe the similarities, differences, irregularities and subtleties of live performance. 

This piece is a big endeavor, the biggest each has ever been a part of. We are nervous, frightened but most of all extremely excited to present a fully thought out dance piece.

 We can't do it without you!

story:
Who We Are

The Cambrians [KAYM-bree-uns] is a brand new, Chicago-headquartered dance production and media company. The Chicago Tribune called our first undertaking, The Nexus Project, "hard to describe, but easy to watch", and we love that. We use large collaborative processes that coordinate the very best performers with numerous choreographers from many different communities. These processes create genre-bending, interdisciplinary performances which challenge the notion that progressive art can't be accessible. We strive to make sure that as many voices as possible have an influence in the art we put on stage. Working with artists from many perspectives allows us to build art rooted in the human experiences that connect us all.

Visit our website WWW.THECAMBRIANS.COM to get to know us in depth!


What You're Helping Us Create


Contributions to this campaign go directly to the building of The Cambrians’ Theater in a Box. The Theater in a Box is a community resource that consists of a 1,296 sq ft collapsible sprung floor, an excellent sound system and an 18-fixture LED lighting rig. We'll be able to set this theater up in neighborhood venues throughout Chicago and beyond for performances.  

When we're not using our equipment, we'll be renting it (at maintenance-level prices) to dance and theatre peers throughout the Chicagoland area. This sort of equipment is normally reserved for high-budget companies and corporate events–as such the current rental rates are far beyond the reach of most small-scale performing arts companies. We don't think dancers should need a multi-million dollar budget to dance on a floor that protects their bodies. We don't think small dance and theater companies should have to pay the same rental rates as massive pop and Broadway shows to use high-capacity technologies like LED lighting.

We've secured some funding toward realizing the Theater in a Box already. It's central to our philosophy that our resources are sharable whenever possible. This campaign supports the final $10,000 we need to see it through to the end.



Why a Freaking Theater In a Box?


Good question! The Cambrians  perform extended runs of four weeks or more in non-traditional spaces (think auto garage) for small audiences of 50-100 people. Renting stage equipment two or three times a year for a month or more at a time gets expensive in a hurry. In other words, over the next two years, the cost to rent equipment for our shows would be significantly higher than the cost of building and purchasing our Theater in a Box, which contains equipment that's better than what we could afford to rent. 

 
Also, the fact of the matter is that many dance artists in Chicago often struggle to meet their basic production needs–a good floor, sound, and light. The Theater in a Box is our creative solution to this problem: a sensible sharing of resources to help the Chicago dance and performing arts community we love execute its creativity to the fullest.


What's the Equipment?


Now down to the nitty-gritty details. The Theater in a Box consists of:


LIGHTING RIG

16 x Chauvet COLORdash Par-Hex 12 Luminaires

2 x Chauvet Q-WASH 419Z-LED

1 x Philips Strand 250ML Lighting Controller


SOUND SYSTEM 

2 x JBL 515XT Powered Speakers

1 x JBL 518S Subwoofer

1 x Mackie Pro FX12 Mixer


COLLAPSIBLE SPRUNG FLOOR

-1,024 square feet configurable in 4' increments for width and length

-Hardwood and Metal Construction

-2” thick EVA foam padding for true spring


How Much Will It Cost to Rent?


Prices for those contributing to this campaign:

Lighting

1 x LED Par Wash - $10/week 

1 x LED Mover - $20/week

1 x Lighting Board - $35/week

4 x LED Par Wash - $35/week

2 x  LED Movers - $35/week

8 x LED Par Wash - $70/week

12 x LED Par Wash - $100/week

16 x LED Par Wash - $120/week

All lights without Lighting Console - $150/week

All lights with Lighting Console - $175/week

Sound System

$50/week

Floor

$25/day + transport and install

$150/week + transport and install

Full Theater-in-a-Box

$300/week + transport and install


Consecutive, two week rentals receive a 20% discount on equipment

Consecutive, three week rentals receive a 30% discount on equipment

Consecutive, four week rentals receive a 40% discount on equipment

Consecutive, five or more week rentals receive a 50% discount on equipment


Perks!


Oh we've got perks. These perks serve as thank-you gifts to those who help make our Theater in a Box a reality. 

For those of you who don’t need theatrical equipment, we’ve designed a customizable line of Cambrians merchandise. Pick from These Cambrians Images to make a tote, gym bag, shower curtain or other keepsake.



First and foremost, we're offering discount vouchers for equipment rental: 10% per $100 contribution. So your $100 contribution gets you $110 in rental credit, your $200 contribution gets you $240, etc... The more you give, the larger the discount, up to 50% off.

Dates for rentals will blackout on a first come, first serve basis. Check our Google Calendar for availability and get your dates to us ASAP.

And because your support makes us wanna boogie, we're gonna Do a Little Dance in addition to any perk you choose. You just give us a task or idea of your choice and one of the Cambrians will do a 30 second dance about it. Dancing's fun!

Stretch Goals!


The campaign is going so well, we're adding stretch goals! If we make it to $12,500, we'll purchase two more LED par washes. And if we make it to $15,000, we'll purchase two more LED washes + purchase one LED moving spotlight for special effects!

We can make this happen!!!

*And remember, all contributions to this campaign are tax-deductible, minus the cash value of any perk you choose. Thanks to our incredible fiscal sponsor Links Hall!*


*In addition, all discount vouchers for equipment rental are limited to the Chicago area, due to shipping expenses.


Congratulations, you made it to the end! Thanks for reading, and please ask us any questions you may have.
story_txt:
Who We Are





The
Cambrians [KAYM-bree-uns] is
a brand new, Chicago-headquartered dance production and media
company. The Chicago Tribune called our first undertaking, The Nexus
Project, "hard to describe, but easy to watch", and we love
that. We use large collaborative processes that coordinate the very
best performers with numerous choreographers from many different
communities. These processes create genre-bending, interdisciplinary
performances which challenge the notion that progressive art can't be
accessible. We strive to make sure that as many voices as possible
have an influence in the art we put on stage. Working with artists
from many perspectives allows us to build art rooted in the human
experiences that connect us all.
Visit our website WWW.THECAMBRIANS.COM to get to know us in depth!







  What You're Helping Us Create


Contributions to this campaign go directly to the building of The Cambrians’ Theater in a Box. The Theater in a Box is a community resource that consists of a 1,296 sq ft collapsible sprung floor, an excellent sound system and an 18-fixture LED lighting rig. We'll be able to set this theater up in neighborhood venues throughout Chicago and beyond for performances.  
When we're not using our equipment, we'll be renting it (at maintenance-level prices) to dance and theatre peers throughout the Chicagoland area. This sort of equipment is normally reserved for high-budget companies and corporate events–as such the current rental rates are far beyond the reach of most small-scale performing arts companies. We don't think dancers should need a multi-million dollar budget to dance on a floor that protects their bodies. We don't think small dance and theater companies should have to pay the same rental rates as massive pop and Broadway shows to use high-capacity technologies like LED lighting.
We've secured some funding toward realizing the Theater in a Box already. It's central to our philosophy that our resources are sharable whenever possible. This campaign supports the final $10,000 we need to see it through to the end.










Why a Freaking Theater In a Box?





Good
question! The
Cambrians 
perform extended runs of four weeks or more in non-traditional spaces
(think auto garage) for small audiences of 50-100 people. Renting
stage equipment two or three times a year for a month or more at a
time gets expensive in a hurry. In other words, over the next two
years, the cost to rent equipment for our shows would be significantly
higher
than the cost of building and purchasing our Theater in a Box, which contains
equipment that's better than what we could afford to rent. 
  Also, the
fact of the matter is that many dance artists in Chicago often
struggle to meet their basic production needs–a good floor, sound,
and light. The Theater in a Box is our creative solution to this
problem: a sensible sharing of resources to help the Chicago dance
and performing arts community we love execute its creativity to the
fullest.

SOUND SYSTEM 
2 x JBL 515XT Powered Speakers
1 x JBL 518S Subwoofer
1 x Mackie Pro FX12 Mixer





COLLAPSIBLE SPRUNG FLOOR
		-1,024 square feet configurable in 4' increments for width and length
		-Hardwood
and Metal Construction
		-2”
thick EVA foam padding for true spring




How Much Will It Cost to Rent?

Prices for those contributing to this campaign:

Lighting
1 x LED Par Wash - $10/week 
1 x LED Mover - $20/week
1 x Lighting Board - $35/week
4 x LED Par Wash - $35/week

8 x LED Par Wash - $70/week

All lights with Lighting Console - $175/week

we've got perks.  These perks serve as thank-you gifts to those
who help make our Theater in a Box a reality. For those of you

your support makes us wanna boogie, we're gonna Do

addition to any perk you choose. You just give us a task or idea of

it. Dancing's fun!

Stretch Goals!

The campaign is going so well, we're adding stretch goals! If we make it to $12,500, we'll purchase two more LED par washes. And if we make it to $15,000, we'll purchase two more LED washes + purchase one LED moving spotlight for special effects!

We can make this happen!!!

you made it to the end! Thanks for reading, and please ask us any
questions you may have.

story:
Who We Are

TE San Pedro Rep offers the Southern California community a unique alternative to the typical L.A. theater experience. A wholehearted celebration of empowered artistic innovation - from every background and medium, TESPR strives to reawaken the creative spirit in each of us.

True to its name, TE San Pedro Rep is an artistic paradise - a caring, dedicated community fully invested in the work of every inspired craftsman. We joyfully embrace the interdisciplinary nature of performance, utilizing every aspect of human experience to delve further and further into the unknown. Through intelligent and fearless exploration, TESPR is committed to reexamining the fundamental works that have defined performance from Ancient Greece to Modern America. We knowingly stand on the shoulders of giants, casting our vision forward into a new era of American performance.

We remain committed to fueling the next generation of American art, creating visionary work that rattles the foundations of modern performance.


The Campaign

The Goal: $3,000 to build a dynamic, innovative administrative department that will nurture, expand and fuel TESPR's artistic and financial aspirations.

This year's STARS Campaign focuses on investing in every important aspect of how we work: company communications, marketing, community relations, student/school outreach, audience expansion and all facets of maturing TESPR's growth as a healthy, theatrical business.


In 2013 we SUCCESSFULLY secured:

Color Laser Printer + Lighting Board

In 2014 we SUCCESSFULLY secured:

Non-Profit Status Funding + New Sound System

In 2015 we are WORKING TO SECURE:

TESPR's First Administrative Department + Marketing & Outreach Expansion


Will you help us SUCCEED THREE YEARS IN A ROW?

We cannot reach our goal without YOU - our community of devoted theatre-goers, supporters, and creators!

Will you add a STAR to brighten our way?


Other Ways You Can Help

The success of this project lies in the sense of community it inspires. We believe in the power of community. It is an ever increasing force, a will that can do things that no single person - no matter their talents - can achieve on their own. Put simply, we are Believers. Optimists. Enthusiasts. We invite you to share in our dream - that together we can build an artistic paradise of devoted, passionate, and FEARLESS artists, boldly pushing the boundaries of performance throughout the world!

story:
It is hard to define with a start up company how much money is needed. We can make a dollar stretch pretty far which both means we can make due with very little and each little bit more we have makes a big difference. Below is a breakdown of how we would use your money depending how much we raise. In each scenario around 50% of the money would go to the dancers, 10 % for advertising, and 40% towards space rental and travel. Thank you so much for your support!

$2,000 - 1 full length show at a black box theater

2 local festival appearances

$2,500 - 1 full length show at a black box theater

Cape Cod Tour including Built on Stilts Festival, a company photo shoot with Larry Pratt, and a sight specific work for film

$3,000 - 1 full length show at a black box theater

1 local festival appearance

Cape Cod Tour including Built on Stilts Festival, a company photo shoot with Larry Pratt, and a sight specific work for film

$3,500 - 1 full length show at a block box theater

Cape Cod Tour including Built on Stilts Festival, a company photo shoot with Larry Pratt, and a sight specific work for film

2 local festival appearances

$4,200 - 1 full length show at a block box theater

Cape Cod Tour including Built on Stilts Festival, a company photo shoot with Larry Pratt, and possibly a sight specific work for film

1 full length show outdoors in NYC

2 local festival appearances

$4,700 - 1 full length show at a block box theater

1 full length show outdoors in NYC

Cape Cod Tour including Built on Stilts Festival, a company photo shoot with Larry Pratt, and a sight specific work for film

3 local festival appearances

Above this amount all additional money will go to the dancers. For every $60 additional dollars raised each dancer will receive a $10 increase in one of their stipends.

story:
The team that brought you Warm Enough for Swimming - last summer's hit at the New York International Fringe Festival - needs your help to mount their next production - Bonedive Scrounger - at the Brick Theater later this month.

Written by Fred Backus and directed by Maggie Cino (one of Indie Theater Now's People of the Year in 2014), Bonedive Scrounger is an urban morality play set in a mythical dive bar built on an Indian burial ground while the relentless grind of Darwinian gentrification carries on around and inside it.  It features a fantastic ensemble cast of Indie Theater veterans:  Rebecca Comtois, Jorge Cordova, Bryan Enk, Bob Laine, Timothy McCown Reynolds, and Alyssa Simon.  After a tremendous response from a staged-reading last spring at the Oven Reading Series at the Brick, Bonedive Scrounger is ready for a full production.

And as the relentless rise of costs grinds on in New York City, those of us still trying to produce new and independent theatrical works face a host of financial challenges in order to keep producing art.  Box office receipts alone are no longer enough to ensure a minimum standard of production value, to pay for the ever increasing costs of renting rehearsal space in a real estate market that is out of control, and to ensure that all the artists involved - Equity and non-Equity alike - get a small stipend for their time, commitment, and talent.  We need your help!  

Obvious Volcano and the Brick Theater Present:

Bonedive Scrounger

A tale of urban menace and Darwinian gentrification

Written by Fred Backus and directed by Maggie Cino

January 22-January 31, 2015 at the Brick Theater, Brooklyn, NY

www.bricktheater.com

In a dive bar built on an ancient burial ground, Jimmy's always talking, Annie's collecting souls, while Bull is claiming hats to mount on the wall.  When Clementina shows up thinking she's on a blind date, Bronco - the writer who writes Nothing for Nobody - has to learn to play the game without shooting any doe.

Starring Rebecca Comtois, Jorge Cordova*, Bryan Enk, Bob Laine, Timothy McCown Reynolds*, and Alyssa Simon*.

*appear courtesy of Actors Equity Association

Stage Manager:  Berit Johnson

Scenic Design:  Christiaan Koop

Light Design:  Morgan Anne Zipf

Costume Design:  Karen Flood

Choreography:  Dina Rose Rivera

Technical Advisor:  Chris Connolly

story:
WHERE YOU MOVE ME MOST is a new immersive workshop exploring the routes queer bodies take in enacting freedom, and the freedom to desire.

The event will take place on 24, 25, and 26 September 2020 as part of SeptFest at The Substation.

With movement as its main tool, WYMMM sees the co-existence of two characters who explore a myriad of sexual and gender identities within themselves as well as each other. They navigate spaces, from the nightclub to the bedroom, their gestures a reflection of surveillance and safety.

Its focus on the nightclub is in reference to local monthly parties for women and non-binary people organised by Herstory and Two Queens Asia. While spaces catering to mainly cis-gay men operate on a regular basis, spaces for other queer people exist in more marginal forms, appearing in monthly and ad-hoc events. These spaces continue to be where young people escape to navigate their position within queer identity in Singapore. Here, the nightclub is a messy utopia, where desire plays out and identity is continually constructed. Much of its dynamics remain offline as protection for the community; bringing these gestures into a performance space safely visibilises these lived experiences.
 
The source material was generated through time spent documenting these spaces, as well as Charmaine’s ethnographic series, How They Love, which features interviews with people in the queer community, as well as photographs lensing the way queer desire is performed for the camera. These observations of gestures form a basis from which to devise the piece.

The piece is co-choreographed with Syimah Sabtu and Sonia Kwek, two movement artists whose research interests have been built on body politics. The piece's new media design is carried by Mervin Wong, whose background in classical music and electronic production intersect with audio-visual pieces for performances.

Topics relating to the queer community fall in a grey area between what can be supported by national arts funds, and what is permissible by the state media authority. Hence, we seek your kind, private donations in realizing this work. Money raised will go towards paying artists fairly and providing for media materials, set, and prop costs.

This immersive workshop has the potential to be staged as a performance in 2021, if and when COVID-19 regulations allow for it. As such, awaiting further news from The Substation, any extra funds will be channeled towards this performance, or donated to Sayoni.

Should you have more questions and/or queries, please write to contact@charmainepoh.com. We are truly grateful for any support given to tell these stories, especially in these times.

story:
Who We Are 

Marc Blanchard and Scott Kuipers are two Toronto based creators.

​Marc is from London, Ontario and Scott is from Prince Edward County. They met and completed their training together at the Ryerson University Theatre School. Having collaborated numerous times throughout their training, they co produced, wrote, and acted in their first original piece, The Brothers Gentle, at the 2018 Toronto Fringe.

​This campaign will help realize our second project, An Utterly Stupid Indefensible Thing, this summer at the 2019 Toronto Fringe . It will also help to ensure we can better compensate our generous designers and technicians! 

What We Need & What You Get

We are seeking $830.00 in funding. 

This will go to: 

  • Helping to cover registration and participation fees from the Fringe Festival
  • ​Renting a studio space for rehearsal 
  • Printing rehearsal and show materials (scripts!) 
  • ​Advertising out production! 
  • ​Travel costs 
  • Providing a contingency (in case something breaks!) 
  • ​Last but not least: through helping to cover these costs, we are able to better produce this show, increasing our audience reach, all leading to better compensate our dedicated team of designers, managers, and technicians sharing box office revenue. 

PERKS 

We value your contribution and want to give you something in return! Here are a few of the perks we can’t wait to share with you: 

  • Personalized shout outs on social media and in our show program! 
  • A handmade post card by resident Doodle Captain Scott Kuipers 
  • A PDF copy of our script, with personalized notes and tons of project images 
  • Complimentary tickets to any one of our shows! 
  • A limited edition 24x36 colour poster, signed with love by the whole team 
  • A printed booklet of the script, signed with love by Marc and Scott 


If we don’t reach our entire goal, the funds accumulated will go to covering rehearsal and registration costs. They will help us realize this project and try and give our community a great experience in the theatre. 

Impact

We strive to tell character-based stories with sensitivity and nuance. We respect the audience and work tirelessly to give a thought provoking experience.

  • Our first project, The Brothers Gentle, a quirky two hander exploring brotherhood and masculinity, opened at the 2018 Toronto Fringe to a warm reception with audiences and critics alike. You can check out a review of the work here: https://nowtoronto.com/stage/theatre/fringe-rev...
  • This campaign not only raises funds for our second collaboration, helping to ensure we deliver the best story possible, but also furthers our advancement as artist producers. It will help refine our skills and build experience, all to become more productive members of this vibrant artistic community. 

Risks & Challenges

Every live performance carries with it inevitable risks and challenges. Here are some situations we could run into: 

  • Pieces of set or actor props breaking. Technical difficulties with sound and projection.
  • ​Not to mention, the Fringe Festival is bursting with amazing artists and so there is lots of healthy competition to reach out and capture the interest of an audience. And while we have lots of experience, this is only our second project and we are still introducing ourselves to this awesome community. 

How do we plan to address these challenges? 

  • Thriftiness: We use low cost set and props. If we can borrow rather than buy, we do! 
  • Good People: We have a whip smart team of artists and designers we know can tackle any issue we come across, technical or otherwise. 
  • Grass Roots: We are running multiple social media campaigns on Facebook, Instagram, and Twitter, creating original content to build interest and audience. And nothing is more powerful than word of mouth! We need awesome people like you, who are interested in supporting artistic development and independent work, to help spread the word! 

Other Ways You Can Help

If you are unable to donate, don't worry! Here are some ways to contribute: 

  • Share this campaign ! You can use the Indiegogo share tools. 
  • Spread the word about our upcoming production! Tickets are on sale June 6th. Check it out here: https://fringetoronto.com/fringe/show/utterly-s...
  • And last but not least, come see An Utterly Stupid Indefensible Thing, on July 4th to 14th at Streetcar Crowsnest the Toronto Fringe! 

And that's all there is to it!

​Travel costs 
Providing a contingency (in case something breaks!) 
​Last but not least: through helping to cover these costs, we are able to better produce this show, increasing our audience reach, all leading to better compensate our dedicated team of designers, managers, and technicians sharing box office revenue. 

PERKS 
We value your contribution and want to give you something in return! Here are a few of the perks we can’t wait to share with you: 

Personalized shout outs on social media and in our show program! 
A handmade post card by resident Doodle Captain Scott Kuipers 
A PDF copy of our script, with personalized notes and tons of project images 
Complimentary tickets to any one of our shows! 
A limited edition 24x36 colour poster, signed with love by the whole team 
A printed booklet of the script, signed with love by Marc and Scott 

If we don’t reach our entire goal, the funds accumulated will go to covering rehearsal and registration costs. They will help us realize this project and try and give our community a great experience in the theatre. 
Impact
We strive to tell character-based stories with sensitivity and nuance. We respect the audience and work tirelessly to give a thought provoking experience.

Our first project, The Brothers Gentle, a quirky two hander exploring brotherhood and masculinity, opened at the 2018 Toronto Fringe to a warm reception with audiences and critics alike. You can check out a review of the work here: https://nowtoronto.com/stage/theatre/fringe-rev...

This campaign not only raises funds for our second collaboration, helping to ensure we deliver the best story possible, but also furthers our advancement as artist producers. It will help refine our skills and build experience, all to become more productive members of this vibrant artistic community. 

Risks & Challenges
Every live performance carries with it inevitable risks and challenges. Here are some situations we could run into: 

Pieces of set or actor props breaking. Technical difficulties with sound and projection.
​Not to mention, the Fringe Festival is bursting with amazing artists and so there is lots of healthy competition to reach out and capture the interest of an audience. And while we have lots of experience, this is only our second project and we are still introducing ourselves to this awesome community. 

How do we plan to address these challenges? 

Thriftiness: We use low cost set and props. If we can borrow rather than buy, we do! 
Good People: We have a whip smart team of artists and designers we know can tackle any issue we come across, technical or otherwise. 
Grass Roots: We are running multiple social media campaigns on Facebook, Instagram, and Twitter, creating original content to build interest and audience. And nothing is more powerful than word of mouth! We need awesome people like you, who are interested in supporting artistic development and independent work, to help spread the word! 

Other Ways You Can Help
If you are unable to donate, don't worry! Here are some ways to contribute: 

Share this campaign ! You can use the Indiegogo share tools. 
Spread the word about our upcoming production! Tickets are on sale June 6th. Check it out here: https://fringetoronto.com/fringe/show/utterly-s...

And last but not least, come see An Utterly Stupid Indefensible Thing, on July 4th to 14th at Streetcar Crowsnest the Toronto Fringe! 

And that's all there is to it!

story:
Short Summary

 

Dear Contributor,

We are a small dance shoe maker and supply dance shoes to people and communities mainly on a national basis at present. We have been in operation for only a few years but have seen the demand for dance shoes grow quite quickly as the dance phenomenon takes off around the world.

So far we have been supplying to the average higher end of the socio-economic spectrum, which is where the bulk of people who dance are sourced from. However, due to the high cost of dancing and learning to dance, it is quite prohibitive to the lower end of the socio-economic range and the poor and disadvantaged and they never end up being able to experience the health, social, self-esteem, and other benefits that are derived from this popular pasttime.

Our dream now is to bring dancing to this lower end of the spectrum and allow these people to finally participate in this great craze. The benefits it will bring will be immeasurable.

The only way we can achieve this goal is to ask everyday folk such as yourself to help with a contribution to get this project off the ground. We aim to have at least 10,000-20,000 new dancers around the underpriveleged world by the end of 2012, with many many more within the coming years (500,000 or more people). In order to do this we will need a fair amount of working capital (i.e. money), so we ask you to contribute what you can and hopefully we can raise an amount that can help us bring this dream to reality! Please help!

 

Other Ways You Can Help

 

Get in contact with us and let us know if you are able to help us spread this dream by letting us know of the local communities, people, or groups who we would be able to get involved in the dance craze who currently would not be able to due to being from a low socio-economic group, are disadvantaged, or otherwise unable to participate due to the high cost or lack of facilities in their area.

story:
My Aerial Dance Project

Hello, my name is Sky Van Vliet.  I am a young dancer and aerialist, as well as an actress and model.  But mostly, I love to perform!  And I have been performing for most of my life!

As an aerialist, I have been very fortunate to be able to use an aerial rig owned by a friend.  But it now seems that the rig will no longer be available for me to use.  While my parents have been amazing supporters of all of my passions for the performing arts, they are just barely able to pay for my dance tuition every month.  So $3,500 for an aerial rig, cable ladder and new crash mat is just not in the budget since my dad is the only one working right now.  

By having my own aerial rig, I can perform at more events and be able to help cover the cost of tuition for the 9 weekly dance classes I currently take. And I would be able to perform at more charity events that are close to my heart because I would own my own equipment and would not be dependent on someone else's schedule.  I would also be able to teach aerial classes!

If my campaign gets funded, I will use the equipment to inspire and do good things.  I WILL PAY IT FORWARD!  I have been so lucky to have the opportunity to train and perform.  I just want to have the tools that will allow me to keep on doing what I am so passionate about!  Peace , Love and Aerial Dance!

If you can't contribute, please share my story and campaign with others.  Thank you for taking the time to consider making a contribution to My Aerial Dance Project campaign!

story:
Who are we?

The Brigata is a company of actors, designers, and writers who stage readings and productions of their own plays. Last year, The Violence of My Affection performed at Chicago's A Red Orchid Theatre. This year, we're bringing this poetic and beautiful play to New York City!

What are we doing this time?

On January 11 and 12, we'll stage readings of the new draft of The Violence of My Affection, an original play by Gaetano Marangelli, at The Tank, a non-profit theater in Midtown Manhattan. On January 13, we'll present previews of The Violence of My Affection and new plays by Gaetano Marangelli and Marta Mondelli. 

Why is this important to us?

The staged readings and preview of The Violence of My Affection serve as the foundation for our production of the play this year. As a new company, we want to find new audiences for our work, and presenting these performances at The Tank during the Association of Performing Arts Presenters Conference in New York on January 11, 12, and 13 offers us a wonderful opportunity to do that.

What is this play about?

The Violence of My Affection is the story of an Italian actress whose love of language binds, then severs her marriage to an American scholar. When their son, a journalist, tells her of her husband’s sudden death, she refuses to believe him—until she reveals to him the cause of her husband’s demise.

The play’s principal character, Sofonisba Bellini, evokes the power of Greek heroines. Her evolving stages of English diction mark both the ascent of her power and her descent into sorrow and anguish. "Marangelli's principal character is not your typical victim of pain and suffering,” wrote Chicago Stage Style of the premiere production, “who doesn’t know how to feel sympathy for the world that rejected her. Her inner mental workings create a magical play." 

What do we need?

The Tank has given us its stage for our performances, but we still need to cover our stage rent expenses for rehearsals, the cost of props and costumes for our previews, and--most importantly--stipends for our designers and actors!

How will your contribution help us?

Your support will balance our budget for these performances, which means we can begin preparing a production of The Violence of My Affection.

Other Ways You Can Help

We'd love it if you:

  • like The Brigata's Facebook page.
  • follow @TheBrigata on Twitter.
  • share our Indiegogo campaign.
  • tell your friends about our project and our performance dates.

The Violence of My Affection stars Marta Mondelli (Sofonisba Bellini), Brendon DeMay (George Bellini), Jacques Roy (Stephen Bellini), and Cristina Lippolis (Colombina and Isabella Marea). The play is being produced by Natalie Qing Zhang and Rachel Alulis.

The Brigata is Rachel Alulis, Katherine Banks, Evan Brost, Mary Coy, Brendon DeMay, Ed Flynn, Matthew Gall, Noam Harary, Cristina Lippolis, Marta Mondelli, Gaetano Marangelli, Jacques Roy, Amanda Sager, Aemilia Scott, Jillian Staats, Rebekah Tsadik, and Natalie Qing Zhang.

story:
About our Director and our Project

My name is Barbara Brandt and I am the Founder and Artistic Director of Direction Dance Ensemble.  I am a dancer, choreographer, classically trained actor and musician.  DDE is my way of using the gifts I have to try to make the world around me a better place.  It is something I'm intensely passionate about - each of us has a responsibility to society, to speak to the issues of the day and to make a positive impact on the world around us.  I try to use my art to do that.  The majority of the works that DDE produces deal with topical issues.  

We are raising funds at this time to support our upcoming joint performance with Repertory Ballet of New York.  The pieces we are creating for this performance address a wide variety of issues: the joys of being a woman, the universal effect that war has on the individuals and their relationships (on both sides), and the struggle that a young gay man has to accept himself.  

Your contributions will help us to pay the dancers, to rent rehearsal space, to build costumes and to pay musicians who are composing the original music we use.  Your dollars are immensely important to our work - without them we cannot continue to grow.  DDE plans to build on its performance base into a company that uses dance as a teaching and healing enterprise.  None of this is possible without the generous support of our sponsors.

WHAT WE NEED

At this time we are working on a budget of $4500.  

  • $1000 for performance space rental
  • $500 for costumes
  • $1500 for musician, designer and dancer stipends
  • $175 for volunteer insurance
  • $300 for publicity printing
  • $500 for rehearsal space rental
  • $500 for extraneous unexpected expenses

HOW YOU CAN HELP

You can help in a variety of ways:

Donate!

We apprecaite any help you can provide - either monetary or otherwise!  All monetary contributions are tax deductable as our organizationan and this campaing are fiscally sponsored by Fractured Atlas.  

Spread the Word!

Even if you can't donate monetarily you can donate your support.  Tell people you know about us and our upcoming performances.  Spread the word about the campaign via the share buttons under the video.  Word of mouth is still the best press around!

Come to the Show!

We have the following upcoming performances:

Nunnbetter Dance Theatre, Bergenfield NJ (yes, you can get there from NYC!)

  • Saturday, May 12 at 8PM
  • Sunday, May 13 at 3PM
The Secret Theatre, Long Island City, Queens, NY
  • July 7th at 8PM
Visit www.directiondance.org for more information and to purchase tickets!
 

IN HONOR OF YOUR DONATIONS

If  you can donate funds, we will give you something in return!

  • $25:  a note of thanks on our FaceBook page, website and in the program
  • $50: a note of thanks on our FB page and in the program, website and program and a signed thank you card from the company
  • $100:  all of the above and a one BOGO ticket to an upcoming show
  • $250:  all of the above and one free Pilates lesson from dancer/choreographer Michael Blackmon
  • $500:  a note of thanks on our FB page, in the program, on our website, a signed thank you card from the company, two ticket to our show and a $25 new student gift card from Alvin Ailey Extension
  • $1000:  all of the above, a Producer Credit in the program and a copy of our DVD

 Any donation, no matter the amount is a blessing and will receive our sincerest thanks!

story:
Who are we?  Our story...

Stories of Substance” uses drama, humor and music in a creative, powerful, and efficient way to educate students about making healthy choices. It raises awareness about vital information, and a strong connection is forged with the emotions behind substance use, domestic violence, sexual conduct, bullying, self-esteem, depression, and internet safety.


The performance is written and performed by young adults and is developed from actual stories. The cast - peer educators, take the real stories and develop an interactive and engaging performance.  The audience can feel and learn. Some of the actors have experienced the scenes they are portraying. The cast share their experience through the scenes as well as in the talk back discussion after each performance, reaching their peers in a very powerful way.


The Impact

Stories of substance (SOS) is all about real stories, real people. Using theatre as an educational tool is not a new concept, but we take it a step further by combining three powerful tools:  theatre, peer education and real stories. Theatre is chosen as a medium for learning because it allows an audience to respond on a “feeling” level. We want our audience to "feel" the information before they think "that will not happen to me'.


Many times, students come up to the cast after shows to relate to a scene they saw on stage, or share with us their own, personal story. Other times, they will reach out to us online. Whichever way they do, our goal is to help them, "stop and think" about the choices they have made and continue to make.


What We Need & What You Get

We hope that through this campaign, we will be able to expand our reach to schools in the NYC metropolitan area. Unfortunately, we cannot afford to do that on our own. That is why we are turning to IndieGoGo to help us donate a show to the high school seniors of NYC.We feel that this show will help students prepare themselves for life issues, especially topics containing issues they might encounter in college.

Your donation would make it possible for us to cover all costs associated with theater rental, casting, transportation, and promotional material. Check out the side-bar on the right to discover what kinds of cool perks you can get!

Other Ways You Can Help

Even if you can't donate, you can always spread the word and refer your friends to our Facebook page and official website! And, as always, feel free to contribute your story to www.storiesofsubstance.com! We are always in need of stories, and we can't perform them without hearing from you! All stories are kept anonymous and confidential. 


Thanks so much, and spread the word!

story:
VAGABOND ALLEY PRODUCTIONS NEEDS YOU!

In 2013, Vagabond Alley Productions reignited and aims to step it up a notch by partnering with Clayton Weller of Pocket Theater a new concept in independent stage production in Seattle where producers only pay a cut of ticket sales for use of the space.

                     In JUNE 2014 Vagabond Alley Productions intends to mount 

                the one act play,"Love in the Time of Zombies," by Damian Trasler.  

This "ZomCom" (Definition: a romantic comedy set against a zombie apocalypse backdrop) is an intimately character driven script, uses a low production value, and will embrace a non-traditional rehearsal process where the actors scene study in preparation for working with the director. 

Our Modified Process Makes a Unique+Quality Result that Benefits Audiences,                                               Artists and their Concerns.

                   Starring D'Arcy Harrison, Jason Sharp and Robert Hankins

                                           directed by Amelia Meckler

         Producer/Artistic Director: D'Arcy Harrison  PR/Marketing: Brittany Carpenter 

                          Show Logo: Corey Feist Video Promo: Nick Terry 

             Video Makeup: Alexandra Wright Fight Choreography: Casey Brown

                           

                                                    History    

VAP was established in 2002 by Artistic Director/Executive Producer, D'Arcy Harrison. Its inaugural production,"Oleanna," by David Mamet starred D'Arcy Harrison and David Glowacki and staged in a Seattle Sodo loft. This show utilized a long form rehearsal process that utilized a directors panel after 4-5 months of private scene study. This script's incarnation garnered a Seattle Times Footlight Award for one of the Best of Fringe 2002 upon review by John Hartl on special from the New York Times.


                               WHY DO WE NEED YOUR CONTRIBUTION?

  • Expenses of the Show= marketing materials, rehearsal space, props, minimal/functional and easily transportable set pieces,etc. The space is paid for after we sell 20 tickets and VAP will fill the house with friends, family, clients, colleagues,..and strangers with its individual flair for multi-pronged word of mouth and PR.  Rights for the play are a % of gross ticket receipts which means our maximum expense of rights will be around $250-300. All other line items listed here will not exceed a $1100 cap.
  • Paying the Peoples!= VAP aims to be an organized, professional fringe theatrical company and believes contributors deserve some compensation for their creative energy and sacrifices. So Production Staff and Actors will be paid.
  • Giving Back=  10% of the proceeds (after fees) of this indiegogo campaign goes to Shunpike Arts Collective, an organization that supports Seattle's arts entrepeneurs in building their creative business organizations.

                              "WHAT DO I GET FOR DONATING TO VAP?"

          An opportunity to partake in a curated and awesome list of services/ items

     for donating to our campaign!  We will deliver your item upon conclusion of the                                              campaign between March 14-March 31 2014.

       You scratch our back we scratch yours! Our donations have reward levels by our                                               generous contributors and supporters.

                                                      

Rain City Integrative Clinic(massage and naturopathy) 

                                                     

Sugar Plum Spa (aesthetician+waxing)

                                                          

                               Cafe Nordo (original,locally sourced dinner theatre)
