story_txt:
VAGABOND ALLEY PRODUCTIONS NEEDS YOU!In 2013, Vagabond Alley Productions reignited and aims to step it up a notch by partnering with Clayton Weller of Pocket Theater a new concept in independent stage production in Seattle where producers only pay a cut of ticket sales for use of the space.                     In JUNE 2014 Vagabond Alley Productions intends to mount                 the one act play,"Love in the Time of Zombies," by Damian Trasler.  This "ZomCom" (Definition: a romantic comedy set against a zombie apocalypse backdrop) is an intimately character driven script, uses a low production value, and will embrace a non-traditional rehearsal process where the actors scene study in preparation for working with the director. Our Modified Process Makes a Unique+Quality Result that Benefits Audiences,                                               Artists and their Concerns.                   Starring D'Arcy Harrison, Jason Sharp and Robert Hankins                                           directed by Amelia Meckler         Producer/Artistic Director: D'Arcy Harrison  PR/Marketing: Brittany Carpenter                           Show Logo: Corey Feist Video Promo: Nick Terry              Video Makeup: Alexandra Wright Fight Choreography: Casey Brown                                                                               History    VAP was established in 2002 by Artistic Director/Executive Producer, D'Arcy Harrison. Its inaugural production,"Oleanna," by David Mamet starred D'Arcy Harrison and David Glowacki and staged in a Seattle Sodo loft. This show utilized a long form rehearsal process that utilized a directors panel after 4-5 months of private scene study. This script's incarnation garnered a Seattle Times Footlight Award for one of the Best of Fringe 2002 upon review by John Hartl on special from the New York Times.                               WHY DO WE NEED YOUR CONTRIBUTION?

Expenses of the Show= marketing materials, rehearsal space, props, minimal/functional and easily transportable set pieces,etc. The space is paid for after we sell 20 tickets and VAP will fill the house with friends, family, clients, colleagues,..and strangers with its individual flair for multi-pronged word of mouth and PR.  Rights for the play are a % of gross ticket receipts which means our maximum expense of rights will be around $250-300. All other line items listed here will not exceed a $1100 cap.

Paying the Peoples!= VAP aims to be an organized, professional fringe theatrical company and believes contributors deserve some compensation for their creative energy and sacrifices. So Production Staff and Actors will be paid.


Giving Back=  10% of the proceeds (after fees) of this indiegogo campaign goes to Shunpike Arts Collective, an organization that supports Seattle's arts entrepeneurs in building their creative business organizations.

                              "WHAT DO I GET FOR DONATING TO VAP?"          An opportunity to partake in a curated and awesome list of services/ items     for donating to our campaign!  We will deliver your item upon conclusion of the                                              campaign between March 14-March 31 2014.       You scratch our back we scratch yours! Our donations have reward levels by our                                               generous contributors and supporters.                                                      Rain City Integrative Clinic(massage and naturopathy)                                                      Sugar Plum Spa (aesthetician+waxing)                                                                                         Cafe Nordo (original,locally sourced dinner theatre)                                                                                Confrontational Theater Project (theatre)                                                                                     Id1 Clothing (independent clothing+accessories)                                                                             Retail Therapy (retail clothing, soaps, accessories,etc)                                        NEW!Comedy Birth with Danielle Gregoire  (stand up comedy)                                                                                      D'Arcy Hair Design (Hair Stylist +Colorist)                                                                                            Seattle Public Theater (theatre)                                                                                                   The Habit (sketch comedy)                                                                                             Copious Love Productions (theatre)                                                                                    Moorea Seal (curated website+handcrafted jewelry)-----------*Note: D'Arcy does not pay herself as an actor or as a producer. All $ raised is to cover the production, paying people, transaction+business fees, rights and charity.

story:
Introducing Harkins House Productions....

Ladies & Gentlemen, this is my company, Harkins House Productions (HHP). I was given the vision to start a company that will serve as the primary vehicle for my work as a playwright initially, then as it grows, groom aspiring playwrights, and stage their works as well. In addition, the company will embark into the growing indie film industry while maintaining its' theatre roots.  Also, HHP offers events with a cultural twist under the sub-brand Kulture Groove, and lastly, provides innovative services to meet the underserved needs of the Black community.

What Makes HHP So Hot....

The uniqueness of HHP is the company's committment to the rich legacy of Black theatre by tackling critical themes, offering dynamic social commentary, and discovering and grooming a new generation of Black stage actors.  In addition, HHP wants to elevate the voice and image of Black people, with a specific emphasis on Black women.  As the company grows, HHP will be utilizing technology in a major way so that its' productions are accessible with the click of a mouse. As it pertains to audiences, HHP aims to fill a void that exists between Broadway, which seldom reaches out to Black audiences, and Tyler Perry.

More About Our Main Stage Productions....

As of March of this year, Harkins House is three years old & has two successful original stageplays to its' credit, FOUR WOMEN and The Man Store.  Debuting November 2010, FOUR WOMEN is set during the '70s amidst a backdrop of rare Soul music. It's the story of four friends and neighbors living in a fictional Southern neighborhood called Moon River. Beautiful Worthy, Nola Jane Lavender, Lena Mitchell, and Delores Taylor are all dealing with deep personal issues while depending on each other for support. With its bold language and witty humor, the stage play resonated wonderfully with the three nearly sold out audiences during its run.

The Man Store debuted in May 2013 for two successful weekends. This stage play is about a scientist named Dr. Delilah Banks, who becomes the first Black woman and scientist to develop a clone in the image of Black men. Along with her daughter, Portia, Delilah opens a business that sells these newly designed Black male clones to single Black women as options for husbands. The stage play is one part satire, one part drama, and one part comedy, and it offers a unique perspective on Black love and relationships.  The Man Store is scheduled for another run during the weekend of November 22-24, 2013 in Memphis, TN.

Why HHP Needs Your Help...

While I am very proud of the company, it has a long way to go before it reaches its' pinnacle.  Harkins House is intentionally a for-profit company that specializes in indie Black theatre, meaning it is not apart of the traditional theatre circuit nor is it structured to receive grants. Funds are raised through sponsorships/advertisers and special campaigns/events (such as this one). The company was established this way to maintain artistic/creative control, fluidity in company operations, and less competition & politics while focusing primarily on promoting the work.

Therefore, I encourage all of you to support the company and its' vision.  With your help, HHP can continue its work in bringing quality productions to Memphis and the surrounding areas before expanding nationwide. 

I humbly ask you to donate a few dollars, which will be used to cover theatre rentals, set design,  wardrobe/costumes, and other operating expenses for our productions.  Every dime you donate will be used for those specific purposes and you will receive some great perks in return for your support! Take a look at the donations and select one that's most comfortable for your wallet. Whatever you give, we greatly appreciate it!

Sincerely,

Chandra Kamaria, Founder/Senior Playwright

story:
Short summary

Hello there!

I am an actress and author currently working on a site-specific piece that will be performed at 'On the Verge', a Festival for emerging artists happening in Liverpool in October. 

After training and working as an actress in France and Italy, I got into the Royal Conservatoire of Scotland (formerly RSAMD) where I had the amazing opportunity to perform at the Globe and in Beijing.

While I was there, I also directed my first devised movement based piece entitled Watch me Disappear performed in a ladies’ bathroom at the Arches in Glasgow, that touched on the issue of eating disorders and body image. I was happy to see that nobody seemed to have remained indifferent to an issue that I feel increasingly concerned about as a woman and as an artist. I would like to continue raising awareness about it and I am currently researching and developing a new piece of work that involves site-specific and physical theatre.

 

What I need

Whatever amount is raised, it will be a huge help towards:

1) Buying the props and costumes needed for the piece. And also a few umbrellas for the audience members if it happens to rain...

2) Paying the very important people who are involved in making this challenging and ambitious piece of work, including the writer/director, the performers and the editor of the sound. 

3) Marketing the show by designing and printing flyers, posters, as well as a fancy programme to guide the audience members through the piece.


The Impact

I hope this piece makes people question the notion of beauty in our society, the influence of the media, including magazines and social media, that constantly make us feel inadequate by feeding our insecurities. Most importantly, I hope it creates a dialogue about something that is secret, taboo, because of the shame involved and that it encourages those who are affected by eating disorders, or know someone who might be, to seek advice and help.


    Other ways you can help

    If you can't contribute financially, you can help in many other ways! Here are a few suggestions:

    -Like the facebook page for 'On the Verge' Festival to keep up to date with the event and invite your friends to like it too: https://www.facebook.com/onthevergeliverpool?fref=ts

    -Spread the word about the festival and the piece 'The Secret Life of Mia' and promote them on your facebook page and twitter account.

    -Befriend 'Mia' on facebook and follow her on twitter so you can share and RT her posts:

    Twitter: https://twitter.com/miaotv

    Facebook: https://www.facebook.com/miaotv

    -If you are an association offering support for people suffering from eating disorders, condemning the way women are portrayed in the media, promoting women's well being and rights etc. and you are interested in getting involved, please get in touch on facebook, twitter or by email: miaotv@hotmail.fr

    Any help you can provide, in whatever form, will be hugely appreciated.

    If you have any questions, concerns etc., feel free to contact me: miaotv@hotmail.fr

    Thank you.

story:
Help The Forum Project make creative tools to create change available to everyone who needs them. Contribute to our scholarship drive to give a deserving educator, organizer, advocate or artist the chance to create real change.


About The Forum Project

The Forum Project (TFP) uses creative tools to create change by educating individuals and communities on important social issues and providing them with tools to combat the oppressions they face. We use Theatre of the Oppressed and other creative methods to provide individuals and communities opportunities to explore and understand the world, their communities and their lives

The Forum Project changes lives!

Over the past year the Forum Project has given workshop and course scholarships worth multiple thousands of dollars to educators, advocates and artists who are working to make a difference in the world, and we need your help to keep this up!

The Forum Project strives to make creative and effective tools available to anyone regardless of ability to pay. We believe everyone should have access to creative tools to fight oppression. We provide thousands of dollars in scholarships so these tools can be available to everyone, especially people doing good work to make the world a better place! 

But we couldn't do this work without your support. If we reach our goal The Forum Project will be able to provide another 20 scholarships to deserving change-makers. 

Help us continue to make this possible by making a gift today. 

The Impact

The Forum Project is a small organization doing big work, and we continue to be a leader in Theatre of the Oppressed training. We have worked with thousands of individuals in multiple different communities in NYC and around the world. In 2013 we provided nearly 50 scholarships to educators, organizers, advocates and artists to some of our numerous trainings, workshops and classes to help give others the tools to fight oppression creatively. 

Testimonials

But don't take our word for it. Read these accounts from a few of The Forum Project's scholarship and sliding scale recipients and learn just how important this work is!

“This has been a POWERFUL experience and community that will ripple throughout my life, so I’m deeply grateful for the support and confidence that enabled me to expand so much!” —Angela, educator and scholarship recipient 

"Your support has created a transformational experience, I really appreciate what has been opened up for me in terms of opportunities as an educator and community builder. Thank you!" —Nicolette, organizer and scholarship recipient

“This work is so important to our communities—adults as well as youth. What an incredible experience. Thank you for making this Intensive workshop possible for those of us who would not otherwise be able to experience and learn; to be able to spread this work!” —Esther, educator and scholarship recipient 

Other Ways You Can Help

Spread the word! Let your communities know about this scholarship drive. 

Facebook: Give today to The Forum Project's scholarship drive to make creative tools for creating change accessible! http://bit.ly/tfpdrive

Twitter: Give today to @TheForumProject's scholarship drive to make creative tools for creating change accessible! http://bit.ly/tfpdrive

story:
The Horde Theatre Group was founded in 2012 to produce and support high quality independent theatrical productions. Comprised of actors and technicians from professional training studios across the country, we have come together to serve the evolving theatre community of Los Angeles.

We feel that The Shape of Things by Neil LaBute is an important play to be produced because it addresses the issues of inner beauty versus outer beauty and our desire to “in the eyes and standards of society” fit in.  

With your continued support of our productions, we hope to eventually reach the point where we can produce work that is completely independent, and gives back – in its self-reliance – to those who initially supported us.

 

Your money will go to many aspects of our production, including:

  • Theatre Rental
  • Reserving Rights for the Play
  • Set Construction
  • Lighting
  • Sound
  • Costumes & Props

Any money that is made – regardless of if we fall short - will go towards funding this production. Any additional money that is made will go towards funding the Horde Theatre Group’s next production. Please help us reach our goal so that we have the opportunity to give you the production in its full quality.

 

Performances:

19th, 20th, 26th, and 27th of July at 7:30 PM

21st and 28th of July at 2:00 PM.

Performances will be at the Whitmore-Lindley Theatre 11006 Magnolia Blvd, North Hollywood, CA 91601. Tickets are free!

story:
The Scoop

The North Plan is Street Corner Arts' return to the fast-paced, politically-charged world of Jason Wells, writer of their 2011 hit, Men of Tortuga.  This pitch-black comedy will have its regional premiere at Hyde Park Theatre (511 W. 43rd St.) in Austin, Texas from December 6 to December 21, 2013. Check out the "Gallery" for our show poster and (soon) bios and pics of the cast!

The North Plan tells the story of Carlton Berg, a bureaucrat for the U.S. State Department, who runs off with the top secret enemies list of a ruthless faction that has seized power in Washington creating a state of martial law.  Unfortunately for Carlton, the chase has come to an end in a police station in the Ozarks town of Lodus, Missouri. With a pair of Department of Homeland Security agents on the way, Carlton's last hope arrives in the form of fellow prisoner Tanya Shepke, a motor-mouthed redneck who's turned herself in for drunk driving and has a penchant for raising hell.

The revolution will not be televised but it will have a soundtrack: Lynyrd Skynyrd.  And it starts right now!

Street Corner Arts began with an idea (over a glass of good whiskey as all good ideas do): what if theatre could exist as a conversation between audience and actors, addressing current topics that affect the average person in an accessible way.  That is the challenge which we always place before ourselves.  By helping us to fund this project, you are becoming an active participant in that conversation.  You are allowing us to continue to present collaborative, relevant, and engaging theatre to the Austin community.


What We Need & What You Get

For this campaign, we are raising $4000 of our $8000 budget.  Here's what each giving benchmark purchases:

  • $500: the royalties for the show
  • $1250: royalties and one week of theatre rental
  • $2000: royalties and two weeks of theatre rental
  • $2750: royalties and entire production theatre rental
  • $3500: royalties, theatre rental & material costs for the set, lights and sound
  • $4000: royalties, theatre rental, material costs for the set, lights and sound & rehearsal space rental
Any funds above the designated goal will go towards the actors and designers first and foremost and, then, towards covering the rest of the production costs (marketing materials, concessions, etc.)

Street Corner Arts believes VERY STRONGLY in paying the actors and designers that kindly give of their time and energy while, oftentimes, working a second and, sometimes, even a third job.  We hire many of the most-talented professional actors and designers in the Austin area.  Your contributions will continue to make that possible.


Additionally, your gifts will entitle you to a number of perks depending upon your giving level.  Donors can receive tickets to The North Plan and even the opportunity for a pre-show cocktail party for the donor and a group of friends.  Make sure that you check out all of the different perks listed on the right.


The Impact

Unfortunately, the ticket price to our productions covers only about 30-40% of the cost of the show.  To rephrase that, theatre is a pricey endeavor.  We know that.  But we feel that it is well worth the cost.  The feedback that we have received from our 3 previously produced plays has been phenomenal.  Long after the lights have gone down on the stage, our audience members have continued to discuss the ideas and the themes of the plays---in the lobby with the cast and crew, on social media, even through emails and phone calls.  That is what is so exciting about live theatre.  The immediacy and the intimacy.  We are so grateful for your continued support and, by funding this project, you will allow the conversation to continue.


Other Ways You Can Help

Strapped for cash?  Here are some other ways that you can help us spread the word...

  • "Like" us on Facebook at: www.facebook.com/pages/Street-Corner-Arts/209035512512455
  • Share this campaign with other individuals that might have the desire and the means to give via Facebook, Twitter, or email.
  • Advertise your business in our program.
  • If you do not have the financial means, but have goods and services that you would like to donate (legal/accounting, printing, rehearsal/living space, food/drink, etc.), we would gladly accept your in-kind donation.

Thanks again for any and all help that you can send our way and we look forward to seeing you in the audience in December at Hyde Park Theatre!
story_txt:
The Scoop
The North Plan is Street Corner Arts' return to the fast-paced, politically-charged world of Jason Wells, writer of their 2011 hit, Men of Tortuga.  This pitch-black comedy will have its regional premiere at Hyde Park Theatre (511 W. 43rd St.) in Austin, Texas from December 6 to December 21, 2013. Check out the "Gallery" for our show poster and (soon) bios and pics of the cast!

The North Plan tells the story of Carlton
Berg, a bureaucrat for the U.S. State Department, who runs off with the top secret
enemies list of a ruthless faction that has seized power in Washington creating a state of martial law.  Unfortunately for Carlton, the chase has come to an end in
a police station in the Ozarks town of Lodus, Missouri. With a pair of Department of Homeland Security agents on the way, Carlton's last hope arrives in the form of fellow prisoner Tanya
Shepke, a motor-mouthed redneck who's turned herself in for drunk driving and has a penchant for raising hell.The
revolution will not be televised but it will have a soundtrack: Lynyrd
Skynyrd.  And it starts right now!Street Corner Arts began with an idea (over a glass of good whiskey as all good ideas do): what if theatre could exist as a conversation between audience and actors, addressing current topics that affect the average person in an accessible way.  That is the challenge which we always place before ourselves.  By helping us to fund this project, you are becoming an active participant in that conversation.  You are allowing us to continue to present collaborative, relevant, and engaging theatre to the Austin community.

What We Need & What You GetFor this campaign, we are raising $4000 of our $8000 budget.  Here's what each giving benchmark purchases:


$500: the royalties for the show
$1250: royalties and one week of theatre rental
$2000: royalties and two weeks of theatre rental
$2750: royalties and entire production theatre rental
$3500: royalties, theatre rental & material costs for the set, lights and sound
$4000: royalties, theatre rental, material costs for the set, lights and sound & rehearsal space rental
Any funds above the designated goal will go towards the actors and designers first and foremost and, then, towards covering the rest of the production costs (marketing materials, concessions, etc.)
Street Corner Arts believes VERY STRONGLY in paying the actors and designers that kindly give of their time and energy while, oftentimes, working a second and, sometimes, even a third job.  We hire many of the most-talented professional actors and designers in the Austin area.  Your contributions will continue to make that possible.

Other Ways You Can Help
Strapped for cash?  Here are some other ways that you can help us spread the word...


"Like" us on Facebook at: www.facebook.com/pages/Street-Corner-Arts/209035512512455

Share this campaign with other individuals that might have the desire and the means to give via Facebook, Twitter, or email.
Advertise your business in our program.
If you do not have the financial means, but have goods and services that you would like to donate (legal/accounting, printing, rehearsal/living space, food/drink, etc.), we would gladly accept your in-kind donation.


Thanks again for any and all help that you can send our way and we look forward to seeing you in the audience in December at Hyde Park Theatre!

story:
Short Summary

The All Stories Theater Company based in Massachusetts is an informal association of artists dedicated to bringing a diverse array of compelling, exciting theater to audiences in the Boston/Providence area - and beyond.

We're founded on some key ideas. One is that life is short, so don't wait around to do your art - get out there and do it!  Another is: if you're calling yourself an artist, you have a responsibility to actively contribute as one- so get out there and do it! Yet another is:  if you believe theater would benefit from this or that change --- on stage,  behind the scenes or  even in the audiences, don't just say things need to change - get out there and do it!

We believe in being proactive, in having high standards and high ideals, in a variety of voices, in community interaction.  Most of all, we believe in the indispensible value of stories.

....Yeah, we know everyone says that, but, for real, we totally do.

And, so, on August 10th and 11th, in a program of one act plays called "All Stories Are True,"  our company is going to bring in a gigantic amalgam of stories to the stage of Blackburn Hall in Walpole MA. And we're going to tell the living heck out of them.


Will you help us do this?

We are looking for some financial backing to help defray the cost of our venue, marketing, and other details. We also believe in paying artists - even just a little - and aim to give our writers, directors, and actors -- most of whom are professionals - a tiny thank you stipend for their hard work.

What We Need & What You Get

We have two major expenses: place and people. We can't do a show without both, so we think this is money well spent.

Our venue rental for the two nights will be a total of $500. Which is rather amazing....
 
We have we have seven writers to supply with a  stipend. And then there are the directors and actors, too. You know- Holly, Mark, Judith, Leeanna, Erin, Liz, Alex, Kyp, Kadian, Libby, Richie, Kristin, Mai, Sarah, Ann Marie, Chanelle, Stasia, and maybe another one or two. And perhaps a cat or a small reptile. Does anyone have a turtle? We would put about $300 into this piece of our budget....the artists, not the turtle...
 
Additional costs: printing of scripts and marketing materials, rental of basic equipment as needed (like room dividers, props, sound, etc.) will round out the last $200.
 
As you can see from our perks list, we're are offering our backers not only a chance to help with this program, but a place in our new company's  community. We don't just want your money: we want YOU. And our perks aim to lure you in. Bwahahaha.
 
Plus, you know, we do want your money.

The Impact

If you back us, you're backing the idea that artists shouldn't wait around to be artists. You're saying you believe in taking chances, being proactive, risking failure, that whole "be the change you want to see"  thing. You're backing one more shoestring company that wants to join its voice with the voices of all the other shoestring companies that make up the backbone of the world of theater. You're backing the beginning-- the beginning of our story. And you're making yourself part of it.

Other Ways You Can Help

Spread the word with social media. You have friends and followers we don't know. Reach them for us.
 
There are also tools on indiegogo that you can use to communicate with others about our campaign if you're a member of this fine site
 
Advice & Friendship. We're interested in what you have to say about theater, crowdsourcing, acting, directing, getting on the AL All Star Ballot.  We welcome the conversation!

story:
Video mapping display above by Joao Data of Datagram, one of the key collaborators for Land Without Evil.

The Story

Two years ago, Sky Candy introduced Austin to narrative-driven aerial theatre with their innovative, groundbreaking show, The Red Shoes.  Today, the company embarks upon its most ambitious project to date, their latest full-length stage show, Land Without Evil.  Sky Candy’s Artistic Director, Chelsea Laumen and seasoned producer and mastermind behind Clever Maven, Agent Red will co-direct the show that opens at the Stateside at the Paramount on Saturday, December 8th, 2012.

Adapted for stage and sky from a novel by Matthew Pallamary, the show explores the narrative of a boy's conflict between life in the Mission and the life of his dwindling tribe in their quest for Land Without Evil.  Told through aerials and acrobatics, dance, capoeira, flow arts, spoken word, ASL, and singing, this show represents the collaborative work of dozens of artists from Austin and around the globe.

Rehearsals and performance are the subject of an episode of the PBS series, Arts in Context, premiering nationally January 2013.

What We Need & What You Get


Sky Candy shows have traditionally been in alternative venues, including the ND night club and our own aerial and circus arts studio.  For this production, we have secured two weekends in one of Austin’s gorgeous, historic downtown theatres, the Stateside at the Paramount.  While venue costs typically represent less than 20% of our show budgets, we are looking at in upwards of 70% of this project’s budget going to the venue.

We feel that moving into a “real” theatre space is a huge step for us as we become an increasingly well-established and professional aerial and circus arts company.  Since Sky Candy’s inception, the support of our amazing community has been foundational in our success and we hope for your continued support as we take this huge leap towards our future.

The total production budget, including venue costs, performer payments, light rentals, set building, costumes, etc, is $26,000.  Over $18,000 of that budget ultimately goes to the venue in the form of rental fees, union labor on site, security, box office charges, and ticket fees.  The goal of $5000 we hope to make through community contributions will help us cover the theatre rental fee and any amount raised above that will go towards covering the additional items mentioned above.

Other Ways You Can Help

Help us spread the word about this project via Facebook, Twitter, or good ol’ word of mouth!  

Come see the show!  You can purchase general admission tickets here starting on Monday, October 30th.

Send out the link to this fundraiser to folks you know who would like to support Sky Candy and the further spread of the aerial arts in Central Texas.

Show Dates & Tickets

Tickets will be available through the Stateside at the Paramount's website starting on Tuesday, October 30th. These are our current showtimes (we may add additional performances based on ticket sales).

Saturday December 8 - 8pm
Sunday December 9 - 3pm & 8pm
Friday December 14 - 8pm
Saturday December 15 - 3pm & 8pm
Sunday December 16 - 3pm & 8pm

story:
xxWe are--

--a group of creative talent ready to make a movie out of William Shakespeare’s Romeo and Juliet like no one has ever seen it before; backwards. That's right. Backwards; starting out with our star crossed lover's suicides and ending with their first kiss, exploring their journey through the afterlife, being cunducted by Queen Mab, and how they share eternity together.

My name is Oliver Jones, and I'm the visionary director of this tall tall tale. You may have seen me perform most recently in Winter in Venice at the Venetian Hotel and Casino, Troll Bridge at World Con 7 at the Hyatt Hotel in Chicago, IL, Awesome 80's Prom at the Planet Hollywood Hotel and Casino, or Cannibal: the Musical at the Plaza Hotel and Casino. I've written and directed ten minute plays on the community theater level, and guest directed a one act play at the College of Southern Nevada. I also wrote the award winning play, When Mom Died on Saturn, produced by the Las Vegas Little Theater, and co-created the late night sketch comedy show, MOTHER FUPPETS.

Now, I have the opportunity bring my art to life, and I need your help!

This is how we will make a difference...

Romeo and Juliet - Queen Mab's Tale has never been done before. Ever. It's a brand new fresh take on the classic tragedy. I have added Queen Mab, a dream witch made famous from Mecutio's much debated dream monologue, into a character in the production that gallops through Romeo and Juliet's head spinning them into a web of dreams and deja vu, while being accompanied by a team of atomi, or dancers, who make up the set, the magic, and the very being of Queen Mab herself.

I want to excite the young people with art, and entertain the old with a twist. Start a new conversation! Create a trend! I can see this thing in my head, and I can't wait to show the world this crazy beautiful dream-like adaptation.

This is what we need to pay for...

Right now my bases are loaded with actors and technical designers who aren't just talented, but are some of the most passionate people I've ever known. They deserve the best:

costumes and props

marketing

film festival fees

renting locations and building sets

If all the funds aren't raised, the money will be distributed equally amongst the load.

Send us your energy!

Tell your mom about this! She probably wants to see it!

Put us in your prayers!

SHARE! Share on facebook, twitter, linkedin, and that website you're on I don't know about! Get the word out!

Talk about the trailer

Thanks!

Oliver Jones

story:
Short Summary

The People's Puppets of Occupy Wall Street is a collective of puppeteers and artists from many disciplines who pool their inspiration, energy and resources to spread Occupy Wall Street's core message of economic and social justice. Using art's unique power to envision other worlds and explore sustainable alternatives, The People's Puppets have created hundreds of puppets for Occupy gatherings and in solidarity with allied organizations, community groups, and unions since October 2011. 

Jack and the Corporate Beanstalk is our latest outreach attempt to educate and excite the 99% about taking back power from the 1%.  A workshop version was performed  at the Greenpoint Theatre Festival & the full length version wil premiere at The NYC International Fringe Festival during August as well as at Bread and Puppet Theater in Septemebr, and many street corners throughout New York City.


Summary: Out of work Jack goes to college to get some magic beans and grow a beanstalk to visit the Giant Job Creator in the sky -but once Jack is saddled with debt they're still at the mercy of the Corporate Giant! In this puppet music spectacle, the audience has to get involved and help Jack take back the Golden Goose for the 99%!

What We Need & What You Get

The $1000 covers rent for the several months we've been working on this project, materials and building supplies for the puppets and set pieces, and storage space and transportation of large puppets and set pieces.  We have maintained a multi-use art space for the last 10 months opening our doors to hundreds of artists, activists, and other members of the community.  Any money we raise beyond our goal will help us keep the doors open to our art studio that much longer. 

The Impact

We live in a time where economic injustice and its social and environmental impact have reached a point where we have no choice but to reorganize ourselves around new principles of transparency, horizontalism, and mutual aid.  We hope this show will help spread that message, and encourage more citizens to become actively engaged in discussing the many problems facing our society, and being part of the soliutions to these problems.

To this end, we have invited members of community organizations and Occupy groups to be in the final song of our performance so that the audience can talk more with people from groups like: Center for Progrssive Economics, the IWW, Alternative Banking Working Group, and others.

Performances

Please come see us perform Jack and the Corporate Beanstalk this August!  And spread the word!

http://www.facebook.com/events/382060955193543/

and follow us on twitter!  power2thepuppet

NYC International Fringe Festival 

Sat Aug18th, Sun Aug 19th, Sat Aug 25th, Sun Aug 26th 
at 1pm @ East 4th St between Bowery and 2nd Ave
http://www.fringenyc.org/index.php/about-us/fringeal-fresco

story:
The classic tale of a boy in a TARDIS t-shirt standing in front of a girl dressed as the Fifth Doctor, asking her to love him... and a girl demanding to know why she can’t be the Doctor or Han Solo or Captain Reynolds. They’d be star-crossed lovers (Wars and Trek, obviously) but they have so much in common - surely they can find the time and space to fall in love? This is a story about wanting to feel safe, to be appreciated and how far we’ll go to find people like us.

 

Who Are You Supposed To Be? is our love letter to being a fan of movies and television, a fan of science fiction and fantasy, a fan of being who you are and sometimes pretending you’re somebody else just for the hell of it.

And we’re taking it to Edinburgh Fringe.

We need your help to make it the best show we can.

These characters are fans of Doctor Who, but this is a universal story of two people meeting – two people from other sides of the world finding out they have so much in common, but can’t agree on who would win in a fight between Batman and Captain America.

 

This fundraiser is to help with three things:

  1. Venue hire – we’ve got a great space at C Venues, one of the largest hubs of theatre and new writing at the Edinburgh Fringe. But being in such a great space requires a little bit of money.
  2. Publicity – we’ve got a great show, with a great hook. Fans of anything or everything will love this show, but we need to tell people about it. We need posters and postcards. Flyers and programmes.
  3. Costumes – we have a couple of particular costumes that we need to get absolutely right. If you’ve ever been to a Convention, you know how good the costumes are. In particular, our main character is dressed as the Fifth Doctor throughout the show. We want to get that costume as close to perfect as possible. The shows hinges on this costume being as close to perfect as possible. Plus, there's a costume that appears in the final scene that also needs that attention to detail, but... spoilers!

And that’s it. We’re going to Edinburgh – and we want to make the show as amazing as we can. Because the better the show is in Edinburgh – it’s a World Premiere – the more opportunity we’ll get to tour the show.

Star Jennifer Lusk will be back in Australia in 2014, and plans are afoot for the Melbourne and Adelaide Fringe festivals – but if we raise over and above our goal, a few more dates in London and the UK over the next twelve months is entirely possible. And it will help Binkaboo Productions get a running start on those Aussie festivals in the next couple of years.

So, if you can't be or won't be in Edinburgh, your donation will help make sure we can bring the show to you.

Check out the rewards we have for you - messages from Edinburgh, signed posters, an annotated version of the script with commentary from the entire team, free tickets for Edinburgh (and 2-for-1 specials when we tour near you). Any generosity will be much appreciated and rewarded as best we can - including our eternal gratitude.

And if the Doctor can tell you anything, eternity is a long time. Thank you!

 

What was that? You'd like to know a little bit more about us? Ok!

Binka Boo Productions was created in 2006 by Jennifer Lusk, in order to create and perform independent theatre as a platform for independent artists.  BBP’s first production, Fitting Rooms, was also Lusk’s debut script, and was performed at both the Adelaide and Melbourne Fringe Festivals, with a sell out Adelaide season. In 2009, BBP staged the award winning play, A View of Concrete by young Victorian playwright, Gareth Ellis, at the iconic Queen’s Theatre, again as part of the Adelaide Fringe Festival.  In 2012, Lusk developed her short story, Photographing The Dead, into a one-woman show with preview perfomances at development stage in Melbourne and two preview shows in London, before premiering at Paradise in the Vaults during the Edinburgh Festival Fringe. BBP is a privately funded profit-share company, with energetic and enthusiastic contributors from the independent theatre scene across Adelaide and Melbourne, and now London.

Jennifer Lusk (producer/performer) graduated from the Flinders University Drama Centre in 2004. She has been present on the independent theatre scene across Adelaide and Melbourne, performing her own work, with her own company, and for other co-ops. Apart from BBP's shows, she has also played Titania for Green Cyc’s outdoor production of A Midsummer Night’s Dream and performed at the Malthouse with CEL productions’ Love Victoria. She has also appeared in a number of Short Films, including Fancy, with Liam McIntyre, and has been repeatedly involved in the Short and Sweet Festival in Melbourne, as a writer, a performer and a director.

Keith Gow (writer) is an active playwright and theatre-maker on the Melbourne independent theatre scene. His short plays have been performed across Australia and in South East Asia. With several Short & Sweet Theatre festivals under his belt (Melbourne, Sydney, Malaysia), he has also mounted his one-man show, Richard Di Gregorio: On Time, at both the Melbourne and Adelaide Fringe festivals. After co-founding "The Wooden Leg" theatre company in 2011, Keith has produced two successful seasons of short plays in non-traditional theatre venues, as well as developed his short play Eight Minutes for Short & Sweet Melbourne 2012. His most acclaimed work, Painting with Words & Fire, was produced at Revolt Art Space in Kensington in February 2012. In August, the play received a one-night only reading at Primary Stages in New York City.

Emrys Matthews (director) is from Oxford, and he trained in Acting at the Liverpool Institute for Performing Arts (LIPA). Directing credits include: Twelfth Night (The Dell, Stratford Upon Avon), Our Finest Hour (Paul McCartney Auditorium, Liverpool), Macbeth (The Dell, Stratford Upon Avon), Jon and Jen (Sennheiser Studio Theatre, Liverpool), Macbeth (Jaqueline Du Pre, Oxford). Emrys also runs his own Doctor Who blog called "Wonderings In The Fourth Dimension". Emrys' favourite Doctor is Jon Pertwee.

Cameron K. McEwan (performer), otherwise known as "Blogtor Who", cuts an impressive figure on the Doctor Who fan scene and is currently writing a book about the cult show. He will be appearing as Feste in Twelfth Night for Play the Fool as part of the RSC's open air free Shakespeare season. This year, he has also starred in the comedy web series PanCam, in the video sequences of Wireless Theatre Company's transmedia alien invasion epic, Dead London and also in the upcoming British indie flick Love.Honour.Obey. He has also hosted and moderated panels at various science-fiction conventions across Europe with guests such as Matt Smith, David Tennant, Billie Piper, Catherine Tate and Karen Gillan. Cameron also writes reviews, lists and comment for Den of Geek, Cult Box and The Huffington Post. He currently lives in London, with his three trousers.
story_txt:
The classic tale of a boy in a TARDIS t-shirt standing in front of a girl dressed as the Fifth Doctor, asking her to love him... and a girl demanding to know why she can’t be the Doctor or Han Solo or Captain Reynolds. They’d be star-crossed lovers (Wars and Trek, obviously) but they have so much in common - surely they can find the time and space to fall in love? This is a story about wanting to feel safe, to be appreciated and how far we’ll go to find people like us.

 
Who Are You Supposed To Be? is our love letter to being a fan of movies and television, a fan of science fiction and fantasy, a fan of being who you are and sometimes pretending you’re somebody else just for the hell of it.
And we’re taking it to Edinburgh Fringe.
We need your help to make it the best show we can.
These characters are fans of Doctor Who, but this is a universal story of two people meeting – two people from other sides of the world finding out they have so much in common, but can’t agree on who would win in a fight between Batman and Captain America.
 

This fundraiser is to help with three things:


Venue hire – we’ve got a great space at C Venues, one of the largest hubs of theatre and new writing at the Edinburgh Fringe. But being in such a great space requires a little bit of money.

Publicity – we’ve got a great show, with a great hook. Fans of anything or everything will love this show, but we need to tell people about it. We need posters and postcards. Flyers and programmes.

Costumes – we have a couple of particular costumes that we need to get absolutely right. If you’ve ever been to a Convention, you know how good the costumes are. In particular, our main character is dressed as the Fifth Doctor throughout the show. We want to get that costume as close to perfect as possible. The shows hinges on this costume being as close to perfect as possible. Plus, there's a costume that appears in the final scene that also needs that attention to detail, but... spoilers!
And that’s it. We’re going to Edinburgh – and we want to make the show as amazing as we can. Because the better the show is in Edinburgh – it’s a World Premiere – the more opportunity we’ll get to tour the show.
Star Jennifer Lusk will be back in Australia in 2014, and plans are afoot for the Melbourne and Adelaide Fringe festivals – but if we raise over and above our goal, a few more dates in London and the UK over the next twelve months is entirely possible. And it will help Binkaboo Productions get a running start on those Aussie festivals in the next couple of years.
So, if you can't be or won't be in Edinburgh, your donation will help make sure we can bring the show to you.
Check out the rewards we have for you - messages from Edinburgh, signed posters, an annotated version of the script with commentary from the entire team, free tickets for Edinburgh (and 2-for-1 specials when we tour near you). Any generosity will be much appreciated and rewarded as best we can - including our eternal gratitude.
And if the Doctor can tell you anything, eternity is a long time. Thank you!

She has also appeared in a number of Short Films, including Fancy, with Liam McIntyre, and has been repeatedly involved in the Short and Sweet Festival in Melbourne, as a writer, a performer and a director.

With several Short & Sweet Theatre festivals under his belt (Melbourne, Sydney, Malaysia), he has also mounted his one-man show, Richard Di Gregorio: On Time, at both the Melbourne and Adelaide Fringe festivals. story:
Zombies.  A garage.  A once in a lifetime Portland theatrical experience.  

We are producing the Pacific Northwest premiere of the thrilling play The Revenants by Scott T. Barsotti.  Instead of producing this play in a large theatre we decided to do it in the actual setting - a basement garage.  This thrusts the audience immediately into the world of the play.  While this will be a terrific experience for the 25 audience members we can accommodate a night - those sales will not cover our costs.  We don't want to compromise vision for the bottom line.  We want to give Portland a thrilling, intelligent alternative to the haunted house this fall.  We have some terrific artists that will help realize this world, and frankly, they deserve to be paid.  That's why we're coming to you.

Where's the money going?

The entire budget for this production is $9000.  If this show sold out every night of its run we would cover just over half of the budget.  We are asking you for the half that will NOT be covered by ticket sales.  We still have to sell out each night and raise all our money in order to just break even.  Our budget will cover lighting and sound equipment rental and acquisition, set work, makeup and effects.  Again - this play is right in the audiences face.  It needs to look real.

It's simple - our goal is to break even.  We the producers won't make any money on this show - we just want to make sure we can keep bringing this type of innovative work to Portland theatre.

What else can you do?

We are seeking a variety of chairs for the audience.  If you have anything you wouldn't mind sharing with us for a month, let us know.

Share this event with as many people as you can.  Word of mouth is by far the biggest draw.  Come to the show - bring your friends.  Get your tickets here.

story:
Meet Vincent DiDonato (Lou Martini, Jr.), the single, lonely and reluctant new owner of CENTENNIAL CASTING, a metal-casting shop in downtown New York City.  The business was started by Vincent's mother and now, after her unexpected death, it is his.

While cleaning out his mother's office, he stumbles across a stack of head-shots from eager actors submitting photos for what they mistakenly assume is an “entertainment-casting” office.  Struck by the photo of one down-on-her-luck actress, Edie Keaton (Alicia Harding), Vincent is convinced by his best friend and foreman Doo Doo (Anthony Patellis), to pretend to be a casting director in order to meet the young lady.

The metal-shop is converted into a professional casting office, Edie arrives for an “interview” and sparks fly as Vincent begins living a hilarious double life of show business and sheet metal, only to realize that this elaborate ruse is jeopardizing any chance of truly winning Edie’s love. Waist-deep in deception, Vincent struggles to find a way to reveal the truth to Edie without losing her forever. A heart-warming, hilarious romantic comedy, filled with twists and turns, catharsis and cannolis, this is the story of two ordinary people in an extraordinary situation who find dreams can come true, at CENTENNIAL CASTING.

____________________________________________

CENTENNIAL CASTING

Written by Gino DiIorio and Nancy Bleemer
Directed by Alice Jankell
Featuring  Lou Martini, Jr.  •  Alicia Harding  •  Anthony Patellis

Janine Molinari  •  Charles Gould

___________________________________________________________________


Can you help

bring this show to

New York City for a

May 1st opening?


CENTENNIAL CASTING has had a number of regional productions and most recently a NYC workshop at the Triad. All have been greatly received! We have been highly encouraged to take this play to the next level and produce a top notch quality run in NYC.

We've assembled an amazing creative and technical team, along with our talented cast of actors, but we now need the support of all of our family and friends to make this wonderful show a reality. 

With the funds raised here, we will be covering all our production costs, including rehearsal space, theater rental, sound and lighting design, set design, publicity and staffing. 

Our passion for this play is undeniable and we are certain you'll love it too! We look forward to sharing this hilarious, heartwarming piece of theater with you all. 

Thank you for your support!


“A fast paced romantic comedy built on a funny premise”. – The Journal News

“In these times of war, higher taxes, higher gasoline prices and other troubles, we need a lot of laughs. And you will be laughing a lot when you see the new comedy Centennial Casting at Penguin Rep in Stony Point” — Rockland County Times

“An excellent comedy of mistaken identities in the Shakespearean tradition” — Times Herald Record

“Centennial Casting” is a laugh-a-minute comedy that will lift just about anyone out of the winter blahs....This not-to-be missed comedy is a real pick-me-upper" - Waterbury Republican

story:
About MoCo Dance Alliance!

MoCo Dance Alliance, a modern dance company founded by Alexandra Schools in 2015 has recently been accepted in the Capital Fringe Festival in Washington, D.C. MoCo Dance Alliance strives to bring the power of physical and mental strength to audiences in the local communities through movement. MDA would also like to give the opportunity for developing professionals to perform as well as create new artistic ideas.

MoCo Dance Alliance will present Perception at the Capital Fringe Festival in the summer of 2016. Through movement, we will explore how the senses react when one is missing . Dancers will switch through the senses of hearing, sight, and touch. 

Current Company Members:

Tiffani Thomas

Jamie Doughty

Kristin King

Michelle Kuah


What is Capital Fringe Festival?

"For 22 days every July and into August, the annual Capital Fringe Festival creates a city filled with non-stop theatre, dance, music, visual art, and everything in-between. Audiences enjoy non-stop, creative experiences and artists develop their artistic visions in total freedom without any curatorial barriers. Our city is enriched as art takes over neighborhoods, animating the spaces — from traditional theaters, to corner bars, to vacant storefronts" 

"Connected over 40,000 adventurous audiences (half of whom are between the ages of 25-54) to 5,000 exploratory artists; and sold 40,000 tickets to the Fringe Festival and ticketed productions at the Logan Fringe Arts Space. "

- www.capitalfringe.org


What will your donation do for MoCo Dance Alliance!?

$585.00- Participation Fee ( THREE shows in July of 2016).
$265.00- Costumes, Insurance, Tech Crew.

Any donation amount will help MoCo Dance Alliance reach their goal. Please help us participate in this amazing D.C event!

Don't forget to check us out on Facebook.

Thank you!!!!
MocoDanceAlliance@gmail.com

story:
Over the past 6 months we have been devising and rehearsing our original show ‘The Sandman’. We performed our piece at university for our final graduate showcase and after receiving exceptional grades and incredible feedback we decided we wanted to see how far we could take the project. With your support we want to take our show to the Edinburgh fringe this August. Although we have been able to create the show itself with no funds we have had to find as many creative ways to help pay for our trip as possible. We have taken a business course on the side of our studies to win funding and we pitched our idea to a room of corporate business students in the form of an accapella song to help pay for initial venue costs. This campaign is the final push to raise the last bit of money we need to make this dream happen.

Why us?

Shindig (noun) - A large and lively party.

Shindig theatre company, comprising of three emerging artists who met at university and have been annoying each other ever since. As a company, we like to focus on the magic involved in storytelling and putting the play back into performing. We are not ones to use smoke and mirrors to create magic, but rather create a 'large and lively party' with as little as two chairs and a coat stand.

The company's roots are spread out over the country from Plymouth to Billericay. It took several Long Island ice teas, karaoke and some embarrassing photos for us to decide that we were going to join forces and actually hit this hard and make our own opportunities.  Since then, we have spent months finding out what makes us fresh and different. And of course, there have been a few more iced teas along the way.

How will we spend your money?

Thanks to the support of London Southbank university and their resources we have been able to create the show itself with practically no money at all. However, having a show isn’t enough to get you to Edinburgh from London for a week. We are able to fund some of the expenses ourselves but need some extra funds to help make the show a success.

Insurance £100 – To perform a show at the fringe our venue requires us to purchase public liability insurance for the duration of our time there. Although not an obvious cost it is essential to make sure us and our audience are safe and covered in case of any unexpected accidents. Our show doesn’t pose a risk to anybody so like most insurance it’s used as a precaution. However, without it we could have to pay a lot more to settle any incidents.

Marketing £95 – As anyone who has been to the fringe before knows putting up posters and flyering is a really important and effective way of getting people into your show. We will find other ways of selling tickets that don’t cost us but still need some materials printed.

Transport £300 – The venue and accommodation is all booked, however getting to and from Edinburgh is another expense that we are struggling to find the money for and it is far more expensive than we had anticipated. This is probably the most important thing to fund as without us there is no show.

Upgrade costume and set £100 – We have generously been able to use the set and costume that we found in the store cupboards at university. However, now we are taking the show to a professional venue there are some items that we have compromised on down to money. If given the opportunity, we would love to be able to invest in the design aspects to help make our show look more professional and in turn sell more tickets.

If for some incredible reason we have money left over or make more than the target, there are still lots of things we could use the money for to make our show bigger and better. We would put it towards outstanding venue costs, accommodation and perhaps even being able to pay or buy gifts for the people that have volunteered to help us make this dream possible.   

Perks

Please see our range of perks where you can be rewarded for supporting our campaign. These include digital version of our artwork and script, A recording of our show and even the chance to be taken out for dinner by us. 

*Please note our show runs from the 21st - 26th of August 2017 at 9.10pm at the Space on the mile, Edinburgh. Perks including complimentary tickets are for these shows only. 

 

We understand that not all of you will be able to donate but any support for our project would mean a lot to us. If you know anyone going to the Edinburgh fringe this year make sure you tell them about our show.

If you are in Edinburgh this summer and don't wish to donate but would like to see our show you can by tickets here https://tickets.edfringe.com/whats-on/sandman

And finally social media is the best way to spread the word so please follow us on instagram and twitter (@shindigtheatre) and like us on facebook (www.facebook.com/shindigtheatre/). Share with your friends and help us make this show a success.

Thank you,

Holly Stringer, Tom Davis and Jacob Adams (Shindig Theatre).

This is probably the most important thing to fund as without us there is no show.Upgrade costume and set £100 – We have generously been able to use the set and costume that we found in the store cupboards at university. However, now we are taking the show to a professional venue there are some items that we have compromised on down to money. If given the opportunity, we would love to be able to invest in the design aspects to help make our show look more professional and in turn sell more tickets.If for some incredible reason we have money left over or make more than the target, there are still lots of things we could use the money for to make our show bigger and better. We would put it towards outstanding venue costs, accommodation and perhaps even being able to pay or buy gifts for the people that have volunteered to help us make this dream possible.   PerksPlease see our range of perks where you can be rewarded for supporting our campaign. These include digital version of our artwork and script, A recording of our show and even the chance to be taken out for dinner by us. *Please note our show runs from the 21st - 26th of August 2017 at 9.10pm at the Space on the mile, Edinburgh. Perks including complimentary tickets are for these shows only.  We understand that not all of you will be able to donate but any support for our project would mean a lot to us. If you know anyone going to the Edinburgh fringe this year make sure you tell them about our show.If you are in Edinburgh this summer and don't wish to donate but would like to see our show you can by tickets here https://tickets.edfringe.com/whats-on/sandmanAnd finally social media is the best way to spread the word so please follow us on instagram and twitter (@shindigtheatre) and like us on facebook (www.facebook.com/shindigtheatre/). Share with your friends and help us make this show a success.Thank you,Holly Stringer, Tom Davis and Jacob Adams (Shindig Theatre).

story:
HI, my name is Shira Robbins. I am the creator of LifeDance. I have danced all my life, starting in a ballet class, going into modern and Jazz classes. I did it every  day with amazing passion. When I was 18 I went into the Israeli army and neglected the world of dancing. Later studied Medicine got married and had children. Along the years dance for me had become a sweet dream...I needed somethig dramatic to lead me back to that world.


  • How did it all start?

Five years ago I got a divorce and felt that my world had collapsed. In order to feel happy and alive again I went back to dancing. It saved my life!

It was then that I realized that many women, non professional dancers have so little dance programs, where they can dance for theirselves. So a new idea was born! A dance class for lay women that include technique from 10 different styles around the world, improvisation and free style! All of these combine- physical, emotional and mind aspects from every culture. The class is on going so the women don't feel they fail. the ages of the women that come to dance are 18-99...and they all dance in the same class.

As this program continued I had realized that something amazing happened! Women from all over the world, that don't speak the same language, found a common way to communicate in that classroom, through their body, love and passion. At that point I went back to the academy, this time to train more instructors.



  • 28th of March! 

On the 28th of March we will be celebrating the women's international month.

We will dance on one of the highest roofs of Israel, under the boundless sky! We will have Jewish, Christians and Muslims dancing together, sweating, laughing, and moving together to the same amazing music.

This program is unique. We want every woman to be able to dance. That way they can stay fit, be happy, creative, empowered, feel feminine, be less stressful, feel they can dance in an environment that is non judgmental or criticizing. To give the feeling that dancing is not for dancers only! And yes...it's never to late.

In that classroom we are all one!


  • What will the money go for?
But... not everybody can afford it!

Your help and support to this project, will enable us to get to many more women, and to train them to be instructors. We will then be able to send these instructors to those women who will benefit the most, like Single mothers, shelters for abused women, low social economic areas, disabled women and more!

Your contribution is the only way our project can be executed, and that means a lot to us!


We appreciate your time and support!

With gratitude,
Shira Robbins and LifeDance team.

story:
A captivating evening at the 'Zoo'

More than 50 years after writing The Zoo Story, Edward Albee wrote a prequel to his classic entitled Home Life. Now the first act of Albee's At Home at the Zoo, Home Life contains the events in Peter's life immediately preceding his encounter with Jerry on the park bench in The Zoo Story(now the second act of the complete work). We meet Peter's wife Ann, and witness the conversation that compelled Peter to go for that fateful walk in the park.

This production is my graduate thesis for the Savannah College of Art and Design, as part of the requirements for my Masters in Arts Administration. Your support of the arts and higher education is greatly appreciated!

Wondering where your donation goes?

Producing a play requires payment of royalties, rehearsal and theatre rental, stipends to the creative team [Director, Stage Manager, Actors, Designers], plus props, costumes, music, lights, and box office expenses! Although all of these costs add up quickly, every dollar counts- so no matter the size, your donation will help us put on a great show!

Creative Team

Samantha McManus [Producer] has a BFA in Performance and is currently a graduate student at the Savannah College of Art and Design. She has previously worked with the Alley Theatre, Main Street Theater, and Houston Grand Opera. Samantha is the Founder and Executive Directer of Firecracker Productions.

Mark McManus [Director] has a BA in Theatre and Political Science and is currently a high school theatre teacher and Houston based director.

Kevin Zahradnik [Stage Manager] has a BA in Theatre and is a former American College Theatre Festival Stage Management Fellow. He previously worked as a Stage Manager for Main Street Theater and currently teaches high school theatre.

Blake Weir [Peter] has a BFA in Theatre and is a Houston based actor. He was formerly a resident company member at AD Players, and was recently seen in productions with Unity Theatre and Black Lab Theatre Company.

Arianna Bermudez [Ann] has a BA in Theatre and RTF and is a Houston based actress. She has worked with Mildred's Umbrella, Classical Theatre Company, Alley Theatre, and Phoenix Theatre, among others.

Allen Titel [Jerry] has a BA in Theatre and Psychology and is a Houston based actor. He was recently seen in shows with Pearl Theatre and Big Head Productions.

story:
Short Summary

Actors International Theatre's vision is Every voice is Heard and Listened to in a Powerful Way through Theater.  Our mission is Employing Actors with disabilities and give them the opportunity to experience the transforming power of theater and alter the global & personal perception of limitations. Anything is possible and we all have a voice!  

Hello, I am  Katherine Filer and the founder and president of Actors International Theatre.  This is our second play directed by our fabulous, Kathe Mull from New York City. This is just the beginning of a journey that leads to Fun, Freedom, Power and Full Self Expression for everyone right now... I don't know what it looks like and I have created this context to live the rest of my life inside of accomplishing it.  Find your VOICE ~ Find your POWER, NOW!!!


What We Need & What You Get

This specific campaign will be used to put on the World Premiere Presentation of 'The Absolutely, Positively, Forget-About-It, Last Night at Von Damh's Sports Bar, Wing Hut and Karaoke Palace!'  Written by Sean Grennan and Directed by Kathe Mull. Featured are 3 people who stutter, Sue Camlin, Gary Auker and Katherine Filer.  This is gonna be FUN!!! Why, because "it's a comedy"!  And there is lots of singing!!!

It's the last night before the closing of "Von Dahm's Sports Bar, Wing Hut and Karaoke Palace" the oldest tavern in the tri-state area, (you could look it up!).  Three old acquaintances meet up to rehash the past, stare down the present, and face the future.  Drinks flow, karaoke is sung and old issues are trotted out, thrown out and mostly worked out.  The final battle comes down to hipster gentrification vs. the kind of authenticity you can't buy at freakin' Restoration Hardware.  Who will win?  Who knows?  Who's askin'?  Have a drink, turn off your precious "Smartphone" and watch "The Absolutely...!

This WORLD PREMIERE PRESENTATION will be at the Philadelphia Fringe Festival at the Shubin Theater at 407 Bainbridge Ave in Philadelphia, PA

Saturday, September 13th at 7pm

Sunday, September 14th at 3pm

Monday, September 15th at 7pm

The running time is 60 minutes, with a 20 minute talk back immediately following.

TICKETS WILL BE AVAILABLE AUGUST 1, 2014!!

All donations with this campaign will be used to create and present this World Premier presentation for all three shows.

All the perks associated with your donation will be around the production of the play and are guaranteed to be FUN!  Even the names of the perks are part of the play.

One perk is to attend the Von Damh's Karaoke Cast Party at the theater on the last night, following the performance from 5-8pm.

If you have any questions please feel free to contact me at: actorsinternationaltheatre@gmail.com


The Impact

This project is valuable to you the contributor and to the world.  Just imagine what is possible if each and every voice in the world can express their unique contribution right now.  Who can you then be?  What is then available to you and your family & friends?

Our first production was "Tough Cookies" presented in New York City, off-off Broadway.  Featured in this play were 3 women who have stuttered all their life.  It was a huge success and the opportunity of a lifetime for these women.  One of the reviews "Tough Cookies" got at the 2013 Philadelphia Fringe Festival was "....don't show up expecting actors who stutter; come expecting actors who act." 

We will be adding photos and video clips as we rehearsal and move forward. So check in and see where we are in the process.


Other Ways You Can Help

If you can't make a contribution to this campaign, please get the word out and make some noise about it.  Share the link Facebook, Twitter, etc.  and tell all your friends about this amazing opportunity.  Indiegogo has share tools for you to use to achieve this!!

story:
This one-hour re-envisioning of Anton Chekhov's classic work delves into the heart and mind of Constantin, a young writer seeking new forms of artistic expression. Constantin struggles with the forms of commercial art embodied by his famous actress mother, Arkadina, and her lover, the renowned writer Trigorin. This fresh take on a classic play poses the vital question: is the value of art purely commercial or can an intrinsic visceral value also exist?


   Cooperative Performance Milwaukee is excited to open our first full season with The Seagull! This version is adapted and directed by Founding Member Don Russell and features a talented cast and creative team of 16 local artists who help to bring this expressionist take on the classic play to life.

As a new company beginning our first full season, Cooperative Performance Milwaukee needs your help in funding this production. This campaign covers the cost of rehearsal and performance space rental, stage props, and marketing and publicity costs.


We are fortunate to have the backing of the strong arts community in Milwaukee. This is evidenced by results of the crowd funding of our debut production of Hamlet, which gained 120% of its funding goal, making it one of the most successful theater-funding campaigns in the area. We are confident that together we can build on and exceed those results for The Seagull!

We want to involve the Milwaukee community in the artist process, as outlined by our mission statement.

"We strive to maintain a dynamic, cooperative community founded on direct, ongoing dialogue between artists and audience. This organization is committed to providing space for innovative works of art and technologies to be conceived, tested, and developed for the purpose of contributing extraordinary performance to the local, regional, national and global community. "

For more information please visit: www. cooperformke.com


Volunteer Opportunities

We understand that not everyone has immediate funds available, but if you'd like to support us with your time, we have need for volunteers to assist with concessions and front of house duties at each of the performances of The Seagull! If interested, please email info@cooperformke.com with the subject "Seagull Volunteer" for more details.


Thank you so much for your support of Cooperative Performance Milwaukee, and the arts!

story:
Why you should donate!

YA4Ever is a theatre company created by the alumni of The Young Artist's Ensemble based out of Thousand Oaks, California. YA4Ever needs YOUR help to put its latest production on stage! 

We have been putting on fantastic shows since 2012. You may have seen or heard about the success of our past productions, such as: Spring Awakening, Rent, The Last 5 Years, Godspell, Into the Woods, The Rocky Horror Show, and Urinetown! We are a nonprofit theatre company, run completely by the alumni of YAE. We are using these amazing production opportunities to learn and experience different sides of live theatre. Through our success we have brought sold out audiences into theatre experiences they will never forget.

Fair is Foul

YA4Ever's latest production endeavor is Fair is Foul, an immersive play inspired by New York's Sleep No More (pictured below). 

Photo from Forbes.com 
Sleep No More is an immersive show that ran in New York City, based on the Shakespeare play Macbeth. YA4Ever is excited to bring its audience along on this thrilling ride through the decadence of the 1920's filled with lust, witchcraft, deception, and murder. Audience members will travel through the Hillcrest Center for The Arts in Thousand Oaks and step back in time to watch this renowned tale come to life. Enter the show through our Jazz Bar where you will be told the rules of the night and put on your masks, audience members are told to refrain from speaking as they start their journey into the world of Fair is Foul. You can travel freely throughout the many rooms of our mansion and follow the different stories unfolding within them. Audiences can always return to our Jazz Bar to relax with a drink and a song whenever they'd like. You have never seen anything like this before so be sure to buy your tickets now!

We Need YOU!

In order for YA4Ever to fully immerse its audience members in the Fair is Foul world we need YOUR help! Sets, lighting, costumes, and more are ESSENTIAL to take audience members on the journey of a lifetime! We are hoping to raise $1,000 by July 20th and we won't be able to do it without our supporters, friends and family. Donate anything you can, any amount is more than appreciated. We love our supporters and want to give them the best theatre experiences possible. Help us bring this spectacle to Thousand Oaks, we guarantee you won't be disappointed!

After you donate please make sure to share this IndieGoGo campaign on social media! Don't forget to like our Facebook page and follow us on Instagram and Twitter @WeAreYA4Ever for the latest news about YA4Ever and the production of Fair is Foul.

https://www.facebook.com/yaeforever1

Other Ways You Can Help

If you cannot donate but would like to see the show you can visit our website for more information. Performances are a limited engagement! July 25th and 26th at 8 PM! TICKETS ARE ON SALE NOW!

http://www.hillcrestarts.com/show_info.php?show_id=43

story:
Short Summary

Contributors fund ideas they can be passionate about and to people they trust. Here are some things to do in this section:

  • Introduce yourself and your background.
  • Briefly describe your campaign and why it's important to you.
  • Express the magnitude of what contributors will help you achieve.

Remember, keep it concise, yet personal. Ask yourself: if someone stopped reading here would they be ready to make a contribution?

What We Need & What You Get

Break it down for folks in more detail:

  • Explain how much funding you need and where it's going. Be transparent and specific-people need to trust you to want to fund you.
  • Tell people about your unique perks. Get them excited!
  • Describe where the funds go if you don't reach your entire goal.

The Impact

Feel free to explain more about your campaign and let people know the difference their contribution will make:

  • Explain why your project is valuable to the contributor and to the world.
  • Point out your successful track record with projects like this (if you have one).
  • Make it real for people and build trust.

Risks & Challenges

People value your transparency. Be open and stand out by providing insight into the risks and obstacles you may face on the way to achieving your goal.

  • Share what qualifies you to overcome these hurdles.
  • Describe your plan for solving these challenges.

Other Ways You Can Help

Some people just can't contribute, but that doesn't mean they can't help:

  • Ask folks to get the word out and make some noise about your campaign.
  • Remind them to use the Indiegogo share tools!

And that's all there is to it.

story:
Short Summary

The Village Playwrights was founded over 30 years ago and is New York City's longest standing LGBTQ play writing group.  It was founded to create a place where LGBTQ playwrights could have their plays read in a supportive environment.   The group meets to read plays the second and fourth Wednesday of the month at the LGBT Community Center in New York's West Village. There is no charge to the playwrights.  In 2014 the Gay Holiday Short Play Reading Festival was started.  The Village Playwrights Intensive Play Writing, a 12 hour course that teaches play structure, was offered in 2016.  And we have produced group productions of our writers' short plays.

What We Need & What You Get

Because we don't charge the playwrights to have their plays read, we rely on donations to cover our costs.  The LGBT Community Center has recently doubled our rental fee.  In the past we were able to cover our costs from the optional donations given by playwrights attending our meetings.  We now find, with the rising rent, we will need to seek additional funds.  $500 will pay for 2 months of meetings at the LGBT Community Center.

    The Impact

    New York City used to be the place to learn the craft of play writing.  But the cost of space is challenging the ability of playwrights to produce and develop their works.  This is unfortunate because the city offers a large and vibrant audience base that playswrights need to develop their works.  Your donation, no matter how small, will help the Village Playwrights continue serving New York City playwrights.

      Risks & Challenges

      One of the biggest challenges of doing theater is finding an audience.  We have an advantage of being the only LGBTQ playwriting group in New York City and have the potential of drawing a large audience to our events.  To achieve this, however, we need to improve our visibility.  It is our hope that this IndieGoGo campaign will help not only to raise money but also let people know how we serve the LGBTQ community.  

        Other Ways You Can Help

        Help us by being an audience member at our bimonthly meetings, 8 pm the second and fourth Wednesday of the month at the LGBT Community Center, 208 W. 13th St., NYC.  It's a great way to see professional actors in plays that are relevant to modern LGBTQ audiences.
