story:
Meet The Director

Hello! My name is Michael J. Terebush. I am currently a senior at Ramapo College of New Jersey. I have directed several shows both within and outside of Ramapo College. I have come to direct shows with three things at the forefront: what is the  essence of the show? How do I want the audience to experience the show? How can I combine those two things to make it cohesive? 

With your help, all of the members of the Damascena NY Performing Ensemble will be able to put on a show at The Alchemical Theatre Laboratory with the multimedia that it needs to succeed.  

What We Need & What You Get

In order to produce this play the Damascena NY Performing Ensemble, asks that you donate generously. Here's where your money is going:

  • Venue - $1500
  • Scenic/Props - $500
  • Projections - $400
  • Sound - $250
  • Costumes - $250
  • Lighting - $250
  • Food for YOU - $120
If the goal is not reached, the show will still go up. However, it may be told in a more reduced form. Where's the fun in that?
Remember, the more you donate, the more perks you get to experience!

The Effect 

From Ori Bensimhon:

"Othello et al is a show that’s designed to highlight the importance of personal perspective, and the emotional complexities involved in every decision we – as people – make. 

By offering our audience so many different perspectives on the same series of events, we encourage them to question, rather than judge people who make decisions with unsavory results. 

If we stop reacting to conflict and instead, approach it with consideration – if we stop to question what feeds it – then we might avoid resolutions as tragic as that of Shakespeare’s Othello."


Meet the Company:

Production Staff 
Director: Michael J. Terebush
Set Design/Props: Stephanie Gonzalez
Sound Design: Tom King
Choreography: Jacqui Marron
Playwright: Ori Bensimhon
Stage Manager: Kara Mendez

Cast
Othello: Tiffany Phillips Maxwell
Desdemona: Samantha Simone
Iago: Matthew Gill Clark
Cassio: Christian Spinella
Emilia: Amber Walker
Narrator: Jennifer Paldino
Chorus #1/Brabantio: Tiffany Machado
Chorus #2/Montano: Sara Malinowski
Chorus #3/Young Lad/Ludovico: Jacqui Marron


The show will take place April 24, 25, 26 @ 8pm.
story_txt:
Meet The Director
 Hello! My name is Michael J. Terebush. I am currently a senior at Ramapo College of New Jersey. I have directed several shows both within and outside of Ramapo College. I have come to direct shows with three things at the forefront: what is the  essence of the show? How do I want the audience to experience the show? How can I combine those two things to make it cohesive? 
With your help, all of the members of the Damascena NY Performing Ensemble will be able to put on a show at The Alchemical Theatre Laboratory with the multimedia that it needs to succeed.     What We Need & What You Get In order to produce this play the Damascena NY Performing Ensemble, asks that you donate generously. Here's where your money is going:  Venue - $1500
Scenic/Props - $500
Projections - $400
Sound - $250
Costumes - $250
Lighting - $250
Food for YOU - $120 
If the goal is not reached, the show will still go up. However, it may be told in a more reduced form. Where's the fun in that?
Remember, the more you donate, the more perks you get to experience!   The Effect 
From Ori Bensimhon: 
"Othello et al is a show that’s designed to highlight the importance of personal perspective, and the emotional complexities involved in every decision we – as people – make. 
By offering our audience so many different perspectives on the same series of events, we encourage them to question, rather than judge people who make decisions with unsavory results. 
If we stop reacting to conflict and instead, approach it with consideration – if we stop to question what feeds it – then we might avoid resolutions as tragic as that of Shakespeare’s Othello."   
    Meet the Company: 
Production Staff Director: Michael J. TerebushSet Design/Props: Stephanie GonzalezSound Design: Tom KingChoreography: Jacqui MarronPlaywright: Ori BensimhonStage Manager: Kara MendezCastOthello: Tiffany Phillips MaxwellDesdemona: Samantha SimoneIago: Matthew Gill ClarkCassio: Christian SpinellaEmilia: Amber WalkerNarrator: Jennifer PaldinoChorus #1/Brabantio: Tiffany MachadoChorus #2/Montano: Sara MalinowskiChorus #3/Young Lad/Ludovico: Jacqui MarronThe show will take place April 24, 25, 26 @ 8pm.

story:
"Teel's work is rich in multidisciplinary references- pushing the limits in dance." -Stigmart10 Videofocus Biennial, 2014

My name is Morgan Teel and I am on a mission to create, develop, and share interdisciplinary dance, in the forms of live performance and inclusion of video art production that perpetually challenges and artistically stimulates.

It is important to me that my choreography is accessible and interactive in the Austin community, as well as nationally and internationally. Being interdisciplinary, what makes my creative work unique is that it serves as a bridge between disciplines, cultures, and communities-- creating a dance film that honors and celebrates the architecture of the new urbanist community, Seaside, Florida, is just one way I plan to do this in 2015.

How It All Started

Why interdisciplinary?

Why have just a chocolate chip cookie when you can have an M&M cookie with chocolate chips? Growing up in Florida, I could never settle on that or making just one art. I ran from theatre to dance rehearsal to voice lessons. So I guess you could say I grew on solid artistic and academic endeavors- but never together. When I moved to Mississippi for college, I focused on dance but used other art forms to fuel my choreography. My last year of school there was a tornado that destroyed the performing arts center- forcing students to find alternative avenues for choreography. In a twisted way (literally!), I am thankful for that tornado because it was here that I found a love for video art that encompasses movement, architecture, and historical and scientific context. Through the creation of my first and second dance films, I become aware of the connectivity dance merged with film brought to a community. So now I am seeking to connect, bridge, and fill the gaps in my new community, Austin, Texas, by continuing to make interdisciplinary dance accessible through the creation of new work.

So you’re new to the professional world?

“Emerging choreographer” is the word kids like to use these days. I graduated in May 2014. A week later, my choreography was shared for the first time professionally to the Tampa, Florida community and a month after I packed my bags and moved to Austin, Texas. These past six months have been spent making my video art accessible to communities at a national and international level, teaching interdisciplinary dance making to elementary students in schools, rehearsing for a dance that functions as both concert and film, and brainstorming, dreaming and devising a plan for how to make interdisciplinary dance accessible, affordable, and relatable to local and national communities.

So are you working independently?

Yes and no. It’s complicated. Yes, because I am an independent choreographer without non-profit status. No, because I have an amazing group of dancers who are just as passionate about interdisciplinary dance works that educate and enhance a community. Though I act as an artistic director, I work collaboratively with other artists.

Are you receiving any other funding? 

Nope! That is why I seriously need you! My last semester of school I received a $1,000 award for creative/multidisciplinary research & through careful budgeting these funds have supported the success of artistic endeavors the past six months but now that is fizzling out. I have researched and applied for countless independent artist grants but they are hard to come by and highly competitive.

This Is Where You Come In

What we need: MOOLAH’S! To be exact, $2,000.

Here is the 2015 budget in a nutshell:

  • Artistic Staff: $355
  • Travel: $650
  • Space Rental: $350
  • Equipment Rental/Purchase: $90
  • Supplies/Materials: $185
  • Marketing/Promotion: $185
  • Production/Exhibition Costs: $185

What exactly does this all go towards?

In general, it will go towards paying my artistic staff because their quite amazing, the creation of new work, and sharing this work with communities through visual and participatory engagements. For example, in January I will be traveling to Seaside, Florida for a multidisciplinary residency in which I will create a new dance film, host a critical discussion about video art with college students, and engage the community with participatory workshops. I am thrilled that my 2015 season encompasses creating new work in my current community as well as the community I grew up around in Seaside, Florida!

So what’s in store for you:

  • $10: Exclusive email updates & invitations to premiere parties throughout the entire 2015 season
  • $25: Handwritten postcard featuring a still from a dance film
  • $50: Stack of postcards with video art stills & DVD of past work
  • $100: DVD of future work

Your Support Counts!

I have already seen the fruits of sharing this love of video art and interdisciplinary dance to the world. The past six months my choreography has shown in a dance festival, an art gallery, a historical palace and other venues in Tampa, Chicago, New York, and Italy. I have also shared my creative process in an interview with Stigmart10's Videofocus Biennial, an online video art publication. I am so thrilled that people across the globe are able to engage and connect with art through my choreography and I cannot wait to continue to make an impact through projects in 2015.

What's the risks and challenges?

Sure, there is a challenge but it is nothing I have not already experienced & overcome. Like I said, the past six months I have not had any funding for my work. That did not stop me from my creative endeavors. I simply found low-cost alternatives to share my work & begin the process of making a new one. So the challenge for 2015 is not creating new work, I will do this regardless. The challenge is having my work funded in order to have exponential growth and success of my craft, as well as making interdisciplinary art accessible to communities.

Other Ways You Can Help

If you're tight on money, I get it. I’ve been there with you. 

5 Ways You Can Still Show Support

  • Get hands on! I am in need of a technical crew, printing services, graphic designer, costume design and a photographer in both Seaside & Austin. Email me at teelmorgan@gmail.com.
  • Get creative! If you have a skill or service that you feel we might be able to benefit from, let me know! I would love to hear from you. Email me at teelmorgan@gmail.com.
  • Make some noise! Share this campaign on social media.
  • Make some more noise! Go shout it on a mountaintop. We want everyone to be a part of this journey with us & that starts with you.
  • Make even more noise! Seriously, third times a charm.

story:
So, what's the story?

Hollywood 1949. A time when the movies were king and the movie stars merely pawns for the studio bosses. 

A time when passion was lauded but sex never discussed. So when naive young actor, Patrick Glass, embarks on a scandalous homosexual love affair with his famous co-star, he starts to feel the full force of the studio's career-destroying muscle. Forty years later, as the truths of the past are uncovered, the true consequences of this 'unacceptable' romance come to light.

Tell me more...

The play’s inception began back in late 2005 when writer Dylan Costello was living in Los Angeles. Spending an unusually rainy day watching classic movies from the golden age of Hollywood, Dylan became fascinated by the reality back then of gay actors such as Montgomery Clift and Rock Hudson and how they dealt with hiding their true sexuality amongst the cogs of the great Hollywood Machine. Further research into the era uncovered truths and lies about the attitudes towards homosexuality in the 1940’s movie industry, especially when the moralistic Production Code was in full force, forbidding even the hint of sexually ambiguous behavior on the silver screen. This was Hollywood after all, a twisted utopia where image, control, money and power were the only things that mattered. A place where the reality never matched the fantasy – and a world that required the forced suppression of one’s homosexuality should one want to keep their movie career. But this was the 1940s and you would think that these homophobic attitudes would have been gradually erased over the last few decades. But the sad truth is that they haven’t and still to this day, gay actors are being asked to choose between their sexuality and their career… and so the Hollywood closet is as full as it ever was.

So this play deals with the important issue of homophobia?

Indeed. The play highlights attitudes towards homosexuality, showing that the homophobia of over 70 years ago can still exist today and awareness of it must still continue without complacency. We want audiences to watch this play and be moved by its message, to show how damaging homophobia truly is - told through the story of it existing in a different era whilst realising that times have not changed as much as people think despite advancements in attitudes towards homosexuality.


So who are Giant Cherry Productions?

Giant Cherry Productions is a UK-based non-profit company that was created with a singular vision in mind - to bring a wave of new LGBT productions to the global film, theater and television scene. Our simple manifesto is to have LGBT characters, stories and themes represented in the same way as non-LGBT - ie - to be seen as 'normal'.

We pride ourselves on striving to put on original works, some controversial, some that push the envelope. We believe that creativity should be about taking risks, challenging audiences' perceptions and provoking their thoughts and imaginations.

We believe it is vitally important for the gay community to see itself represented on film, stage and television. Issues are universal, regardless of sexuality. We are all human beings who all live, love and lose just like everyone else. We have love stories, we have tragedies. Sexuality shouldn’t be an issue. So we believe it’s always appealing to see plays, movies, TV shows where characters have the same problems as everyone else – and they just happen to be gay.

Over the past few years, our work has been nominated for (and won) several awards and our reputation is growing to an extent where we are proud to have this chance to bring a production to the US for the first time.

And Giant Cherry are partnering with Chicago-based Glitterati Productions on this play. Tell us more about them.

Glitterati are well renowned on the Chicago theater scene and was founded in 2005 to produce Ken Ludwig's Moon Over Buffalo, which ran for three months at Theater Building Chicago. Since that time, the company has been involved in productions of Gypsy and No, No, Nanette, a staged reading of Mr. Shaw Goes to Hollywood at Victory Gardens, and along with Pride Films and Plays, Glitterati co-produced the critically acclaimed production of David Drake's The Night Larry Kramer Kissed Me at Luna Central. Up next is a new musical, Heavenly Evening, which brings together Judy Garland, Ethel Merman, Beatrice Lillie, Cole Porter, and Noel Coward. Music and lyrics by Robert Benson with a book by John Nasca.

So this is the US premier of 'The Glass Protege' in Chicago?

Yes, indeed. Giant Cherry Productions is excited and honored to be bringing its signature production The Glass Protégé to Chicago theater audiences. Writer Dylan Costello first connected with the Chicago theater community when his play Hello Norma Jeane was one of five finalists in Pride Films and Plays’ 2011 Great Gay Play and Musical Contest. Dylan flew to Chicago from London for the enhanced staged reading of Hello Norma Jeane in 2012 and was so impressed by the work of director John Nasca on the piece that he introduced John to his newest play The Glass Protégé, and a co-production was soon born. Giant Cherry has always been impressed with the quality and reputation of Chicago theater, seeing it as a valuable and extremely worthwhile market that easily rivals New York. Having the chance to bring this production to the Windy City only highlights the importance of the exciting Chicago theater scene and the many talented creatives that inhabit it, for the reputation of this very meaningful theater community extends far beyond the confines of the United States.

What we need and what you get

This play is getting a buzz already and we want to build upon and utilise this energy to achieve success in bringing our work to as wider an audience as possible. We feel tackling the play's issues and themes on homophobia head-on in an uncompromising way will only strengthen our reputation as a company focusing on LGBT issues. It's important that it's a success so that our reputation can increase which will in turn make more people aware of our passion for LGBT productions, visibility and rights a human beings in general. Our passion is to develop further as a company at what is a momentous time for us.

We have reached a point with the success of our previous productions in that we now are becoming a company that people are aware of - and more importantly - want to work with. Our reputation is as such as we have had - and still have - famous names wanting to be part of our projects and we want to be able to afford all those that wish to work with us, in that we can continue to build on our increasing good reputation.

This activity is also important to us in the uniqueness of the fact that this production will be running in both the UK and USA within two weeks of each other. This is the first time we have had the same play being produced on both sides of the Atlantic and this fact alone is increasing the awareness of our company and getting people talking about our artistic endeavors.

But none of this comes cheap. Our LGBT productions rely majorly on funding and investment from donors. Costs of a typical theater production include sets, costumes, marketing, hire of the theater, etc.

We also have a super-talented cast and crew already signed up for the production who passionately believe in - and want to be part of - this exciting new play.

How will my contribution help?

The Glass Protege is our signature production and one that we feel very proud of. We want the show to be the best it can possibly be. Even just the smallest contribution will go a long way to helping find that essential item of costume or pay for refreshments for the actors during the busy rehearsal period. But more importantly, your contribution will ultimately enable the important message in this play to reach the audience that it needs. It's a time when LBGT rights are becoming more widespread but at at the same time, LGBT rights in other countries are being eroded in terrible ways. Homophobia is still alive and well and this show will tell the damaging effects it can have on those - and how their lives are destroyed - because of falling victim to it. Closeted Hollywood stars, your fun neighbor or the cute guy that serves you in the local bar, their sexuality will still be seen as 'an issue' by sadly so many. We had men from a certain generation come to see the original production of this play four years ago and received messages from them long after telling how the play affected them, as if it was their story being told on stage. The story of being gay in an era which criminalized them for being so. If this new version of the same production can reach and affect people in the same way, then it's a job well done. And your contribution, no matter how small, will help make that happen.


Other Ways You Can Help

If you are unable to contribute, that doesn't mean you still can't help:

  • Please feel free to share this campaign via social  media and the Indiegogo share tools.
  •  Or please do come and see the show if you can!

Many thanks for your time!

Giant Cherry Productions and Glitterati Productions

story:
SLENDER

Reality:Check Productions presents SLENDER, a new play by Shane O’Regan, inspired by the urban legend of The Slender Man.

There have always been whispers in the night... but what if those stories told around the campfire weren't just stories? On a dark, cold night deep in the forests of Ireland, a chance meeting brings the legend of The Slender Man to life and tests the theory that if you truly believe something is real... it may just become real.

After all, once you see him… you are his.

THE TEAM:

Premieres February 24th – March 7th, 2015.


CAST

Shane O’Regan

Stephen O’Leary

Hilary Bowen-Walsh


CREATIVE TEAM

Director / Ronan Dempsy

Producer/Jamie Hallahan

Visual Design / Ste Murray

WHAT YOU GET:

  • Reality:Check need to €800 to fund this play and get our company off the ground!
  • In return we can offer you some fun perks in exchange for your funding
  • You will also be supporting the Arts, which is always great
  • But most importantly: YOU WILL BE HELPING TO DEFEAT THE SLENDERMAN! Lets make sure he can never take another soul!
The Impact

Your money will go to:

  • Building our set! (we need to keep up with the beautiful sets that are standard in Theatre Upstairs!)
  • Advertising! Paying for our visual design and printing so we can promote the show physically and stop clogging up your news feeds! (Sorry!)
  • Pay our amazing cast and crew! It is of upmost importance to us at Reality:Check to make sure our cast and crew our paid. They are so phenomenal and always go above and beyond, without even being asked.

Reality:Check

Reality:Check Productions are a brand new company set up in 2015.

We are so excited to bring a huge range of new work to the public, be it Theatre, Film, or general craic!

We are so passionate about this project and with everything we do and we will never forget the help we were give by all of you amazing human beings.

We will strive to entertain and engage you in every way we can, for years to come!

After all, This is only the first step...

Other Ways You Can Help

Even if you cant afford to give any money (we all know the feeling), We would really appreciate if you gave our Indiegogo page a share to help us on our way

Love, always

Shane O'Regan & Stephen O'Leary

Reality:Check Productions
story_txt:
SLENDERReality:Check Productions presents SLENDER, a new play by Shane O’Regan, inspired by the urban legend of The Slender Man.There have always been whispers in the night... but what if those stories told around the campfire weren't just stories? On a dark, cold night deep in the forests of Ireland, a chance meeting brings the legend of The Slender Man to life and tests the theory that if you truly believe something is real... it may just become real.After all, once you see him… you are his.THE TEAM:Premieres February 24th – March 7th, 2015.CASTShane O’ReganStephen O’LearyHilary Bowen-WalshCREATIVE TEAMDirector / Ronan DempsyProducer/Jamie HallahanVisual Design / Ste MurrayWHAT YOU GET:

story:
The Big Picture:

In association with Bonne Compagnie Collective, independent dance artists Elke Schroeder and Christine Birch are in the process of creating Soft Limits, a new full-length work of dance theatre to premier in September 2014.

Under the mentorship of Iñaki Azpillaga (of the Brussels-based dance company Ultima Vez) Elke will be choreographing and performing this work with the dance talents of Christine Birch, Jane Alison McKinney, Sérgio Mendes, Kate Nankervis, Danielle O'Reilly and Brodie Stevenson.  This project will also include the musical direction of Valerie Calam, lighting design by Simon Rossiter and make-up and prosthetics by Joey Hinds.

(*For more detailed bios of the artists please see below, and for inspiring images, dancers' photos and juicy videos, see our gallery).

In June 2013, Elke and Christine will be travelling to Brussels for an intensive 2 week research residency.  This first period of creation and movement coaching will be led by Iñaki and attended by Sérgio and Danielle.  There will be several dance artists invited into the process from the Brussels contemporary dance community (and the other dancers mentioned above will be joining in later creation processes).

 

And this is where we need your help!

This is where everything starts!

This research/residency period is invaluable to the creation of Soft Limits.  Even though we have to travel to make it happen, this residency will allow for:

Concentrated research time:  We will be in the studio working on movement research for 5 hours/day during the 2 week period - a lot of work can be done in this time as we'll have little interruption!

Immersion in the Brussels dance community:  Brussels is the heart of the Euro dance scene and we will have the opportunity to soak in its different dance aesthetic by participating in morning classes and working in-studio with talented international dance artists.  This means we will deepen our knowledge of floorwork and partnering, necessary components of the Soft Limits vocabulary.  We will be breaking out of our physical comfort zone!       

Mentorship with Iñaki:  It is truly a rare and exciting opportunity to be mentored by such a brilliant dance mind - and on his own turf!  He has also hand-picked the dance artists that will be joining us and volunteering their time to "play" with us in the studio.

This is just the first stage of our creation process.  From this, we will bring back a large amount of material and choreography that we can mold in our upcoming research/creation periods in Toronto.  In addition, we will be able to share the dance knowledge with our Toronto dance family.  We will be bringing Iñaki to Toronto to continue the mentorship process, as well as to lead workshops in partnering and technique (hosted by the TO Dance Community Love-In).

 

 

A little introduction to the concept of Soft Limits:

Definition: Soft Limits (from the practice of BDSM)

Limits which are not necessarily set in stone. They may be flexible, may be pushed or may change over time and/or with experience or knowledge of that type of (sexual) play.  Soft limits require a cautious approach and, while appealing, can still generate an uncomfortable amount of fear.

Intrigued?  

Here are few words from choreographer Elke Schroeder:

"The concept for this dance piece comes from my studies at UWaterloo where I have been researching sacred ritual and its relationship to sexuality and the body.  As society becomes more sexually free, how does this effect relationships (to self and others), gender roles, and norms, and how is this reflected in media, choice of clothing, and "personal" ritual?  In sexuality, where is the line between sacred and profane?

In Soft Limits, I want to explore these themes through an apt medium: the dancing body.  Specifically, I want to express ideas of restriction versus freedom, adornment/clothing, fluidity of gender roles and game-playing.  This last idea of "play" is particularly rich for me - think of all of the games we played as children that could very quickly turn "adult" if played out in a certain way... Twister... Show and Tell...  Truth or Dare... Blind Man's Bluff... Tag... 

Soft Limits will be a piece that challenges on every level.  The movement vocabulary will be physical to the extreme - virtuosic technique interwoven with intricate partnering. The dancers in this work are compelling performers and I will encourage them to take risks both in creation and onstage.  I want to give the audience an experience that will shock and amaze but still be easy to connect with." 

Soft Limits... Collison/Sex/Culture/Boundaries/Play

 

The Dirty (Practical) Details:

For this leg of the process, we're looking to raise $7,000.00.  Here is where the funds will go:

 - return flights to Brussels for Elke and Christine

 - mentorship fees (at a reduced rate!) for Iñaki

 - artists' fees (at a reduced rate) for the dancers involved

 - studio rental in Brussels

- accommodations (at a reduced rate!)

 Food and any other costs will be coming from the artists themselves and any money that we raise above our goal (and anything left over from after the residency) will be put towards our next creation period in Toronto in September 2013. 

 

And Now, Something More Exciting!

We can't express enough how much we appreciate your support.  In return for your generous donations, we can offer you some creative gifts to express our gratitude.  As strong women, we decided to channel Greek Goddesses for our funding perks - we hope they make you smile. :)

 

Other Ways You Can Help:

As dancers, we understand that not everyone can give monetarily... Would you consider helping us by sharing our campaign?  Help us by creating buzz for Soft Limits!  

Do you have any contacts in Brussels?  We would love to connect with people living there (dancers and non-dancers alike) and possibly find a place to stay that would not be too expensive...?  We would also love to hear from you if you have connections for reduced flights or anything else you think we may need for our residency.

We also accept: love letters, hugs and high fives ;)

 

The Finale:


We are extremely passionate and driven artists and are excited at the impact that Soft Limits could have - on the audiences that see it, on the Toronto Dance community and on ourselves as dance artists.  We want to contribute to the evolution of contemporary dance in Canada by pushing at its limits with our work, and this research period Brussels is this work's first step.  As individuals, we have been part of many successful dance projects, and now we want to pool our talents in the creation of this new and exciting dance piece.


With every ounce of our beings, we thank you for your support.

Love and more Love to you - Elke, Christine and the artists of Soft Limits

 

 


Artist Bios:

 

Elke Schroeder is an independent dance artist based in Toronto working as a performer, choreographer and instructor.  Since graduating from The School of Toronto Dance Theatre in 2005, she has had the pleasure of working with Blue Ceiling Dance, TILT Sound + Motion, Catalyst Dance Company, Lindsay Ritter Dance and Event Horizon Dance, and performing for Amanda Acorn, Susie Burpee, Vanessa Kimmons, Kate Nankervis, Andrea Nann, and Daryl C. Tracy.  In 2011, Elke co-founded Bonne Compagnie with dance artists Amanda Acorn and Kate Nankervis and continues to create and perform with this collective.  Elke has continued her training in Europe, focusing on floorwork technique (and studying extensively with Iñaki Azpillaga of Ultima Vez), and from this she has created a class called FloorWork(ed) for professional dancers and beginners.  Currently, she is dancing a new creation for Blue Ceilings Dance and on a solo project entitled Avalanche.  Elke is also a yoga teacher and a student of the Independent Studies Program at UWaterloo – a program that is self-directed (thesis-based) and incorporates her work with movement and sexuality.      

 

 

 

 

After fourteen years of classical ballet training, Christine Birch attended The School of Toronto Dance where she had the pleasure of working with D.A. Hoskins, James Kudelka, Peggy Baker, Sasha Ivanochko and Danny Grossman.  She has danced for Peggy Baker in move and Tino Seghall's work Kiss at the Art Gallery of Ontario. Birch has also worked with independent choreographers Meryem Alaoui, Rhonda Baker, Lady Janitor and Elke Schroeder.  Birch is co-founder of multi-disciplinary arts collective called One Trunk and produced and danced in everything in moderation as part of the 2011 Toronto Fringe Festival. She is a member of Skindivers Dance Company formed by Hanna Kent and has taken part in both Impulstanz (Vienna) and Reykjavik International Dance Festivals.  Currently she is working on developing a solo/duet show with Rhonda Baker and plans to attend Deltebre Dansa this coming July.

 

 

Iñaki Azpillaga was born in Donostia (Spain).  Bask folk dance was his initial approach to dance, and his dance formation is comprised of classical ballet studies as well as jazz, modern and contemporary dance.  After dancing with the National Ballet Company of Spain, Iñaki directed his career towards the contemporary dance field, working with different companies and in a variety of productions in Spain.  He then studied composition, improvisation and lighting design at Nikolais/Louis School in New York.  Winning the first prize in the VI Choreographic Contest of Madrid gave him the opportunity to create his first production “Diálogo de sordos” (Deaf Dialogues).  Following an encounter with Wim Vandekeybus, Iñaki joined his company Ultima Vez in Brussels. For three years he performed in his creations and he now assists his choreographies.  Currently, he combines assistance to dance creations with his pedagogical engagement; he teaches workshops and gives dance lessons to professionals and in dance schools. Within the teaching frame he has created the pieces: Cyclopes (Tokyo 2010) and Jeffrey.1 (Copenhagen 2011).

 

 

Sérgio Mendes trained in Chapitô, Portugal and E.S.A.C., Brussels, where he took a BA-degree in acrobatics.  He has taught at Danshögskolan, Teaterhögskolan Stockholm,and has danced for choreographer Robert Olivan.  He directed, choreographed and performed in Man-made manners presented in Portugal and “The more you hit me, the more I like you”;he won the Move-against-it contest in Salzburg.  With the Norwegian social anthropologist Christian Kuran, he explored the topic of domestic violence.  Sérgio has trained with Wim Vandekeybus, Jozef Frucek, Linda Kapetanea, and Anton Lacky, as well as at a kung fu monastery in china: living, observing and training in martial arts.

 

 

Kate Nankervis is an indie dancer and choreographer based in Toronto. She has a BFA (hons) in Dance from York University. In 2012 she founded Katheros in Motion as a vehicle for her work, only place, her first solo show has toured nationally and internationally and will be presented in May 2013. She has worked for various artists including Elke Schroeder, Blue Ceilings Dance, Eroca Nicols/Lady Janitor, Vanessa Kimmons, Bee Palomina, Bluemouth Inc. (NY) and Tino Sehgal(GER). Her choreography has been described as ‘brisk and entirely human” - Eye Weekly and "gripping and beautifully eerie"- Mooney on Theatre 2011. Kate is a recipient of the IMASCO Performing Arts Award 2008. She works with adelheid dance projects as rehearsal and project assistant and is a co-director of the Toronto Dance Community Love- In. (www.katherosinmotion.ca)

 

  

After studying theatre for four years in Victoria and Vancouver Brodie Stevenson discovered dance through the practice of Contact Improvisation. In 2004 he enrolled in The School of Toronto Dance Theatre and graduated in 2007.  Stevenson has recently worked with choreographers Julia Aplin, Peggy Baker, Sylvie Bouchard, Darryl Hoskins, and Sasha Ivanochko. He is an active member of the collaborative dance collective, Octamerous. With the Throwdown Collective he co-created One Couch for the 2009 season of Dusk Dances and remounted the piece for their 2010 season.  Stevenson is currently a company member of Toronto Dance Theatre where he has worked with choreographers such as Josh Beamish, Deborah Hay, Christopher House, Felix Marchand, and Natasha Torres-Garner.

story:
Who am I?

I am a stand-up comedian from England, currently based in Melbourne, Australia.

I have recently released my free debut comedy special 'Infinite Love'. You can watch the video at the Youtube link above, or download the audio album from http://www.alandriscoll.com/comedy

What do I need?

I need to raise $500 dollars to pay the venue hire fee for my 2013 show at the Melbourne International Comedy Festival.

The show will take place at Station 59 in Melbourne over 10 nights from 27th to 31st March and 3rd to 7th April.

Entry will be free. The show will also be recorded and released online as my second free-to-download comedy album.

What is the show about?

Here's the official blurb:

Have you ever noticed that men always leave the toilet seat up, while women break your heart with apathy? Have you ever noticed that men commit the vast majority of violent crimes, whereas women like shoes?

Have you ever noticed how an increasingly fluid spectrum of human sexuality undermines outdated comedy routines based on gender binaries?

Happily married, and 10,000 miles away from his ex-girlfriends, Alan Driscoll is finally at a safe enough distance to tackle some of his issues with women. How do you cope with sexual rejection? How can we resist the lure of infinite free pornography? Why can’t we all just get along?

What does your money go on?

The $500 dollars goes straight to the venue to pay the hire fee. This is a completely non-profit endeavour, and the album will be free for anybody to download.

Your contribution also entitles you to a range of exciting perks as detailed on the right.

How else can you help?

If you can't afford to contribute, please help spread the word about this campaign by sharing the link to your friends.

story:
Short Summary

These are tough times, as we are all aware. The global economic collapse of the past few years have all but gutted the funding to the arts in the United States. As such defunkt theatre finds ourselves in a position of an unexpected funding shortfall for the 2013 season leading into a major dual production of the landmark plays The Children’s Hour and The Boys in the Band. These pieces of theater provide a vital mirror to our society’s struggle with equality, humanity and diversity.
 
"One of Portland's essential theater companies." - Willamette Week

Why should you care? How can you help?  These are both valid questions.  We are seeking emergency funding to fill the gap. Every little bit helps.  (and hey, all donations are entirely tax deductable)
 
 "defunkt reminds us why risky theater is worth our time." The Oregonian

defunkt theatre is a nationally recognized, 501-c3 non-profit ensemble theatre company dedicated to creating innovative productions that challenge conventional ideals of society and theatre. We offer fresh and relevant perspectives on issues of race, gender, and class. We strive to stretch the minds and comfort zones of our audience.
 
"defunkt theatre has made a name for itself presenting theatre that explores sexuality and gender politics. Their reputation has made them a magnet for directors looking to work with challenging themes."- Ken Hoyt- Just Out

defunkt theatre began in 2000 as four artists with a goal of producing first class, riveting and fearless theater unlike any they saw in Portland.

defunkt theatre has grown and changed since then, but the mission and the aesthetic remain the same. defunkt theatre offers more pay what you can nights than any other theater company in the Pacific Northwest, nearly half of all performances.
 
defunkt theatre was listed as one of the 12 'Hot Hip and On the Verge' US theatre companies by American Theater Magazine.

Since its inception defunkt has won the following drammy awards:

2001: set design: The Woods: damali ayo.
2002: lighting design: Phaedra's Love: james moore.
2003: set design: The Bad Infinity: damali ayo and kollodi.
male in a lead role: cart: rollin carlson.
2004: male in a supporting role: Cloud 9: peter buonincontro.
2005: set design: Killing Game: bill tripp.
2006: costume design: Doctor Faustus Lights the Lights: lori sue hoffman.
direction: Doctor Faustus Lights the Lights: kristan seemel.
2008: direction: The Lesser Magoo: sarah jane hardy.
2010 4.48 Psychosis:
Outstanding Production
Director: Grace Carter
Ensemble: Christy Bigelow, Joel Harmon, Matthew Kern
Sound Design: Richard E. Moore.
2012 Portland Civic Theatre Guild Award                                                                      
 

What We Need & What You Get

We are seeking $10,000 to pay for the production rights to both plays, materials for the sets, costumes, lights, sound, space rental, and compensation for the more than 30 local artists involved in this project.  Half of the performances will be pay-what-you-can to allow access to all members of the community. All funds raised will go towards this production.

The Impact

Herstory/History : a pair of landmark plays in repertory:  The Children’s Hour by Lillian Hellman and The Boys in The Band by Mart Crowley.  Two of the earliest depictions of homosexuality in mainstream culture, these plays have been rarely seen in recent years  but they still have a great deal to say about the gay experience in America.  Lillian Hellman’s first play, The Children’s Hour is the story of two women falsely accused of a sexual relationship and the devastating consequences of that lie.  The nine men that make up The Boys in the Band were among the first positive depictions of openly gay men in America.   Director Jon Kretzu collaborates with defunkt theatre to produce two evenings of theater that mirror and inform each other, showing us both how far we have come as a society, and how far we have yet to go.
 
*Note: The Children’s Hour will be performed at The Back Door Theater on Hawthorne Blvd, and The Boys in the Band will be site specific in an alternate location.  May 10th through June 16th 2013.
 
Both shows  are directed by Jon Kretzu who recently completed a 20 year stint as Associate Artistic Director at Artists Repertory Theatre, where he directed over 40 productions for the company.  Other Portland directing credits include Dracula for Northwest Classical Theatre Company; The Carpetbagger's Children for Profile Theatre; Guys and Dolls for The Musical Theatre Company; Romeo and Juliet, A Winter's Tale, Much Ado About Nothing and As You Like It for Tygres Heart Shakespeare Company; Waiting for Vern, Jeffrey, Bent and The Sum of Us for triangle! productions; Broadway Bound and Hay Fever for Portland Repertory Theater; The Importance of Being Earnest for New Rose Theatre; The Mystery of Irma Vep for Storefront Theatre; and Down the Road for the Oregon One-Act Festival. Jon has also directed numerous productions in Seattle, Milwaukee, San Francisco, Chicago and Los Angeles.  Jon was the dramaturg for Portland Repertory Theatre, has served as a guest director and professor at a number of West Coast and Midwest universities, and has worked as an acting coach in Los Angeles, Seattle and Portland. He has also served as the London and New York theater and classical music correspondent for a variety of Northwest newspapers and magazines.

Even if you can not financially contribute to this project you can still help us my sharing on Facebook, Twitter and all other media you might be privy to!  THANK YOU.
story_txt:
Short Summary
These are tough times, as we are all aware. The global economic collapse of the past few years have all but gutted the funding to the arts in the United States. As such defunkt theatre finds ourselves in a position of an unexpected funding shortfall for the 2013 season leading into a major dual production of the landmark plays The Children’s Hour and The Boys in the Band. These pieces of theater provide a vital mirror to our society’s struggle with equality, humanity and diversity.
 
"One of Portland's essential theater companies." - Willamette Week

Why should you care? How can you help?  These are both valid questions.  We are seeking emergency funding to fill the gap. Every little bit helps.  (and hey, all donations are entirely tax deductable)
 

 "defunkt reminds us why risky theater is worth our time." The Oregoniandefunkt theatre is a nationally recognized, 501-c3 non-profit ensemble theatre company dedicated to creating innovative productions that challenge conventional ideals of society and theatre. We offer fresh and relevant perspectives on issues of race, gender, and class. We strive to stretch the minds and comfort zones of our audience.
 

"defunkt theatre has made a name for itself presenting theatre that explores sexuality and gender politics. Their reputation has made them a magnet for directors looking to work with challenging themes."- Ken Hoyt- Just Outdefunkt theatre began in 2000 as four artists with a goal of producing first class, riveting and fearless theater unlike any they saw in Portland.defunkt theatre has grown and changed since then, but the mission and the aesthetic remain the same. defunkt theatre offers more pay what you can nights than any other theater company in the Pacific Northwest, nearly half of all performances.

story:
In the past five years, Sideshow Theatre Company has taken on Hell, serial killers, Greeks, embodiments of death itself, and even real live working on-stage robots. We've made a name for ourselves as the best and most inventive ensemble of storytellers in Chicago, but this summer we'll be taking on our biggest challenge yet: THE END OF THE WORLD. (reverb, reverb.)
 
Our world premiere production of Carrie Barrett's The Burden of Not Having a Tail will bring audiences into Sideshow's own, homemade and up-to-snuff survival bunker at Chicago Dramatists, and take them through a hilarious, outlandish and surprisingly moving look at what it takes to prepare for all eventualities. Sideshow Ensemble Member Karie Miller will be acting as tour guide, bringing this amazing new one-woman show to life and getting deep into the mindset of a survivor.
 
Of course, in any doomsday scenario, the Number One Most Important Thing is to be prepared, and doing so properly means that we need your help! A donation to this campaign will allow us to obtain all the must-haves: rice, detergent, rice, stage lights, guns, salt, sound cues, rice, a tank, bouncy balls, med supplies, rock salt, tv sets, anthropomorphic evolutionarily-discarded anthropomorphic tails, rice, and of course, a properly fortified, fully high-functioning, A++ state-of-the-art concrete bunker. Your donation will help support our production budget, including set, props, sound, lights, actor fees and space rental, and contribute to the creation of a immersive, off-kilter and constantly surprising world that properly reflects the mad-cap energy of the script. We hope you will support one of Sideshow's most ambitious productions to date, and help us bring this new work to life with the best storytelling imaginable.
 
If you can't make a donation, there's still plenty of room in the bunker: be sure to reserve your seat for The Burden of Not Having a Tail, running this summer from June 29th-August 4th! You'll be glad that you did, when the end comes.
